PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes attempts by the government to raise the pension age for women from 60 to 65 years.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate oppose this proposed change.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bell (from 20 citizens) and Senator Kernot (from 68 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Chemical Registration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals, and full ecological implications of the chemicals, on the package labels and in newspapers etc.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia asks that the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993 be amended with the application of common principles. To ensure that all parents with dependent children are treated equally, allowing maximum freedom of choice in child rearing.
These Acts need to be amended to take account of:

PETITION.PARA: 1.the fact that 60% of married women in the workforce who have children, would prefer to stay at home and mind their children, but for economic reasons can't afford to (Institute of Family Studies Survey).
2.the failure to provide for equitable choice for women and families in allowing parents the maximum right to choose the most appropriate form of care for their children.
3.that there be recognition of a parent at home as a formal occupation reflecting its economic value and worth to society.
4.the need for equal payment of any subsidies and allowances for the care of children, paid directly to the parent.
5.the recognition that a family with more than one child incurs extra expenses.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate amend the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993.

PETITION.TITLE: Forests: Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the ancient and irreplaceable native forests in the South West of Western Australia are being destroyed by logging for woodchipping, that many species in these forests are in danger of extinction, and that Federal Government intervention is urgently needed to protect our natural heritage.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in parliament assembled, should call on the Federal Government to:
1.immediately use its powers to protect Hawke, Sharpe, Giblett and Rocky blocks and all other high conservation value and old growth forests in the South West of Western Australia,
2.refuse to renew woodchip export licences unless it is guaranteed that the wood comes from tree crops, agroforestry or plantations and,
3.take steps to ensure the rapid transfer of the wood products industry from all native forests and on to plantations, tree crops and agroforestry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JONES

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition, from 610 citizens, which is not in conformity with the standing orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws attention to the House that the Federal Government and the State governments (except Tasmania) signed the National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS) in December 1992. The policy states:

`until assessments are completed, forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.' (NFPS page 11)
This obligation is being totally ignored by the NSW Government. A prime example is in the high conservation value Deua Wilderness in southern NSW.

Despite the NFPS obligation, logging activities are continuing in both the Eastern and Western Deua Wilderness before the required assessments. This reckless approach to forest management threatens endangered species known to exist in the area.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to force the NSW Government to cease logging in the Deua Wilderness, and all other areas of high conservation value forest in the state. This will then allow assessments to be undertaken as required by the NFPS.

DEBATE.TITLE: RIGHTS TO PRIVACY AND EQUALITY (ICCPR) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill to implement Australia's international obligations under Articles 17 and 26 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This bill brings into law two articles of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; the right to privacy and the right to equality before the law. It is a response to the Government's so called Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994 introduced in the House of Representatives yesterday.

The Government's Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994 represents a narrow and inadequate approach to protecting the rights of gays and lesbians in our community. In fact, this bill exposes the Government's unwillingness to protect these rights, contrary to Australian Labor Party policy, Australia's international treaty commitments and to the Government's own rhetoric in both international and domestic arenas.

In modern Australia there is a growing majority of people who accept that what happens in people's bedrooms is no basis for discrimination. Yet discrimination continues; on our streets, in our laws, even in this Chamber.
Australian governments need to shake off their homophobia and squeamishness about gays and lesbians and confront the issues.

Our experience in this country of confronting discrimination, whether sex, racial or disability discrimination, shows that laws on their own are not enough. Certainly legislation has powerful symbolic value and provides an avenue for appeal. However you can't legislate to force a change in the attitudes of individuals. Australia has the opportunity to create an innovative link between community education campaigns and law reform in order to eliminate discrimination.
In the legislative sphere there is much that needs to change at all levels of government in Australia.

The Greens (WA) believe government decision making should occur as close as possible to the community who are affected by the decisions. In the case of many laws which affect gays and lesbians it is preferable that the states take the initiative to eliminate any discrimination. However, where states are recalcitrant we support Commonwealth intervention to ensure that our international human rights obligations are met.

The most obvious areas of discrimination in the states are the anomalies between heterosexual and homosexual age of consent laws and the enactment of anti-discrimination laws. The states of Western Australia, New South Wales, Queensland and the Northern Territory have a higher age of consent for homosexuals than for heterosexuals. Western Australian, Tasmania and Victoria have yet to introduce anti-discrimination legislation. Queensland's has a flawed anti-discrimination law which requires change.

These states have exhibited a marked history of recalcitrance in initiating law reform to ensure equality for gays and lesbians. As long as this continues Australia is flouting its international human rights obligations, not to mention basic moral decency. The Federal Government has the clear and unequivocal responsibility and source of power to legislate where the states prove themselves inadequate. I call on the government to enact Commonwealth anti-discrimination legislation based on sexual orientation as a matter of priority.

In the Federal sphere a series of laws deny equality to gays and lesbians. These include laws relating to superannuation, social security, life insurance, industrial relations and the Marriage Act. The Commonwealth, as an employer is also yet to accord its gay and lesbian employees the same conditions as those of heterosexual employees. Although, the recent agreement between unions and the Taxation Department is a positive move in that direction.
The gay and lesbian community around the world has been devastated by the HIV/AIDS pandemic. Laws in this country are yet to fully recognise the rights of people suffering from HIV or AIDS.

While legislation is a key area for reform, government policy must also keep pace with the changing community values. The Commonwealth has strategies and action plans in place for a number of portfolios which still fail to recognise the existence and needs of gays and lesbians in our community. For example we have a national action plan on violence which fails to address the abuse and physical threats that gays and lesbians are subjected to daily.

There is a dire need for counselling services in smaller capitals and regional areas to offer information, help and support to the thousands of gays and lesbians in needs of such services. The Government's health and welfare policies continue to ignore this need. And there are many other examples.

Going hand in hand with the need for legislative and policy change is the need for education. Fostering community awareness of the issues which confront gays and lesbians should not be dismissed as the soft option. A national education campaign, drawing directly from the experience and skills of the gay and lesbian community should be developed as a matter of priority, concurrent with anti-discrimination legislation.

The process of law reform itself is an important opportunity for developing awareness and understanding. Through community debate and input people are able to express there fears and concerns. The law reform debate should not just be pushed by the gay and lesbian rights groups, but by a wide range of people interested in social justice in our community. Meaningful change will require a community approach.

The Australian Law Reform Commission is a useful vehicle for fostering understanding and airing of views on the road to legislative change. It seems incomprehensible that in the last decade of the twentieth century the Commission has yet to receive a referral from the Attorney-General on gay and lesbian law reform in Australia. I call on the Government to do so immediately.

This bill which I have introduced today is in response to the insultingly weak legislation which the government has laid on the table. The Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994 has little to do with human rights and its focus on sexual conduct rather than gays and lesbians as people is yet another insulting example of homophobia in the Government.

It pains me to see this debate de-homosexualised at every turn. The coalition have erected the flimsy mask of states rights in front of their own inability to come to terms with developing a caring social policy. The government in turn has used this bill as a party political point scoring exercise, while at the same time having the audacity to laud this as a great step forward for gays and lesbians.

No one wants to talk about the rights of gays and lesbians to be able to walk down the street free from persecution, being able to show affection in public as our culture (and laws) allows opposite sex couples to do, to create nurturing families, to be free from discriminatory laws, to be valued and respected members of our community.

The Privacy and Equality (ICCPR) Bill 1994 incorporates into domestic law the right to privacy and equality before the law. The bill enshrines this for all Australians. However, the practical affect is to afford groups in our community, such as gays and lesbians, the right to be free from arbitrary interference of privacy and enjoy equality before the law.

The bill fully implements our international human rights obligations with respect to privacy and equality before the law rather than a partial protection of privacy for sexual conduct. It creates a direct inconsistency between any state laws which are in conflict rather than the passive approach of the Government's which requires a challenge to the state laws.

This bill is still a minimalist approach and no substitute for comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation linked with an effective national education program. The gay and lesbian community deserve nothing less from this Parliament.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, and at the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1105 standing in the name of Senator Gibson for this day, relating to an order for the production of a report by the Auditor-General on the Australian National Line.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of confusion in the public arena concerning ANL, particularly regarding valuations and the various statements about the value of a public asset. Because there has been a lot of confusion in the public arena about values as a going concern, and values of the organisation to be liquidated, it behoves the parliament to seek some clarification of those statements. In that way the public will have some understanding of where the truth actually lies and what has happened as a result of this very confusing process.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this matter is urgent. It should not be allowed to go much further. That is why my motion No. 1105 moves to engage the Auditor-General to produce a report for the Senate to clarify this matter and get to the truth. The public is confused, the parliament is confused, and I believe the Senate should have access to a report as soon as possible.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated, the government will not be supporting Senator Gibson's motion. I understand that Senator Collins may be on his way to make a contribution, but time will tell. The Auditor-General is already required to audit the accounts of ANL. The Auditor-General has signed off an unqualified report for 1993 which has already been tabled.

PARA.TAB: In my view, it would be absolutely inappropriate for the parliament to order the Auditor-General to inquire further into ANL when he already has a statutory obligation to audit the annual reports. It seems to me that this exercise has been motivated by very base political motives on the part of Senator Gibson and the opposition—something that we have become used to, I suppose, over the years as this desperate crew on the other side of the chamber try to move the political focus away from its extraordinary troubles and travails. I do not believe that it will succeed in that particular task.

It would ill-behove the Senate to agree to this extraordinary and very unnecessary proposal that Senator Gibson is seeking to move. It is a matter that, clearly, the government will not be supporting. I would urge other honourable senators to treat this particular proposition with the contempt that it deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised at the remarks by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner). I always thought the Australian Labor Party prided itself on supporting open government. Earlier today, the government agreed with a recommendation from the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration which, in itself, provided a move in that direction in terms of freedom of information. We have a very valuable motion from my colleague Senator Gibson which contains the words `there are now available, in the public domain', and yet we are being precluded from being able to debate relevant issues that are in the public domain.

PARA.TAB: This is a house of review, this is a house of debate, where we expect the facts to be put on the table. If the facts are in the public domain, why can the issues not be debated here in this place? It is not a good day for this parliament or for this Senate when the government denies the Senate the opportunity to agree to the motion that my colleague Senator Gibson is seeking to move or in any way to attempt to delay the debate on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps a division on the motion to suspend standing orders might be avoided if I indicate that I will be voting with the opposition.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, now there has been a clarification from Senator Coulter, it appears that yet again the tyranny of numbers are against us. On that understanding, I will not call a division, having made the government's position absolutely and definitively clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly explain the Australian Democrats' position. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 332 of the committee, entitled Australian Government Credit Card. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate my speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome this opportunity to table report No. 332 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which reviews two audit reports on the Australian government credit card. The first audit report was tabled in Parliament in December of last year and a follow up audit was tabled last June. Both reports attracted considerable public attention with occasional sensational articles appearing in the media. It was in this environment that the committee decided to review the credit card system and act, as it were, as the umpire.

PARA.TAB: The committee considers overall that the Australian government credit card provides a useful purchasing tool for government agencies. However, there are areas at both the macro level—an oversight by the Department of Finance—and at the micro level—administration by individual agencies—where improvements can be made. In respect of the macro level, the committee recommended that responsibility for oversight of the credit card system should remain with the Department of Finance, as this fits well with Finance's role as administrator of the public account and oversight of financial management policy. Consequently, the committee does not support the Auditor-General's suggestion that the Department of Administrative Services be responsible for the management of the credit card system or be the sole supplier of training courses.

At present, credit card bills are paid through a system of agency settlement accounts. Although there is evidence that the settlement account system is not working as well as it should be, the committee is not convinced that the system should be abolished. Instead, the committee considers that the current system should be made to work better. We have recommended that various options to improve the system should be developed, tested and trialled.

Turning to the micro level—administration of the credit cards by individual agencies—one of the main findings in the audit report was that departmental controls on the use of credit cards do not provide an adequate audit trail. Evidence received during our review showed that many of the card holders did not retain their yellow Mastercard dockets, let alone other documents.

The committee finds this a totally unacceptable practice and has recommended that all agency heads ensure that all card holders are fully conversant with their obligations; that there be random checking of supporting documentation; and that appropriate penalty mechanisms be introduced for non-compliance. Also, within agencies there are a significant number of credit card holders who do not use their card. We were told that this level was about 25 per cent, which is the normal rate as far as the general community is concerned but is higher than that for corporate cards issued by large business enterprises. The existence of inactive cards poses an unnecessary risk of fraud if the card is lost; an unnecessary administrative burden on agencies; and results in a financial loss to the Commonwealth of some $300,000 because of the annual card fee.

The committee has recommended that credit cards be issued on a needs basis—not on the status of the officer concerned—and also that patterns of credit card usage be reviewed annually with a view to cancelling cards where the level of use cannot justify the expense. The committee also considered the issue of placing limits on individual transactions. This was because the merchant service fee usually ranges from 1.3 per cent to 3 per cent of the value of the transaction. Clearly if the item bought on the credit card is expensive, the fee can exceed the cost of alternative methods of payment. The first audit report, tabled in December 1993, gave an example of a credit card purchase of $900,000 where the merchant service fee was some $11,600. This contrasts with the costs associated with writing a cheque, estimated by the audit office as being about $13.

The committee declined to recommend a public service wide limit on individual transactions, but instead recommended that agencies should set their own limits based on their own typical purchase and expenditure patterns. As well, agencies should monitor all high value transactions to ensure that a cost effective approach was being used by individual card holders.

The current credit card contract expires in June 1995, and the committee considers it is opportune for the Department of Finance to obtain feedback from agencies concerning their experiences with the credit card with a view to incorporating improvements in the new contract. Finance should examine options for incorporating new product developments and improved statistical analysis and management reporting into to the new contract. Also, the contract should be flexible enough to enable the Commonwealth to take advantage of any product or technological improvements which may emerge over the life of the contract.

The committee recognises that Commonwealth agencies operate in a devolved environment and are therefore responsible for administering the credit card system. Nevertheless, the committee considers that Finance, as the responsible central agency, should provide on-going guidance and support to individual agencies to help promote the efficient and consistent use of credit cards throughout the public service. An example of the role that we believe Finance should play is to develop general guidelines on the appropriateness or otherwise of expenditure on items such as travel, hospitality, conferences and other staff related activities.

In closing, I note that, until the Auditor-General decided to conduct an audit, the credit card system had not been evaluated since its introduction in 1987. Although the committee has not endorsed all of Auditor-General's recommendations, I would like to commend the Audit Office for focussing attention on this important issue. I believe that the work undertaken by the audit office has already resulted in significant improvements in the operation of the credit card system. I believe that our recommendations will produce still further improvements. I commend the report to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts on waste disposal, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference for the inquiry which led to this report focused on the issues associated with incineration as a means of disposal of waste and energy recovery.I wish to emphasise, however, that the committee considered this in the context of the waste minimisation hierarchy and as such considered that incineration and landfill should be used as a last resort.

PARA.TAB: The primary focus of policy and operational sectors of government should be waste minimisation, reuse and recycling. The committee agrees with the view put to it by some in submissions that there is no such thing as waste. Waste is nothing more than a resource that needs some innovative idea on how it can actually be used. Waste is a resource which, if used in the right quantity and in the right way, is recyclable or reusable.

The committee believes that, if incinerators are to be constructed for the processing of domestic or municipal waste, there should be a requirement to have recycling and waste to energy facilities, and it has so recommended in its report. The committee does not support the construction of high temperature incinerators to deal with Australia's scheduled wastes, as it was given evidence during its inquiry that there are alternative technologies available.The committee has recommended that technologies designed to reuse or recycle be given priority and environmentally friendlier alternative technologies for the destruction of scheduled waste be considered in preference to high temperature incineration.

Australia's adherence to the Basel Convention, which prevents the export of hazardous wastes and the virtual ban on high temperature incinerator construction, has facilitated the development of a number of alternative technologies in Australia for the disposal of hazardous material. There has been a great deal of progress on various technologies since the work of the Independent Panel on Intractable Waste, and a number of innovative technologies could be operating commercially in the next couple of years.

The committee looked at a number of these technologies, which are described in the report. We do not, however, wish to comment on the relative effectiveness of these technologies or on their appropriateness for dealing with particular waste materials. These decisions will be made by the appropriate agencies and enterprises in terms of their commercial and public acceptability and technical requirements.

The committee was concerned at the lack of national standards for both the operations of incinerators and landfill sites. It therefore recommended the establishment of panels to act as independent facilitators in the settlement of disputes where communities and governments are unable to resolve the issues relating to the siting or the operation of disposal facilities and other waste management issues.

During the inquiry, some unsatisfactory aspects of current practice in the disposal of hospital waste were brought to the attention of the committee. As a result of a competitive tendering process, hospital waste from Sydney was being sent to Brisbane for incineration at what was alleged to be a substandard facility. It was also alleged that some of that waste would be sent on to Melbourne when the Brisbane facility was not working.

On at least one occasion when the Brisbane incinerator was not working it was alleged that medical waste was stockpiled in skips, covered only by polytarps, and stored in the open at the rear of the premises at a time when summer temperatures were around 40 degrees centigrade. The committee has therefore recommended that the government investigate the need for legislation relating to the transport of hospital wastes across borders and implement an appropriate strategy to reduce the risks associated with the transport and treatment of hospital wastes.

Economic considerations of any proposed waste disposal facility should include direct and indirect environmental and social costs. Currently, these costs are rarely included. They should include costs such as subsidies for road construction and maintenance, traffic regulation, site supervision and monitoring, and the long-term maintenance of landfills. It is only when the full implications of waste are factored into the production process that industry will have a real incentive to minimise wastes created by its products and packaging.

The trend to employing private waste disposal companies has left the system open to a number of problems. Private companies tend not to have any incentive to reduce the amount of waste to be disposed of or to reduce the distance the waste is transported. The committee considered that these problems could be addressed by an effective regulatory and monitoring system operated by the relevant government authorities. The committee also believed that there should be independent panels which could provide advice to resident groups who felt they were disadvantaged by waste management arrangements.

The committee did not accept the argument that it is cheaper to use raw materials than to recycle products. There is a finite source of non-renewable raw materials and these should be conserved. The committee has therefore recommended that where technology is available, governments work with industry to encourage the use of recycled materials instead of raw materials.

The committee believes that there still exists a great deal of confusion in the industry and in the broader community about the principles of the national waste minimisation and recycling strategy. Accordingly, the report recommends that, as a matter of urgency, the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency be required to establish formal and informal consultative processes with local, state and territory governments, industry and the broader community on all the major principles of waste management, particularly those relating to the national waste minimisation and recycling strategy.

The committee believes that there is an urgent need for a review of the current situation and approach to the strategy. It is more than two years since the strategy was adopted and there is still inadequate quantitative and qualitative information available to enable effective waste management decisions to be made. There is still a great deal of confusion and a lack of knowledge and understanding of key principles at the community level, within industry and at the local government level.

Accordingly, the committee has recommended that the government give priority to the measurement, review and monitoring of performance against the waste reduction targets contained in the national waste minimisation and recycling strategy and that the minister provide details of the actions taken when responding to this report in parliament.

During its inquiry, the committee encountered on a number of occasions situations where leading industry associations and competing technologies were unaware of the progress of relevant competing technologies which had been public for some time. The committee has accordingly recommended that emphasis be given to the prompt dissemination to local, state and territory governments, industry and the broader community of the information collected in the review of available technology for the treatment of scheduled wastes.

The committee has also recommended that the government: recognise the central role of local government in waste management; include representatives of Australian local government associations in national waste management planning; assist local government to disseminate information about the costs and benefits of waste management options; and encourage local governments to exchange information about developments in waste management.

The committee is concerned at the lack of progress in a number of areas since the introduction of the national waste minimisation and recycling strategy. The committee will therefore monitor the progress at regular intervals.

There are a number of issues which were not dealt with in detail in this report because insufficient information was obtained in the time available. The committee will keep the terms of reference open, with a view to taking up at a later date issues such as jarosite, the illegal dumping of DDT on a property near Orange and the government processes relating to its treatment, and the dumping of dangerous waste at landfills in Victoria.

Another matter of concern to the committee was the reluctance of some Commonwealth departments to assist with this inquiry. The exception to this was the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, CEPA, which provided a comprehensive written statement, informative comments at the public hearing and supplementary material subsequent to the hearing.

The committee appreciates the efforts of the officers from CEPA. The other relevant Commonwealth departments did not provide information on very basic issues and did not answer adequately the fundamental questions asked at public hearings. The committee reserves the right to follow up this matter at a later date.

Given the time, in a moment I will move to have the remainder of the tabling statement, which covers a number of other issues, incorporated in Hansard. Prior to doing that, I would like to place on record my thanks to my committee colleagues and to Senator Gibson, who was the previous deputy chair and the person who moved that this reference be referred to the committee. I thank them all for their efforts. I particularly want to thank the staff for the work that they did. Given the changes going on in the committees, there was a lot of pressure put on staff to have this report finished on time. As I said earlier, we had a lot of additional submissions and correspondence, and people were pushed hard to have this report finished. So I thank the staff for their work. I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the statement read as follows—

The inquiry which led to this report was undertaken to gather information on the current status of scheduled waste management and the development of new technologies to deal with these wastes in Australia.
The Committee was also required to look at the opportunities for the use of incineration for general waste disposal.

It became apparent that these issues could not be separated from management of waste generally, and therefore the inquiry encompassed a wider waste management approach, including waste minimisation policies.

It is important to determine an appropriate definition of waste. Without a basic definition of the various waste streams it is impossible to make meaningful comparisons of quantitative and qualitative data, and this can undermine the effectiveness of implementing waste management policies.
There are a number of definitions currently in use in Australia.

The New South Wales Waste Disposal Act 1980 defines waste as `effluent, garbage or trade waste' while the South Australian Waste Management Act 1987 defines waste as `any matter, irrespective of value, that is discarded or left over in the course of industrial, commercial, domestic or other activities'.
In evidence to the Committee, Professor D.E. Mainwaring said that, `things are waste in the absence of an economic method of recovery and recycling'.

A related definition was provided by Dr John Cole of the Environment Management Industry Association of Australia, who defined waste as `something that has no economic utility and has to be disposed, or stored, or whatever, but has no utility to society'.
The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce cited a definition by categories, in terms of:

SPEECH.PARA: a)domestic soft waste, which is household refuse collected by councils;
b)domestic hard waste, which is larger household refuse, such as garden waste, old furniture, etc;
c)commercial and industrial waste, which is packaging, offcuts, etc, resulting from commercial and industrial activities;
d)demolition waste, which is demolition rubble and offcuts from building activity; and
e)council waste, which is street sweepings, tree prunings, garden waste, etc.
Scheduled or intractable wastes come into a different category.

PARA.TAB: Intractable waste is waste for which there is no environmentally sound method of disposal, or which does not degrade naturally. This waste may be toxic (which means poisonous) or hazardous (which means poisonous and having a good likelihood of affecting human beings).
Greenpeace Australia did not differentiate between toxic and hazardous and considered that if it was toxic, then it was hazardous.
The Committee was required in its inquiry to take particular account of the findings and recommendations of the Independent Panel on Intractable Waste.
The Independent Panel found that the definition and differentiation of the many component parts of the waste stream were unsatisfactory and not generally understood by the community.
Waste in the right quantity and used in the right way becomes a recyclable or reusable material. The question is, how might it be turned into a resource?

The Environment Management Industry Association of Australia considered that the definition of waste was dynamic, because by innovative approaches much that was considered waste could be reused, recycled or reprocessed.
The view was given that the role of industry in dealing with waste was to reduce the hazard, reduce the volume and then to emplace it in a safe location until such time as a suitable reuse was found.
Using this principle, there is no such thing as waste; there is just intermediate processing.

One example presented to the Committee was the CSIRO and Pacific Power process which can regenerate used transformer oils and remove the polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs). Unlike a number of other processes which can destroy PCBs, which the Committee was told of during its inquiry, this technology can recycle PCB-contaminated oil.
The Committee supported the view that waste is a resource which in the right quantity and used in the right way is recyclable or reusable.
The Committee appreciates that there are practical difficulties in storing this material until innovation provides a use, but believes that this is not insurmountable.

It was estimated that 14 million tonnes of waste was being generated annually in Australia, of which only 10 per cent was being recycled in one form or another, while 90 per cent was going to landfill.

The Australian population generated 776 kilograms of solid waste per capita in 1993. In addition, more than 200 000 tonnes of liquid and solid industrial wastes were taken to special landfills and treatment facilities, and being discharged to sewers.

The amount of waste being generated is increasing at an alarming rate. In Sydney alone, 4000 tonnes of waste is produced each day. The amount of waste generated in Sydney increased two-fold between 1977 and 1987 to three million tonnes, and in 1992 was estimated to be almost five million tonnes.
Most of this waste is disposed of at landfill, although in Sydney some of this material is incinerated at the Waverley Woollahra Process Plant.

Some substantial gains have already been made in waste reduction. For example, over the last five years the City of Heidelberg has reduced its total waste from all sources from 40 000 tonnes to 34 000 tonnes.

Experience in Europe has shown that 10 per cent reduction can be obtained through waste minimisation programs: roughly 25 per cent being recycled, and 25 per cent composted, leaving only 40 per cent going to landfill.
It was suggested that the amount going to landfill could be reduced to 3 per cent if a waste to energy process was included.

The Waste Contractors and Recyclers Association of New South Wales considered that, due to population growth, by the year 2000, even with a 50 per cent reduction in waste, there would still be about two million tonnes per year of disposable waste in New South Wales, which was the same as the figure for 1990.
Even more telling was a recent study by the Waverley Council, which found that the amount of waste taken out of the system had been compensated by an increase in production of waste.
The amount of intractable waste in Australia is not large by world standards, because this country is an importer rather than a producer of materials from which intractable wastes derive.
The Independent Panel on Intractable Waste found that the estimates of intractable waste in Australia were unreliable, and were underestimates.
The Panel recommended the collection of accurate and up to date figures on the dispersion and quantity of Australia's stockpiles of intractable waste on a national basis as a matter urgency.

Some work has already begun in this area. The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation has surveyed some areas, and the Electrical Supply Association of Australia Inc is preparing an inventory on PCBs. These surveys will add to the existing level of knowledge.
However, the Committee believes there is an urgent need for a nationally coordinated, comprehensive survey of the range of scheduled wastes that are dispersed throughout Australia.

Waste treatment is a profitable business. The waste management market in Australia in 1990 had an estimated annual value of $1.3-1.5 billion per year, and the potential export market is estimated at $6 billion per annum by the year 2000.
However, North America and Western Europe currently supply approximately 70 per cent of the market.
The prime focus of policy and operational sectors of government should be waste minimisation, reuse and recycling.

The development of waste management strategies is hindered by uncertainty and indecision. There is insufficient quantitative and qualitative information on the existing waste streams in many cases, making long term policy development and coordination very difficult.
The Committee is of the view that waste minimisation, recycling

SPEECH.PARA: and reuse strategies must be given absolute priority.

PARA.TAB: Strong incentives and disincentives are urgently required to reduce the quantities of waste being generated.

A number of mechanisms have been suggested, such as volume or waste based charges; differential waste charges; container deposit legislation; virgin material tax or tax exemption for recycled products.

A number of regulative measures have also been suggested, such as requirements to source separate compostable materials; recycling contents standards; uniform packaging standards; and bans on certain types of products or packaging.
Basic quantitative data are necessary to determine the success of various strategies, incentives and disincentives.
The Commonwealth, State and Territory governments have agreed to a 50 per cent reduction in waste by the year 2000.
This target has created considerable confusion as to how it will be measured and the acceptability of the conditions which apply.
The major barriers to the expansion of recycling operations are market uncertainties, problems with adequacy and reliability of supply, and quality of supply and price for materials.
The environmental efficiency and potential markets for recycled materials is another area which requires urgent research.

Much of the debate on the potential of waste minimisation hinges on the economics of recycling. In particular, the processing of the organic waste stream will significantly contribute to the achievement of the 50 per cent target by the year 2000, but this is dependent on developing markets for this material.

The waste management debate could be significantly improved by conducting environmental audits on how much energy is spent on collecting, recycling and reusing certain materials, on what the cost of that is and how much energy is used in collecting, incinerating it and using it for energy generation.
Discussion on other issues is also needed, such as when it is environmentally optimal to stop repairing items such as old cars and updating to a new, more environmentally friendly models.
What is viable in the rural areas compared to what is viable in large urban areas needs to be assessed, and economically viable strategies must be developed for rural areas.

While the Committee acknowledges the views of organisations such as the Friends of the Earth, which strongly oppose all forms of waste disposal and treatment, the reality of the existing situation does not permit this approach to be implemented immediately.
The Committee was required to consider the available options for the final disposal of waste, and the progress in achieving improved waste management.
In considering waste disposal options the cost effectiveness, technical reliability and environmental acceptability must all be taken into account.

A full cost benefit analysis needs to be done, taking into account all the known (or suspected) environmental factors, and an appreciation of the extent of the scientific understanding of the environmental consequences of each option.
The Committee is satisfied that the existing technology is capable of dealing with any potential environmental threats from incinerator emissions or ash residue.
The Committee has recommended that if incinerators are to be constructed for the processing of domestic waste, there should be a requirement to have recycling and waste to energy facilities.
There a number of problems which can eventuate if landfills are not constructed or operated correctly.
Landfill and incineration have been compared by Mr Sam Bateman, Principal Engineer with Maunsell Pty Ltd, in the following terms:

the only two techniques that have been successful at disposing of solid waste on a large scale have been incineration and landfilling. Both processes degrade the waste, one in a few seconds and the other over decades. Both produce a mineralised residue and the vast majority of the mass flows out as gas. Both produce gases with a very large number of trace elements that can affect health and the environment. Both produce contaminated waste water. Both can produce useful energy from the process by-products. Landfilling takes up more space than incinerators but costs less. Incinerators cannot exist without landfill but landfill can exist without incinerators. The two technologies are not dissimilar except in space and time.

This is the disposal conundrum; space and time. If there is sufficient social pressure on space and time then incinerators are viable. Waste disposal is really a land use issue. Landfills can alienate a lot of land cheaply for a relatively short time and incinerators alienate much less land expensively for a relatively long time.
Mr Bateman concluded that the choice between modern landfill and incineration was an economic and land use decision, not an environmental one.
In considering waste disposal options it is necessary to address their public acceptability, siting considerations, planning permission conditions or the views of the special interest groups.
The debate about the siting of the disposal facility can detract from the development of a holistic waste management system.

The Committee was concerned at the lack of national standards for both the operations of incinerators and landfill sites, and has recommended that "independent panels be established to facilitate the settlement of ongoing disputes with regard to waste management issues".

The Independent Panel on Intractable Waste found that community opinion in Australia was so opposed to high temperature incineration as a means of disposal that it would be very difficult to site an HTI facility without massive resistance from the host community. The Panel recommended that alternative means of disposal be explored and developed.

This Committee also believes that it is unlikely that high temperature incinerators will be built in Australia, given the level of community resistance, nor does the Committee support the construction of a high temperature incinerator given that there are alternative technologies available.
Work is commencing on the development of management plans for the destruction of some scheduled wastes, and information is being collected on the quantities of waste needing treatment.

The Independent Panel opposed the long term storage of scheduled wastes as they considered it was expensive, potentially hazardous and did not provide a solution. The Panel also considered that the option to store waste in the long term provided little incentive to use developing technologies.
The Committee was told that there was a measurable risk from the storing of material, which was very much higher than the risk associated with its destruction.

It was also suggested that most of the toxic waste was stored quite safely, and that it was the other wastes, of which there were several hundreds of thousands of tons accumulated or stored in landfills or in other not very safe situations, that were of real concern.
There was little support for transportable disposal systems, although relocatable systems were considered feasible.
One of the difficulties with transportable treatment plants is that of getting approval at each new site, as an environmental impact assessment would need to be done for each location.

SRL Plasma Ltd pointed out that generic technology approval could only apply to the technology, and not its use in a particular site, because site requirements could render that particular technology inappropriate.

The problem of what to do with the scheduled wastes or mixtures of waste for which there are no known acceptable disposal technologies available is a difficult one, and Australia has addressed the problem to the extent that there are no longer any intractable wastes being generated, so that as long as imports are also controlled, the problem should not get worse.

The Committee has recommended that "enterprises be required to disclose the quantities of scheduled wastes they have stored and that these be stored in National Environment Protection Council approved premises, and that an agreement for their disposal, or a research proposal for their reuse or recycling, be made with the National Environment Protection Council".

The Committee has also recommended that "enterprises be required to have scheduled waste disposed of according to the terms of an agreement with the National Environment Protection Council by an environmentally acceptable process, at a rate which is commercially feasible".
During the Committee's inquiry there was considerable discussion about the difficulty of estimating the costs of landfills and other disposal options.
Municipal waste disposal charges are often included as a general levy, which also covers water and sewerage.

Economic instruments, such as lower charges for sorted waste compared with mixed waste, and charges relating to the volume or weight of garbage, may provide incentives to reduce the amount of garbage generated by households.

The Committee was told by the Local Government and Shires Associations of NSW that Sydney councils were subsidising industry by $3.9 million per annum for the collection of materials that industry consistently reminds the community are recyclable.
Local government was also subsidising the NSW State Government to the extent of $2 million per year.
A number of submissions expressed the concern that if a major incinerator was constructed, a guaranteed throughput would be required to maintain its economic viability.

The costs of waste disposal at the Waverley Woollahra Process Plant are currently twice the costs of landfill disposal based on weight. This did not seem to have been a disincentive when transport costs were considered.

The Committee believes community must be made aware of the true costs of waste collection and disposal. Economic incentives could result in a reduction of material going to landfill and incineration, provide further incentives to recycle, reduce the pressure on the environment, and provide funds for further research and development of alternative technologies.
The Committee was told that the most important aspect of waste disposal in Australia was the financial aspect, which was not being addressed correctly.
It is only when the full implications of waste are factored into the production process that industry will have a real incentive to minimise wastes created by its products and packaging.
There has been a great deal achieved in terms of a national waste management approach in areas such as the waste minimisation strategies.

There is, however, an urgent need for setting national standards on a range of matters to address issues such as the problems associated with the transborder movement of hazardous materials for disposal at sites with less stringent requirements or practices.
Another aspect that needs attention is the setting of standards which will enable industry and authorities to plan new facilities with confidence.

The issue that the Committee was required to investigate was the range of options for waste disposal. The Committee has covered these in its report, but emphasises that these matters should be taken in the context of being the last resort.
The Committee supports the principles of waste minimisation and re-use as priorities, and recycling into other materials in preference to final disposal.

The Committee was concerned about the lack of knowledge and understanding by governments, industry and community groups in relation to the availability of alternative technologies or practices, and in some cases the basic aspects of some national policies.
There is a significant need for governments to provide information to correct the misinformation current in all sectors of the community.

There is a need to ensure that manufacturers accept their share of the responsibility for the waste produced. The Local Government and Shires Associations of New South Wales expressed the view that: "For too long Local Government and the community have accepted responsibility for the disposal of wastes created by industry. It is time industry took greater responsibility and Federal and State Governments introduced legislative controls and fiscal policies to the betterment of waste management and minimisation".
Waste management strategies must balance the competing demands between environmental safeguards and an affordable standard of living.
It is possible that the same amount of waste reduction could be achieved by waste minimisation as could be achieved by incineration, but for less cost and within the same time frame.
The Committee considers that there is merit in allowing the development of alternative processes to incineration, which can take advantage of the value of the raw material.
All options for the disposal of wastes, whether to landfill, water, air or by incineration have risks associated with them.
It is important that waste management strategies should not only look at the volume of the reductions but also at reduced public risk.

The National Waste Minimisation and Recycling Strategy was prepared by the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency (CEPA) in conjunction with the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) and was released in June 1990. The Strategy set a national target of 50 per cent for waste reduction by the year 2000.
As part of its role in implementing and evaluating the Strategy, CEPA is required to:

SPEECH.PARA: .in cooperation with the States and Territories establish a project team to oversee compliance with policy and regulation, and the operation and performance of the Strategy;
.work with the States and Territories through ANZECC and, when it is established, the National Environment Protection Council, to further develop, implement and review the Strategy; and
.establish formal consultation mechanisms with industry, unions, community and environment groups to assist in the continuing development, implementation and review of the Strategy.

PARA.TAB: The Committee also believes that the production of vast quantities of documentation has not achieved the desired goal in relation to the provision of information to the community, industry and local councils.

The Committee supports the efforts of the Australian Centre for Cleaner Production in holding free seminars in a number of capital cities, which provided information on enterprises that had been successful in reducing the amount of waste produced.
The Committee also heard a number of favourable comments in relation to the free seminar held by CEPA on incineration in November 1993.
The Committee encourages the use of these `meet the people approaches'.

The Committee was also concerned at the extent to which local councils and communities were implementing programs for waste reduction based on the best advice available, although no one knew whether these measures were effective or what other consequences might arise from these approaches.

The Committee has therefore recommended that, "as a matter of urgency, the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency monitor the effectiveness of all measures adopted so as to ensure that the desired outcome is achieved, and provide ongoing reports to this Committee."

Another issue that was of concern to the Committee was the lack of national standards. While some areas, such as emissions from incinerators, were currently being addressed by most States, there were number of other areas that appeared to have made little progress.

The Committee was given, on and off the record, examples of interstate transport of hazardous materials, in particular, hospital waste, to be dealt within States which had lower environmental standards, or which did not enforce the standards they had.

The Committee considers that a national cooperative approach is urgently needed with uniform standards across most aspects of waste management. The Committee has therefore recommended that "the National Environment Protection Council be requested to give the determination of national standards priority on its agenda".
The Committee believes that its recommendations, if implemented as a matter of urgency, will address many of the issues raised in its inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This inquiry of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts into waste disposal was one of the most enjoyable inquiries that I have participated in, in that it was most enlightening and I find the process of learning particularly enjoyable. It is a process which the committee members all undertook. I say that on behalf of other committee members who participated in the inquiry, knowing that we started the inquiry from one aspect of knowledge and that no committee members can say that they emerged from the inquiry without learning considerably more about this problem of what we do with waste material in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The process involved the discovery also that many authorities in Australia that have the responsibility for disposing of waste also seemed to benefit from our inquiry. At one stage the chairman and I were particularly concerned about the fact that we seemed to be providing a vehicle for the dissemination of information between authorities rather than just gathering the information ourselves. Consequently, that particular process forms one of the recommendations, recommendation 15, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that emphasis be given to the prompt dissemination to local, State and Territory governments, industry and the broader community of the information collected in the review of available technology for the treatment of scheduled wastes.

That is because we found examples of responsible authorities that were unaware of the developments in technology and in the management regimes. It is very important that they no longer remain ignorant of what is to happen.

PARA.TAB: Another thing that was particularly important was that, during the process of investigating what possible technologies could be used to manage waste materials, the committee found that, if a commitment had been given to a total solution some years earlier—the best example was the high temperature incinerator—or to such a management regime, then of course Australia would not have benefited from the development of alternative treatment technologies, technologies which now have the potential to increase export opportunities for Australia.

I speak particularly in regard to the technology that is available now to treat the PCBs, the sort of material which was previously considered the prime candidate for disposal by high temperature incinerator. Australia has developed effective technology to deal with that material and is in a position to export that technology worldwide. That opportunity was created by the very step of not endorsing and establishing high temperature incineration. I believe that we have turned a threat into an opportunity, a quite beneficial opportunity, for Australia. That learning process was a part of the inquiry that I enjoyed.

The part that I did not enjoy—and, to be frank, I think other members of the committee felt the same—was the confusion and lack of cohesion and coordination in this area. We found that some authorities responsible for waste management were able to use best available technology and apply imagination and foresight in their planning for how to deal with what we normally consider waste; we found that other authorities seemed to be more concerned with perpetuating a set of practices which could be described only as destructive and costly, both in financial and sociological terms, to the communities to which they were responsible. That confusion and lack of coordination and cohesion should be addressed as a matter of urgency. I think the Commonwealth government has a role to play in leading the way in coordinating some of the efforts of those who are responsible for managing our waste.

We see targets for greenhouse gas emission reduction programs and waste volume reduction, but we see very little evidence of leadership by way of either example or financial assistance being applied, and there is plenty of room for this. That is an area which could be very productive in terms of achieving goals with comparatively little input either financially or in terms of time.

The other important thing that emerged as a result of the committee's work was an eagerness on behalf of local government to be involved in taking the opportunities that were identified, whether they be in recycling, in reuse or in reduction of waste. Local governments around Australia are seeing the opportunities to work very well on behalf of their communities, to take hold of the benefits that are available here. There is a need to communicate to local governments around Australia which may have the same problem what other local governments are doing. Again, there is the capacity for the Commonwealth to give leadership in making sure that that information is shared and that the opportunities are understood.

There was also an appreciation of the need to define waste disposal. We spent a fair amount of time in the committee trying to do this. At one stage we were even told that there is no such thing as waste, that waste is merely resources which have yet to be identified.

The person who introduced that concept to us was able to demonstrate his lateral thinking in determining and demonstrating a use for furnace dust, which was a problem in Wollongong, and sewage, which could both be identified as waste by one definition, but which he managed to demonstrate were resources when they were combined in the right way, using the technology that he had developed, and were capable of producing a product which had some intrinsic value.

The committee enjoyed its exposure to such lateral thinking and such a productive exercise regarding Australia's resources. There we had an example of waste which was not waste. With regard to the attitude which can be applied to so many of the things we dispose of, particularly that which we dispose of in landfill, if we have the attitude that it is not really waste but merely a resource for which we should be looking for alternative uses, I think we will improve Australia's productivity, economy and employment situation.

The other important concept is that it is not merely sufficient to segregate and collect materials and say that that is recycling. To complete a recycling process it is necessary to repurchase the product of the recycled materials. We saw that local governments can play a significant role in that process, as can the Commonwealth government, particularly in terms of bounties for recycled paper or the use by purchasing departments of materials that have been made from recycled material. I welcome this report, endorse its recommendations and recommend the reading of it to all honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee) adjourned.
