DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present report No. 1 of 1994 of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the examination of annual reports.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual reports included in this report relate to the year 1992-93 or the calendar year 1993 and were tabled in the Senate during the period 1 July 1993 to 30 June 1994. The committee was due to have reported to the Senate by 30 June 1994 on its examination of annual reports but was granted an extension of time until 13 October 1994. The delay in reporting was caused by the committee's concerted effort to meet its deadline of 29 August to report on its inquiry into sexual harassment in the armed forces.

PARA.TAB: The committee's effort to finalise the sexual harassment report also resulted in a postponement since late 1993 of work on the committee's other inquiry into relations with China. The committee will now concentrate on completing this wide ranging inquiry. Earlier today the Senate granted the committee an extension of time until the last sitting day in June 1995 to report on this matter.

All the annual reports examined by the committee were in accordance with the guidelines for preparing annual reports. In its previous report on annual reports, the committee had commented on the preponderance of female staff in the ASO 1 to 3 ranges and the progressive increases in the proportion of male staff in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The department recently wrote to the committee outlining the steps which it had taken to develop a strategy to integrate equal employment opportunity principles into the department's management practices.

The committee was pleased to note that the secretary had taken the lead in developing this strategy. The committee believed that such action by the secretary should signal to all staff his determination to increase EEO principles in departmental management practices in accordance with the government's equal employment opportunity policy. Although the Department of Defence stated in its annual report for 1992-93 that there had been a small but significant increase in the number of women in the senior executive service levels, this statement was wrong. Other tables in the report showed that the number of women in the SES remained at five during the year. The department confirmed that no increase in numbers had occurred.

The department also confirmed that two columns in table seven on page 274 of the report were also wrong because some categories of professional and technical staff had been included in the wrong salary ranges. There is little evidence to show that the department is making a serious attempt to integrate EEO principles in the department's management practices in order to improve the representation of female staff and their career prospects throughout the department. The employment of women in senior officer and senior executive range is still well below public service norms. The committee believes that the department management should make a more determined effort to improve its EEO record. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 331 of the committee, entitled An advisory report on the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994, the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994 and the Auditor-General Bill 1994, and on a proposal to establish an audit committee of parliament. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome this opportunity to table the 331st report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which is an advisory report on legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901 and a response to a resolution by this chamber. On 28 June this year, Senator Robert Ray gave notice of a motion in the Senate to establish a joint standing committee to be known as the Audit Committee of Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The notice of motion detailed the functions of the audit committee, in summary, as being: firstly, to advise the Auditor-General of the committee's audit priorities; secondly, to advise the responsible minister when the committee wishes a performance audit to be conducted on a government business enterprise; thirdly, to consider the resources of the Australian National Audit Office; and, finally, to report to the parliament on any issue arising out of the performance of the Auditor-General's functions or reports of the independent auditor that the committee believes should be drawn to the attention of parliament.

The notice of motion also proposed that the committee's membership be the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate, alternating as chairman and deputy chairman; the chairman of the JCPA; two government and three opposition members of the House of Representatives; and one government senator, one opposition senator and one senator to be nominated by any minority groups or independent senators.

On 29 June, the Senate passed a motion I moved, that the proposed resolution for the establishment of an audit committee should be referred to the JCPA for inquiry. The referral also requested the JCPA to give particular attention to the appropriateness of establishing a separate committee rather than conferring the functions of the proposed committee on the JCPA. On 23 August, the Senate agreed to extend the reporting deadline until today.

Honourable senators will be aware that on 29 June 1994, the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) introduced a package of three bills in the lower house. The bills were the Auditor-General Bill 1994, the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994 and the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994. For the sake of brevity, I shall refer to the bills respectively as the FMA Bill, the CAC Bill and the Auditor-General's Bill.

After their first reading in the House, the minister successfully moved that the bills be referred to the JCPA for review with an advisory report to be presented to the House. The JCPA decided to combine its report on the proposal to establish an audit committee and its review of the three bills into the one report. Let me say at the outset that the JCPA has welcomed the opportunity to consider the Senate's referral and to review the bills.

The committee's review has allowed many Commonwealth entities and organisations outside the Commonwealth an opportunity to comment on the proposed audit committee and the three bills. The committee received 65 submissions and held six public hearings, with witnesses coming from as far afield as South Australia and Tasmania to give evidence. The committee also invited the coalition, the Australian Democrats and all Independent senators and members to consider their comments. The review process has been important and valuable. The committee believes that the constructive and bipartisan approach of all involved in the inquiry has led to recommendations that will enhance the effectiveness of an audit committee and the quality of the legislation.

Before I detail some of the major recommendations made by the committee, I should like to draw the Senate's attention to the long involvement of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in moves to have an audit committee of parliament established. The formal motion to establish an audit committee of parliament draws heavily on a proposal to establish such a committee made by the same committee in 1989.

In that year the Joint Committee of Public Accounts reviewed the audit office and, in its report No. 296 entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and the Parliament—Reform of the Australian Audit Office, recommended the establishment of a separate parliamentary audit committee. This recommendation was based on the precedent of the UK House of Commons, which had established a statutory audit committee called the Public Accounts Commission in 1983.

The government's interest in establishing an audit committee is particularly welcomed by the committee. However, the notice of motion proposes creation of a separate audit committee, a move proposed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in 1989. The committee now considers that, for reasons of efficiency and effectiveness, the functions of an audit committee should be more appropriately conducted by the JCPA itself.

The committee has come to this conclusion for several reasons. Firstly, the public accounts committee has a long history of liaising with the Auditor-General. This has given the public accounts committee members a strong understanding of the issues affecting the Auditor-General and his office. Secondly, the public accounts committee has a statutory obligation to examine the reports of the Auditor-General. Public accounts committee members have developed a detailed insight into the Auditor-General's levels of activity and the efficiency with which they are carried out. With this information, the public accounts committee members are well placed to comment on the Auditor-General's proposed levels of future activity.

Thirdly, the public accounts committee already acts informally as a conduit for parliamentarians to indicate aspects of public administration that they would like the Auditor-General to examine. If the audit committee functions were added to its responsibilities, the public accounts committee would undertake this task on a formal basis.

The committee does not believe it appropriate for Australia to follow the United Kingdom precedent, where the House of Commons audit committee and the public accounts committee are separate. The reason for this separation in the UK is that by tradition the chairman of its public accounts committee is, by convention, a member of the opposition. It was not considered appropriate for the opposition to preside over a committee reviewing the appropriations of an agency of state, and thus the function was given to a separate government controlled committee.

A similar separation is not necessary in Australia, given that the chair of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is always a government member. However, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts believes that it is highly desirable that an audit committee of parliament have statutory recognition to give the necessary permanence to such an important committee.

The committee believes that statutory recognition can be most appropriately achieved by amending the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951. This act details the membership, duties and functions of the public accounts committee and should be amended to give the public accounts committee the additional powers to perform the functions of a parliamentary audit committee.

The JCPA believes it is important that its functions as an audit committee should be clearly distinct from its traditional functions. To clarify the distinction, the public accounts committee believes that the Public Accounts Committee Act should require the committee to convene as the audit committee of parliament when performing audit committee functions.

It is also important that minority parties and Independents should be represented on the audit committee. This is most appropriately achieved by increasing the membership of the public accounts committee by one and reserving the extra position for a representative of any minority groups or Independents in the parliament.

The committee believes that these recommendations will give the parliament a strong and efficient audit committee that will strengthen the links between the Auditor-General and the parliament. As I mentioned, the public accounts committee decided to combine its report on the audit committee proposal and its review of the three bills to replace the Audit Act into the one report.

I shall now focus on the committee's major recommendations concerning the replacement legislation. The Auditor-General Bill defines the powers, functions and role of the Commonwealth Auditor-General. The public accounts committee welcomes the introduction of the Auditor-General Bill and supports the principles behind the legislation. In particular, the committee welcomes the fact that the Auditor-General has been given an unambiguous mandate to audit the financial statements of all Commonwealth entities and almost as extensive a mandate to conduct performance audits. The decision to establish the audit office as a statutory agency is also a positive step. However, the committee believes that the bill, as proposed, represents a limitation on the parliament's capacity to make informed assessments about the efficiency with which taxpayers' money is being used by government business enterprises. Clauses 14 and 15 of the bill only allow the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits of business enterprises at the request of both houses of parliament by resolution or at the request of the responsible minister.

Although the bill does allow parliament to request a performance audit of a business enterprise, the committee believes that to require a resolution of both houses is cumbersome, time consuming and potentially impractical. It is important that there be an easier mechanism by which the parliament can directly request the Auditor-General to conduct a performance audit of a business enterprise.

Accordingly, the committee recommends that parliament delegate its authority to request a performance audit of a GBE to the proposed audit committee, without the need to go through the responsible minister or both houses. Of course, parliament as a whole and the responsible minister would continue to be able to request the Auditor-General to conduct a performance audit of a GBE. The committee expects that the audit committee would rarely exercise this power and only after consultation with all parties involved.

I shall briefly mention the other two bills: the Financial Management and Accountability Bill and the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill. The FMA Bill establishes an appropriate structure for financial management and accountability within Commonwealth agencies and, in fact, the committee has made only two minor recommendations for change. Finally, I turn to the CAC Bill. At present, the accountability requirements for Commonwealth authorities and companies are scattered through numerous enabling acts, company memoranda and articles of association. The CAC Bill draws these together in a single set of core reporting and accountability requirements. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity also to comment on the Joint Committee of Public Account's advisory report on the notice of motion to establish an audit committee of the parliament and on the legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901. Senator Gibson, in presenting the report, has already outlined the additional functions that the committee envisages for an audit committee and why the Joint Committee on Public Accounts has recommended that the functions of an audit committee should be conducted by the Joint Committee on Public Accounts itself.

PARA.TAB: I would like to stress three of the principles about the Audit Committee of Parliament that have arisen from the joint committee's recommendations. Firstly, the joint committee believes that it is highly desirable that an audit committee of the parliament have statutory recognition to give the necessary permanence to such an important committee. As has been discussed, the joint committee recommends that this be achieved by way of amendments to the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951.

Secondly, the joint committee believes that its function as an audit committee should be very clearly distinct from its traditional functions. For this reason, the joint committee has recommended that, when it is performing the functions of the audit committee, it is specifically convened in that forum. Thirdly, the committee believes that minority parties and independents should be represented on the audit committee. Senator Gibson, in presenting the report, has indicated that the committee recommends the membership of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts be increased by one and that that extra position be reserved for representatives of the minority groups or Independents within the parliament.

I endorse what Senator Gibson has said. These recommendations, together with the various other recommendations in the report, will, the committee believes, ensure a strong and efficient audit committee.

As I mentioned earlier, the joint committee report also reviews the package of three bills to replace the Audit Act 1901. Those bills are: the Auditor-General Bill 1994, the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994 and the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994.

I would like to highlight some of the recommendations that the committee made regarding the Auditor-General Bill. One of the recommendations made by the Auditor-General was that the Auditor-General Bill should be amended to provide the audit office with the authority to establish appropriate terms and conditions of employment of staff. Currently, audit office staff are employed under the Public Service Act 1922 and this arrangement will continue under the Auditor-General Bill as it currently stands.

In his submission, the Auditor-General argued that he needed to be able to set terms and conditions for his staff that are competitive with private sector equivalents because that would give him or her the flexibility to meet changing requirements. The government's 1987 policy guidelines for Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises state that statutory authorities should be staffed under the Public Service Act unless there are strong reasons for doing otherwise.

In the government's view, a case has not been made out to exempt the National Audit Office from this policy position. Furthermore, the Department of Finance has pointed out that there are many other Commonwealth agencies besides the National Audit Office that have difficulty providing professional staff with competitive remuneration packages. So it is not an issue that is unique to the audit office.

But the committee believes that the Auditor-General is in a unique position in the public sector given his or her vital role in strengthening the accountability of the executive to parliament and improving public sector efficiency. The committee believes that the Auditor-General's capacity to undertake these functions would be enhanced if he or she had greater flexibility to negotiate competitive remuneration packages. This would assist the Auditor-General in attracting and retaining the highest quality staff. Accordingly, the committee has recommended that the Auditor-General Bill be amended to allow the Auditor-General to negotiate the terms and conditions of the staff at the audit office with those officers and employees.

However, the committee is aware of the concerns expressed by the employees' representatives during the proceedings that the terms and conditions of staff could possibly be eroded if they were no longer employed under the Public Service Act. It is the committee's view that it should be possible to balance the Auditor-General's desire to have freedom to determine competitive packages for his staff with the requirement to protect their basic terms and conditions.

This can be achieved by placing safeguards in the legislation along the lines of those included in the enabling legislation of other budget funded Commonwealth authorities not employing staff under the Public Service Act. So the committee has recommended that the terms and conditions set by the Auditor-General must be consistent with government industrial relations and employment policies and the principles decided by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission from time to time.

We recognise that the process of establishing terms and conditions of the audit office staff is likely to be complex and lengthy, involving negotiations between all relevant parties. For this reason, we recommend that audit office staff should continue to be employed and appointed under the Public Service Act until such time as any new terms and conditions are agreed with staff.

Another recommendation made by the Auditor-General is that former Auditors-General should not be able to take up further employment in the public sector. The Auditor-General is concerned that there could be seen to be implications for the independence of the Auditor-General if an Auditor-General is reliant on the executive for future employment when his or her term of appointment is completed.

The committee acknowledges that the position of Auditor-General is unique and has a special place within the system of government. However, inclusion of such an amendment to the bill would prevent a former Auditor-General from making a further and valuable contribution to Commonwealth administration. Accordingly, the committee believes that there should not be a restriction on former Auditors-General seeking offices of profit under the Crown.

I would now like to turn briefly to another of the bills in the legislative package: the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, known as the CAC Bill. A matter of concern to a number of witnesses appearing before the committee was that the penalty regime established under the CAC Bill for breaches of duty by executive officers of Commonwealth authorities is unnecessarily harsh. An associated concern was that Commonwealth authorities will find it increasingly difficult to attract quality men and women to fill positions on boards of management.

The committee is aware of the trend in the private sector towards boards being filled by professionals skilled in financial management, as non-financial experts become reluctant to accept the more onerous obligations being placed on directors. The committee believes it desirable that the boards of Commonwealth authorities and companies should contain a mix of financial experts and community representatives with relevant, although not necessarily financial, expertise.

It believes also that the penalty regime for executive officers in the CAC Bill should not discourage appropriate people from sitting on the boards of Commonwealth authorities. On the other hand, it should also reflect the high standard of duty and care that parliament expects of people undertaking a public duty. In order to ensure that there is no confusion regarding the definition contained in the bill, the committee has recommended that the explanatory memorandum be amended to state that the individual circumstances of each particular case will be relevant in determining whether an officer of a Commonwealth authority should be classified as an executive officer or not with respect to the penalty regime. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee welcomes the introduction of the CAC Bill, principally because it will enable Parliament to view the accountability requirements of the vast range of Commonwealth authorities and companies as a whole. Furthermore, it will ensure that the accountability requirements are explicit and consistent for each class of Commonwealth entity.
However, a number of recommendations have been made to clarify the interpretation of clauses in the Bill and make them more consistent with standards set by the Corporations Law.

In conclusion, I believe that the review process that has culminated in this report has been valuable and conducted in a constructive spirit. The notice of motion to establish an audit committee of parliament and the legislation combined, represent a landmark package aimed at improving the framework of Commonwealth financial administration and strengthening the accountability of the public sector to Parliament.
I believe the Committee's recommendations will further enhance this package and lead to even more accountable and efficient public sector management.
I look forward to the Government's response to our report and to the upcoming debate on Senator Ray's motion and the three Bills.

I would like to thank the officers of the Department of Finance and the Australian National Audit Office who have assisted the Committee during the course of the review. The Committee also wishes to express its appreciation to all the others who prepared submissions and appeared as witnesses before the Committee at such short notice.

The Committee believes that these recommendations to amend the CAC Bill should relieve many of the concerns held by the directors and executive officers of Commonwealth authorities about their duties and liabilities.

In conclusion, I believe that the Committee's recommendations, in toto, will enhance the quality of the three Bills and strengthen the links between the Auditor-General and Parliament. It will be interesting to follow the course of the debate in this House on Senator Ray's motion and the legislation. The end result should be more efficient and accountable public administration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to incorporate the rest of my speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, the Committee has supported the CAC Bill's penalty regime for executive officers who breach their duties, but recommended that the Bill be amended to allow relief from prosecution in cases where there are extenuating circumstances.

As part of the penalty regime of the CAC Bill, `executive officers' of Commonwealth authorities are liable to pay compensation or damages, as well as face fines and prison terms, for failure to comply with a range of obligations.
The Bill defines executive officers in Commonwealth authorities as the directors of an authority and `any other person who is concerned, in, or takes part in, the management of the authority'.

A number of Commonwealth authorities questioned whether this definition is so broad as to include relatively junior management. The implication being that junior staff could also be liable to pay fines and compensation or face prison.
The Committee acknowledges the potential confusion that may arise from the vagueness of the definition, but notes the following advice from the Attorney-General's department, and I quote:

The definition has deliberately been cast in a general fashion to ensure that the question of whether a person is an executive officer will depend on the facts of the particular case and the actual activities that the person undertakes on behalf of the company rather than the actual title or position of the relevant person in the company.

However, the Committee has recommended that some confusion can be avoided by amending the Explanatory Memorandum to state that the individual circumstances of each particular case will be relevant in determining whether an officer of a Commonwealth authority should be classified as an executive officer or not.

The Committee believes that these recommendations to amend the CAC Bill should relieve many of the concerns held by the directors and executive officers of Commonwealth authorities about their duties and liabilities.

In conclusion, I believe that the Committee's recommendations, in toto, will enhance the quality of the three Bills and strengthen the links between the Auditor-General and Parliament. It will be interesting to follow the course of the debate in this House on Senator Ray's motion and the legislation. The end result should be more efficient and accountable public administration

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994.

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING (STUDENT ORGANISATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 in accordance with Commonwealth government responsibilities in respect of providing benefits to students within Australian higher education institutions.

The bill provides for the continued support of existing student services within Australian higher education institutions through an amendment to the act which will allow the Commonwealth to make payments to student organisations directly and recover funds from the States' General Revenue Assistance if necessary. The bill will also allow the Commonwealth to make payments to student organisations directly for certain permitted purposes. The recovery of funds will be possible under the provision contained in section 15 of the States Grants (General Purpose) Bill 1994. This mechanism ensures that there will be no additional budgetary implications.
The provisions contained in the bill will override the provisions of any state law or any other action the state may take to the contrary.

The amendment is a direct result of the Tertiary Education (Amendment) Act 1994 (the act) passed by the Victorian government and the actions of the Tasmanian state government towards the University of Tasmania.

The Victorian act purports to abolish compulsory student unionism while protecting the provision of specified services to students. While the provisions of this act were being debated in the Legislative Assembly amendments were made, after considerable pressure from the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee and the National Union of Students to increase the range of services funded from non-academic fees. While the Victorian minister may add to the list of approved services by regulation there is a danger that the list specified by regulation will limit the services and amenities available to students.

For example, a number of activities and services such as student newspapers, student advocacy and generally activities of a representational nature will not be provided for. The Victorian act also places restrictions on the use of profits from activities funded from the compulsory non-academic fees.

Whilst the Victorian government has legislated against student organisations, the Tasmanian government has used the Victorian act as a precedent to exert pressure on the University of Tasmania to conform to state government demands. The University of Tasmania has agreed to amend the university ordinances relating to the payment and use of fees for student association membership at the university. All students will continue to pay a compulsory student association fee but any student who objects to their funds being directed to the Student Representative Council (SRC) will have their fee dedicated to the provision of student services.

Traditionally the role of the SRC has been important in meeting a range of non-academic needs of students on campus. The Commonwealth government will challenge the state Governments to protect the rights of students.

Action taken by the Tasmanian and Victorian governments have the potential to affect the culture and quality of services and amenities at universities. Their intervention is a direct attack on the autonomy of higher education institutions. Institutions and student organisations should jointly be able to make decisions about the imposition, collection and use of fees for the provision of services and amenities, independent of government interference.

By restricting students' expression of views on public issues the Victorian government has cynically flouted the international instruments and principles which it had originally claimed to be the basis of its legislative action. Making the expenditure of fees levied by the institution dependent upon state governments' views of what is `appropriate' effectively amounts to the choking of open debate of government policies as they affect the institution and the student body.

The value and need for compulsory student unionism has been endorsed by the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee and student organisations around Australia. This principle is in accordance with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), Article 22 concerning Freedom of Association. Furthermore, most if not all institutions allow for conscientious objection to the membership of student organisations.

The Victorian act prohibits the acceptance by universities of financial assistance from the Commonwealth for a student organisation as a result of the state preventing or hindering the imposition or collection of fees, a provision currently contained within section 25a of the act.

This amendment to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 will allow the Commonwealth to make payments directly to student organisations for the purpose of enabling those organisations to continue to provide `benefits' to students and maintain funding support at a viable level.

The Commonwealth, through this amendment, will ensure that institutions maintain an environment that fosters the necessary culture and atmosphere for students to exchange ideas, hold and express opinions in a free and unimpeded manner.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts for inquiry and report:
The intention of the Federal Government, in October 1994, following the final negotiating session in Paris, to sign the International Convention on Desertification, with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the extent of desertification in Australia's rangelands, its causes and environmental, social and economic impacts;
(b)actions required to halt and reverse desertification in Australia;
(c)the means of monitoring the progress of programs directed at reversing desertification in Australia;
(d)the capacity of the desertification convention to contribute to Australia's efforts to halt and reverse desertification, both in Australia and overseas; and
(e)the impact of the desertification convention on the economic, social and environmental sustainability of rural, pastoral and mining communities.

SPEECH.PARA: Notice of motion altered on 20 September 1994 pursuant to Standing Order 77.

This motion seeks to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts the matter of the international convention on desertification. Honourable senators will recall that, at the time this motion was put forward, Senator Chapman also put forward a motion to refer the same matter, but with different terms of reference, to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. That motion was defeated, and this motion is the alternative proposal. This motion seeks to refer this convention and its impact in relation to a number of matters in Australia, which I will pick up in a moment, to the environment, recreation and the arts committee.

PARA.TAB: In moving this motion and on other occasions, I have drawn attention to the fact that, in relation to international conventions and international obligations, the federal government has often entered into agreements which have bypassed the proper democratic processes of parliament. We have seen numerous examples of this. For instance, we have given effect to the London Dumping Convention in local law. When one sought to tighten the provisions in that piece of legislation, one was told that one could not change one full stop or comma in the legislation because it had already been agreed to in an international forum. Similarly, by analogy at the state level under intergovernmental agreements within Australia, one often finds that governments have entered into agreements and the parliaments are presented with legislation which cannot in any way be modified.

There is a general concern in the parliament. That concern—which is certainly shared by the opposition, and to some extent by the government—is that these international conventions should, in some way, be brought before the parliament, and the parliament should have an opportunity to look at them and make some comment upon them.

We are the elected representatives of the Australian people. We have a responsibility, therefore, to ensure that we have a chance to look at what our government is entering into on our behalf. When it comes to legislation that gives effect to conventions, we also need to be able to make serious and sensible comments on them with a right to amend them if we do not like the provisions or we feel that the provisions are not strong enough. That has not been the situation up until this time.

I think there is wide agreement with the opposition that that is an area of quite serious concern. Senators will know that Senator Vicki Bourne is intending to have legislation debated in this chamber in relation to that matter. In a sense, motions of this sort are a first attempt to go down the road of democratising the processes in relation to international agreements, conventions and the like.

When Senator Chapman moved his motion, we believed that there was a certain misconception about this specific convention on desertification in that the desertification convention relates to the countries which are provided with aid in relation to desertification and, therefore, Australia in itself would not be subjected to any provisions within that desertification convention.

However, we have as world citizens a responsibility in relation to environmental protection and the effect of desertification. There might be some argument about this, which can be looked at by the committee to which this matter is referred. Senator Chapman earlier quoted two Oxford scientists who had done work on desertification and were claiming that desertification had not advanced as far as many other people were claiming and that there was something of a beat-up in relation to desertification. Leaving that matter aside, we see the question of desertification very much as an environmental matter, in relation to this convention. As I said, as world citizens, we have a responsibility to look at that. While the social and other consequences are significant, the primary concern should be that of the environment. That is why we have chosen to refer this convention to the environment committee.

I think that there has been a great deal of misunderstanding in the Australian rural community about the impact of this convention on people in rural areas. We believe that the convention will not have impacts on those people, but in deference to Senator Chapman's concern—I hope he notices this—the last term of reference of this committee has been modified to take those matters into account. The committee can look at those matters and, if it finds that we are right that there will not be economic and social impacts on rural people, that will be reported. Hopefully, that process will help to lay to rest those unfounded concerns which people in the rural community have.

I, therefore, draw Senator Chapman's attention to clause (e). The original motion referred to `the impact of the desertification convention on the sustainability of rural, pastoral and mining communities'. It now reads `the impact of the desertification convention on the economic, social and environmental sustainability of rural, pastoral and mining communities'. I believe that picks up the concerns Senator Chapman expressed in his original motion, the motion which was rejected by the Senate.

I hope that the opposition will see fit to support this motion. It will clearly achieve the first objective, which was to bring the convention before a committee of the Senate. In relation to the specific concerns which Senator Chapman voiced, I believe that they have been taken care of in that amendment.

It was our understanding that the government would support this reference to the environment committee but was not prepared to support Senator Chapman's reference. I have just had an indication from the government that it is not now supporting the reference. I had hoped that it would, because it is a serious matter if the government enters into these international agreements and conventions while bypassing the democratic processes and elected representatives of the people of Australia, who should have some input into the acceptance, modification or otherwise of these international conventions. I am surprised that the Labor Party, which prides itself on being a democratic party, evidently seeks to continue a situation in which government can go ahead unilaterally and do these things.

It is often argued that governments are the bodies elected to make these sorts of decisions and that they have a mandate to do that. But at election time governments and political parties never set out that they intend to enter into this, that and the other agreement. That is not part of their charter. It is therefore not part of their mandate to enter into those agreements without bringing those agreements back before the elected representatives—before the House of Representatives and the Senate. Therefore, I am rather surprised that the government on this occasion is not prepared to accede to this motion.

I strongly recommend to the opposition that it support this motion because it does achieve, I believe, the objectives of its original request. It is somewhat broader in that it recognises and emphasises the environmental aspects. It picks up the concerns which those opposite have expressed in relation to the democratic process. It also picks up their concerns in relation to the impacts of this convention on rural people because it specifically talks about the economic and social impacts on rural, pastoral and mining communities. That has been done by way of amendment. Therefore, I strongly urge the opposition to accept this motion and to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved this morning by Senator Coulter, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, seeks to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts for inquiry and report the proposal by the federal government to sign the international convention on desertification. The motion lists a range of references, which I seek to have incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The list read as follows—
The intention of the Federal Government, in October 1994, following the final negotiating session in Paris, to sign the International Convention on Desertification, with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the extent of desertification in Australia's rangelands, its causes and environmental, social and economic impacts;
(b)actions required to halt and reverse desertification in Australia;
(c)the means of monitoring the progress of programs directed at reversing desertification in Australia;
(d)the capacity of the desertification convention to contribute to Australia's efforts to halt and reverse desertification, both in Australia and overseas; and
(e)the impact of the desertification convention on the economic, social and environmental sustainability of rural, pastoral and mining communities.

SPEECH.PARA: Those terms of reference indicate that this motion is a rather unsubtle attempt by the Democrats to engage in a pea and thimble trick. What the Democrats are doing by proposing this reference is using the international convention on desertification as an excuse to promote a wide-ranging environmental inquiry in Australia. That is an inquiry that is simply not needed.

PARA.TAB: In his remarks when moving this reference, Senator Coulter claimed that there was a misconception regarding this convention in relation to Australia because it relates to countries which are provided with aid to deal with the environmental problem of desertification. In saying that, of course, Senator Coulter is completely ignoring the potential domestic impact of this convention through the capacity it gives the federal government yet again to abuse its external affairs power under the constitution.

Senator Coulter also indicated that this inquiry really is, as I said, a pea and thimble trick, by saying that the environment is the most important issue in relation to this convention. There is no doubt about the importance of the environment, but the environmental issues in relation to desertification in Australia are already being handled in a number of satisfactory ways. They are already the subject of the landcare inquiry that is being carried out by the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. There are a number of programs underway to deal with the particular environmental problems that relate to this matter.

But what has not been properly investigated is the potential impact of this convention on Australia and, as I particularly referred to a few moments ago, its impact in relation to the power it gives the federal government under the external affairs power. As I said, if we are going to have an inquiry into this convention, that should be the focus of the inquiry not the Australian environment, which is already subject to adequate inquiry in this regard.

Certainly, the last term of reference in Senator Coulter's motion, which asks the committee to look at the impact of the convention on economic, social and environmental sustainability of rural, pastoral and mining communities, does, to some extent, attack that issue. But I suggest that that is merely a sop to try to persuade our side of this chamber that we ought to support what really is an inquiry focused in an entirely different direction. It is not adequate simply to tack on at the end of Senator Coulter's terms of reference one term of reference that looks at one particular aspect of that convention when the whole thrust of the inquiry is in a different direction altogether.

As I said, the inquiry that Senator Coulter has proposed on behalf of the Australian Democrats is simply not needed. The terms of reference put forward by Senator Coulter divert attention from the main issues which surround this United Nations convention. Those main issues are, first, its potential to centralise the control of land management in Canberra—

TALK.START.PARA: —A shame!

—A shameful possibility, Senator O'Chee. The second issue is Australia's potential liability at international law under this convention, and the third is this Labor government's appalling record of abusing the external affairs power under our constitution to override the proper jurisdiction of the states. These are the important issues that relate to Australia's intention to sign and subsequently ratify this convention on desertification.

PARA.TAB: These are the issues which my proposed reference to the rural and regional affairs committee of the Senate would have addressed had it been carried successfully when it was debated in this chamber a couple of weeks ago. These are the issues of real concern to Australians, especially those living in rural and regional areas. But sadly, these are the issues to which the Democrats, along with the Greens and the government, paid scant regard when they voted two weeks ago to defeat that proposed inquiry. Instead, they now want to initiate a wide-ranging, unnecessary inquiry into desertification in Australia, an issue which, as I have already said, is being addressed and indeed is already the subject of an inquiry by the Senate rural and regional affairs committee in its landcare investigation.

Senator Coulter in the debate a couple of weeks ago argued that he would not support my reference of the convention to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs—and he repeated it again today—because in his view it would not apply to Australia. If that is the case, we have to look at his attempted reference today as a rather cynical and transparent attempt to confuse the issue and to manipulate the political agenda, with the possible intended outcome of affecting the national rangelands management strategy, when he knows he does not have the support of either the opposition or the federal government.

Senator Coulter's narrowing of the context to examine desertification only in Australia ignores the substantial nature of the convention, which places Australia in the category of affected developed country which will not receive assistance but which is required to provide assistance to affected developing countries. Examining desertification in Australia does not go to the problem of the extent to which aid is necessary to assist developing countries. The reference which I sought a couple of weeks ago would have examined the potential domestic policy implications of implementation of the convention on Australia. That, as I have already said, is a quite separate issue but it is the key issue with regard to this convention.

Another of Senator Coulter's reasons for seeking this particular reference, as he said in his remarks a couple of weeks ago, was the impact of population growth on the incidence of desertification. Given the Australian context of today's motion, that is rather irrelevant and inconsistent. Australia's rural regions have actually experienced negative population growth; they have experienced falls in population. Senator Coulter well knows that. Population considerations are therefore not relevant to desertification as an issue in Australia.

The inescapable fact is that the impact of the convention on domestic policy will mostly affect rural and regional Australians. Consequently, it is that earlier reference that should have been undertaken if we were really concerned about the impact of this convention. Senator Coulter's motion pays lip-service to the international nature of the convention by seeking examination of the capacity of the desertification convention to contribute to Australia's efforts to halt and reverse desertification both within Australia and overseas. It ignores the consequences for Australia of being bound at international law, of handing over its national sovereignty and providing the Australian government with the legislative capacity, through the capricious exercise of the external affairs power, to centralise control of rural land management. One can ask where the Democrats' allegiances really lie.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not Democrats for the bush, that is for sure.

—The evidence would suggest that, Senator O'Chee. Of course, Senator Lees is running around the rural areas of South Australia all the time, trying to cuddle up to farmers in rural communities, suggesting that the Democrats are the true friends of rural people.
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I believe there is a sexist connotation in what was said by Senator Chapman and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—There is no point of order.
—Mr Deputy President, I seek a point of clarification. Are sexist connotations not considered unparliamentary?
—Not unless they reflect upon any senator and the senator towards whom the remark is directed takes offence.
—I have taken offence.
—There was no reflection on you, as I understand it, Senator Margetts.

—Senator Margetts seems extremely sensitive this morning. I was not even referring to the Greens; I was referring to the Australian Democrats. I assume that her remarks related to my comment that Senator Lees, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, was running around South Australia cuddling up to farmers in rural communities. I do not see any sexist connotation in that remark. Males or females can cuddle up. I do not see why it should be regarded as being particularly disparaging of females.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying before that interruption, Senator Lees runs around South Australia purporting to be the friend of farmers and the rural community. Yet we have the Democrats proposing a wide-ranging inquiry, completely ignoring the potentially detrimental impact of this convention on rural communities. They are looking at only one side of this issue rather than taking a balanced approach. They are really ignoring the main issue of this convention as it potentially impacts on rural and regional Australians.

The real issues seem to have totally escaped the Democrats with regard to this proposal, because the real issues are not the impact of desert regions in Australia or the extent of deserts, or even what is required in Australia to halt and reverse desertification. They are quite different issues. The first is whether it is appropriate that Australia deal with desertification as an environmental problem and as a social and political problem in Australia—or in Africa, Latin America, the Mediterranean or the Caribbean—through the mechanism of an international bureaucratic body.

The second issue is the United Nations environment program's scandalous mounting of a publicity campaign based on flawed scientific evidence on a subject largely misunderstood even at the international scientific level, purely to manipulate the global environmental political agenda and attract aid funding to maintain its own bureaucratic hierarchy. I addressed that in some detail in my remarks on the earlier proposed reference a couple of weeks ago—and I do not need to add anything more to that today.

The third is an issue which the Democrats have ignored in their proposed reference: the usurpation of Australian sovereignty by an international committee and the stifling of democracy in this country by not allowing the public some foreknowledge as to how their lives and livelihoods may be affected by Australia's accession to this convention. The government has given no indication as to how this convention may be implemented in this country. That the government has chosen not to do so but instead has displayed a willingness to sign away our sovereignty without confronting the Australian public's legitimate concerns should ring alarm bells, even for the Democrats. But it seems to have failed to do so.

Of course, we should not forget that, when former Senator Richardson was minister for the environment and was questioned on this issue, he refused to rule out—I think it was Senator O'Chee who asked the question—the possibility of the Australian government at some future date using the external affairs power that it would have under the signing of this convention to impose its will with regard to rangelands management.

The signing of this convention represents an almost certain potential for abuse of the external affairs power to further control land management in Australia, to override state laws and to centralise federal government power in the process. It should be noted that this ludicrous situation has not escaped some of those on the government's side. A former Labor minister, Peter Walsh, in an article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on 12 July, wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not and never have been a monarchist but find it ironic that so many contemporary Australians determined to protect us from the non-existent threat of English tyranny, fall over each other in a scramble to surrender Australian sovereignty to a ragtag and bobtail of unrepresentative UN committees accountable to nobody.

I say, `Hear, hear!' to that. Of course, he is not the only senior Labor figure expressing concern about the federal government's abuse of power. Only this week, the Queensland Labor Premier, Mr Goss, launched a detailed criticism of the federal government's approach. Premier Goss is therefore now on common ground with the Liberal state premiers—and, I might say, on this issue he is on common ground with us in the federal opposition.

PARA.TAB: While there is an obvious overlap in terms of the environmental impact of desertification—and perhaps the Democrats have taken into account in this proposal my criticisms of the wide-ranging and conflicting scientific evidence and have attempted to clarify the nature of desertification—one cannot ignore that Australia's existing programs and inquiries are already examining this issue in the Australian context. I must repeat that the emphasis of Senator Coulter and the Democrats in this proposed reference represents both a duplication of, and an interference in, that process that is already under way.

The majority of Australians are preoccupied with a national drought of crisis proportions. This convention is something which they simply do not want. To them, it is unnecessary and it is irrelevant. If we need to provide assistance through aid and technology exchange to other countries that are suffering from this problem, that can be readily accommodated through our existing bilateral and multilateral aid provisions.

Perhaps if the government came clean on how it proposes to implement the convention and addressed some more relevant Australian concerns, instead of indulging in this preoccupation with international posturing and centralisation of power, the Australian community in general—not to mention those of us in the opposition—might feel a little more charitable in regard to the government's approach to international conventions.

Let me conclude by summarising that the signing of an international convention and the consequent domestic policy impact is not a matter for a wide-ranging environmental inquiry as proposed by the Democrats. The most unsatisfactory aspect of Senator Coulter's motion today, apart from the inconsistencies on which it is based, is that it is an attempt to manipulate the environmental agenda in this country for political point scoring purposes. It is quite senseless to attempt to turn every issue into an environmental issue regardless of the nature of the problems.

I suggest that an attempt to do that is nothing more than political opportunism and political cynicism, and that is something the Australian public, I believe, would find unacceptable. So it is on that basis that the opposition certainly will not be supporting this motion for the signing of the convention to be referred, on the basis provided by the Democrats, to a committee for investigation. I urge the Senate likewise to vote against it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it might be appropriate if I speak on behalf of the government on this occasion because the next duty minister will be here shortly, but not briefed on this debate. I therefore apologise for jumping ahead of Senator Margetts in the queue. The government does not support this motion, does not see the point of it and thinks that the consultations necessary to qualify the government to sign this convention on 14 October have been wide ranging and comprehensive and justify the government taking the view that this convention should be signed.

PARA.TAB: This convention arises because of global concern that the planet earth is increasingly turning to desert, the areas of natural environment are in decline, the areas of rangeland and cultivatable land are in decline, deserts are taking over and, most importantly, that is occurring in Third World countries but not only there. Australia is a First World country. Arguably, that phenomena that we are witnessing is occurring here.

As a consequence of that global problem, governments of the world believe that an international solution must be found and international action must be mounted, and that action mounted in one country to solve the problem may not even help in that particular country if there is not unified action elsewhere. This is a classic case of the United Nations playing a role for the planet. This is a classic case where international cooperation and action is necessary. It is as a consequence of that universally perceived view that this convention has come to life.

I am not sure of the exact number of countries which have been involved in the process of hammering out this convention. I might be wrong, but I think it is 112. We have a convention which is the product of the labours of 112 different countries—all with different political systems, all with different political views and different responses to the development versus environment debate. But they are united in the view that we cannot let the globe go the way it is going without taking an international stand, and that point unified everybody. As a consequence of all that diversity and difference, there is now an international convention in which Australia has played an important part in bringing to life.

When the United Nations succeeds in getting global action on a major issue, it ought to be applauded. It is a miracle in itself to get 112 countries to agree on anything; yet we have universal international agreement at the negotiating table for a convention on a serious matter. The trouble is that, when it gets to Australia, it falls foul of what I regard as petty domestic politics, and those petty domestic politics overwhelm the vision of what is necessary here.

When the United Nations does something which stimulates the world, people say, `Good on the United Nations. What a fantastic system.' The United Nations system tends to be mired down in squabbling and detail and unable to act cleanly and effectively. This is an occasion on which it can act cleanly and effectively. The detractors say, `We haven't had enough time to consider this. We should not have to vote on it. This is anti-democratic. It is a usurpation of the constitutional powers.' They make criticisms of that nature. But here is a global problem; and here is a unified global response. On 14 October the government will play its global role in supporting this international convention by signing it.

Before I go to the detail of this motion, I want to deal with two of the threshold arguments put forward, firstly, by the Democrats and, secondly, by the opposition. The Democrats—without denying the larger picture at all and to be fair to them—would emphasise the larger picture in stronger and more colourful terms than perhaps I have. I note for the record that Senator Coulter is nodding his agreement to that point. I express to Senator Coulter that I think that would be the case. That in no way denies our commitment to it, but his tendency would be to express that more strongly.

However, the Democrats say that there should be greater parliamentary debate, that it is a usurpation of power by the executive for the terms of this convention not to be subject to greater parliamentary debate and somehow that is undemocratic. I put it to Senator Coulter in these terms: there are 112 countries, if my figures are right, involved in this. We are one. That means that 112 parliaments of some sort or another—some of them not democratic, that is true; others of them very democratic—are required to support this one way or another, yes or no.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a reservation?
—They can put reservations forward if they want to. If we want to indulge in the technicalities—
—They have a right; it is not just yes or no.

—It is not a yes or no thing; Senator O'Chee is absolutely right. I concede the point. They can support it, yes or no, or they can put reservations to it. The purpose of putting a reservation to it escapes me because what is required is not someone to say, `I'm half pregnant' or `I'm half in support of these things' or `only in these circumstances' or `owners of pearl-handled pocketknives can indulge in that particular act and non-owners cannot' or other trifling technicalities of that sort.

PARA.TAB: What is required here is firm across-the-board unified international action. If every parliament of the 112 countries is going to have complete and utter licence to pore over the terms of this convention and change it at will—and to take the example further, as some in the opposition may wish to do; that the states in the Australian federation should have that opportunity—the number of negotiators will be expanded by the number of members of the 112 parliaments. The possibility of the United Nations ever being able to agree on anything, when any one of those can veto it, would become absolutely impossible.

There has to be a simple and democratic way of doing it—and there is in Australia. That is found in our constitution. It has been given to the Commonwealth government by our constitutional forefathers in their wisdom. The Commonwealth government of Australia has the power under the constitution to enter into these conventions. If the Commonwealth then wants to apply those conventions within Australia and wants to legislate to do so, it has to come to the parliament for the right to apply them. But the right to enter into them is, under the constitution, with the Commonwealth government.

Otherwise, every member of this place and every member of the other 112 places would have a say and we would never arrive at a conclusion. That is not a recipe for action; that is a recipe for defeating the purpose of a convention where there is overwhelming international recognition that something has to happen. It is a recipe for preventing action, not a recipe for doing anything. It is a recipe for avoiding the point, not reinforcing the point. It is a recipe for befuddling the community, not galvanising it around a perceived public need. Those opposite are still pretending that they are on the side of arguing for improvement in the environment while they are doing all this befuddling, beguiling and misrepresentation.

The argument raised by the opposition is that this is an abuse of constitutional power by the Commonwealth. It is a silly argument. It is an argument that has no basis in foundation. We cannot have an argument which says that the constitutional forefathers who drafted the constitution of Australia did not mean to include an empowerment to the Commonwealth government to effect international treaties and conventions. They did. That is accepted. If the government exercises that power we cannot say that the government is abusing that power. It is not.

The government was clothed with that power by the constitution. In the case of this convention, we are exercising our power quite properly after widespread consultation in the community about an international problem that requires urgent action. To describe that as abuse is an abuse of the understanding of the constitution. It is an attempt to use the constitution in a debate as if it is some sort of toy that can be thrown up to prevent action by a government on the basis that somehow the government is misrepresenting the constitution. The people who do that misrepresent the constitution—not the government.

We are not signing away our sovereignty; we are in fact reinforcing our sovereignty as our constitutional forefathers have framed the constitution. I am one of those people who think that the Australian constitution is inadequate in many respects and ought to be changed. But I will argue that in the proper forums at the proper time. This is a power in the constitution and the government is entitled to exercise it.

I turn to the arguments as to why we will not support this motion. The first argument is that the government has consulted widely with interested parties at every stage of these negotiations. The government has invited contributions widely within Australia in relation to the development of Australia's objectives for this convention. We have acted on that advice and sought to have those objectives enshrined in this international convention.

Arising from that community consultation, our objectives are: the convention itself should be international in scope but should provide for the development of regional, national and local plans and programs to combat desertification; it should ensure that it has addressed the underlying causes of what is turning land into deserts, including environmental causes, human behaviour and socio-economic factors; and it should include specific and remedial measures to turn back deserts into arable land. We have pursued the objective that ensures it contains effective and equitable funding provisions which maximise coordination of existing programs to combat desertification. The convention should also recognise the relationship between the desertification convention and other international environmental agreements, ensuring consistency between them all, and maximise possible commercial opportunities for Australian expertise in arid land management.

They were the objectives that arose from our community consultation which we proceeded to the international negotiating table with. Who did we go to that negotiating table with? Did we go on our own as a government? Or did we bring community representatives? We brought community representatives to the negotiating table so that it was not just the government negotiating but it was the government and the Australian community organisations negotiating together. We brought the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation, and they participated in the negotiations with us as a government; they participated actively as members of our delegation and in the international negotiating sessions. Did the government of Australia go as the government of Australia without recognition of the role of the states or the territories in Australia? No, it did not.

The government of Australia consulted closely with the states and territories. The states and territories, I might say, have played a significant role in the development of the policy positions that have been put forward. Their input led to the provision in the final text that the preparation of national action plans to combat desertification should be voluntary for developed country signatories—an issue that Australia pursued in these international talks—and the state of New South Wales represented the states and territories of Australia on the Australian delegation at all but the first of the five international negotiating sessions.

So we went as the government of Australia with the community organisations, the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation, and we went with the state of New South Wales representing the states—a comprehensive delegation representing the spread and spectrum of Australian political and ethical views on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The CSIRO also gave advice.

—The CSIRO as well, I am told, acted in an advisory way on this delegation. Importantly, Australia's objectives were met in full in the final text of the desertification convention and they were agreed at the final negotiating session in Paris on 17 June this year. All parties involved in the Australian delegation—the NFF, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the state of New South Wales representing the states and territories—supported the final text. That is the act of a responsible government representing the Australian community in the width and depth of its political and socio-economic spectrum and views on this subject. In signing off on this agreement, the voice of the Australian community is one that is bound to be heeded when the Australian government gives effect to its will by signing the formal document on 14 October.

PARA.TAB: Several processes are under way which are working towards researching the effects of desertification in Australia and which seek to develop and implement policies designed to relieve these effects.

I come to the second argument. What are we doing about implementing this convention and what are the things that are under way? I will refer to a few of them. The Commonwealth government is working with state governments and non-government organisations on the formulation of a national rangelands management strategy. The national rangelands management strategy will seek to provide management guidelines, scientific advice and recommend an ongoing consultation process relating to land use in Australia's rangelands while taking into account the economic and social implications. That is one major work on foot.

The Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs is currently inquiring into the landcare policies and programs in Australia, reporting on the last sitting day in December this year. It is a significant policy under scrutiny and it is subject to report later this year. The same committee is also inquiring into the rural adjustment scheme, reporting in December, and the value adding in agricultural production reporting in June of next year. That committee has a full workload and is doing significant things in those areas as well.

The review of the decade of landcare, currently being undertaken under the auspices of the National Landcare Advisory Committee, will look at the operations and appropriateness of landcare programs. How they operate in the rangelands will be a key issue to be considered in formulating the national rangelands management strategy. There are a number of inquiries, in principle, currently being undertaken. The findings of those inquiries will make up what the government decides will be its most appropriate approach in implementing these reports. I do not think anyone can seriously argue that the government should pre-empt these inquiries and declare an implementation program instantly to satisfy and gratify some of the members of this Senate who ask what it should be. I think it is entirely appropriate that those inquiries go through, be completed and that the findings be publicly aired and contested. The government should draw from them in formulating its implementation program.

The government considers that the issues raised in this motion are in the process of being addressed to the satisfaction of the majority of the interests that are involved; that is, through the consultative process, which surrounded the effective preparation of Australia's negotiating position on the convention. It is a position which is reflected in the final text and through the ongoing processes I have outlined in which government scientists, experts and land users are working together to find solutions to the environmental, economic and social difficulties which our arid environment presents us with.

In conclusion, there is nothing that is happening here which can be stalled by allegations that we are undemocratic. That is nonsense. We are acting perfectly and responsibly within the constitution, as everyone knows. If we were not, there would be a challenge to us and we would be struck down and so we should. There is no challenge. We are not struck down. We are acting with authority, and we should proceed. What is the issue on which we are proceeding? It is the fact that this globe's land mass is turning to desert and requires concerted international action by all countries in the world to remedy it. It is an overwhelming international environmental issue. It is supported by all colours and stripes of government and political opinion as a major international problem. Australia in those circumstances has an obligation as a leading and developed nation in the world to play its role with the United Nations under this convention to attack that problem. That is all that this government wants to do: stand up for this country, play its international role properly and ensure that a serious environmental problem is properly dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I went to the dentist this morning and the pain of having a tooth pulled is nothing in comparison with the pain which will be inflicted upon rural Australia if this treaty is signed without scrutiny. There are, therefore, two issues which need examination today. The first question to be asked is whether it is appropriate to sign this treaty, as the government would have us do, without any consultation with the parliament and without any parliamentary scrutiny. The second question to be asked is: if parliamentary scrutiny is appropriate, what is the best manner in which to conduct that scrutiny?

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators listening to Senator Cook, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, might be mistaken for believing that Senator Cook is actually concerned about this country. In fact, he is not. Some of the arguments that we have heard from Senator Cook have been totally and utterly spurious.

Senator Cook started by saying that there were 112 countries involved in the negotiation of this treaty. That is probably the case. He then went on to say that there are 112 parliaments that will have to decide yes or no. Leaving aside the question of reservations, that is exactly what Senator Cook said. But the interesting thing is that this parliament will not get the right to say yes or no because this arrogant minister and this arrogant government have taken it upon themselves to decide what is good for this country and what is not, without any reference to the parliament and without any reference to this chamber.

The role of the parliament is to keep an eye on the ministry. The role of the parliament is to ensure that the executive does not have an unfettered power to do as it wishes. Yet this minister says, `Forget about your responsibility as parliamentarians. There are 112 nations which have negotiated on this and now that it has all been negotiated we do not want you to fulfil your obligation to scrutinise this convention.' That is the argument that the government puts up.

It follows from that argument that there is no point whatsoever in having this parliament because on every issue the government could say, `The executive has decided; there is no role for you.' But there is a role for us and that is why this parliament is here. This parliament is here because our founding fathers believed that no person, no government should be given unfettered power. Our role is to scrutinise what the people who sit opposite do.

TALK.START.PARA: —They gave us the right to sign it.

—Senator Cook's understanding of constitutional law is minuscule, to say the least. One of the most appalling misrepresentations that I have heard in this chamber is that the founding fathers, through the constitution, gave a power to the Commonwealth government to sign treaties. That is arrant nonsense. Senator Cook has obviously never read section 51 of the constitution.

PARA.TAB: Section 51 of the constitution does not say that a power is given to the Commonwealth government. It says that the Commonwealth parliament shall have the power to make laws with respect to, amongst other things, external affairs. It does not say `Commonwealth government' and it does not say `the executive'. It says that the Commonwealth parliament shall have a right to make laws with respect to external affairs.
