It follows that if the Commonwealth parliament has a right to make laws with respect to external affairs, we at least have a right to refer some of these matters to a committee for examination and report beforehand. But Senator Cook does not want us to do even that.

Here is the hypocrisy of those on the other side. They say that there is a power to make laws with relation to external affairs, but when we do not want to go as far as making a law, when we merely want to examine the issue beforehand, they say that we do not have a right to do it. What arrant hypocrisy! What utter garbage!

TALK.START.PARA: —Be honest for a change. Tell the truth for once.

—Senator Cook should listen. It would be a good thing if he were honest for a change. Senator Cook has a reputation in this chamber which is quite without parallel and he is only adding to it at the moment.Senator Cook says that there is an unfettered power. That is nonsense. To the extent that a power exists, to the extent that the executive has a right to sign these treaties, that power and that right are not embodied in the written constitution; they are embodied in common law.

PARA.TAB: When this country became a Commonwealth in 1900, the common law as it stood at that point in time was embodied in our constitution. What does the common law say about the power of the executive to sign treaties? The interesting thing is that before 1900, or before 1901, the common law did not recognise an unfettered power of the executive to sign treaties.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no federation before 1901, you stupid fool.
—I think Senator Cook ought to withdraw that.
—No, I don't think I should.
—I take offence, Madam Acting Deputy President, and I ask that it be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Minister, would you please withdraw?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I withdraw the remark but—
—Unqualified, please, Minister.
—Anyone who wants to argue that there was a federal constitution before 1901 really invites that sort of comment.
—Unqualified withdrawal!
—Senator O'Chee.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, was that withdrawal unqualified or otherwise?
—That was withdrawn, Senator.
—I thought you just asked the minister for an unqualified withdrawal.
—He has withdrawn it. Please continue.
—Okay, let us get on to the next silly point that Senator Cook came up with, which was the suggestion that there was no constitutional law in this country before 1900. That is utter garbage.
—Federal!

—Senator Cook again shows not only his ignorance but his lack of manners in interjecting as he leaves the chamber. He obviously shows that he has no concern for this issue if he wants to march off in a huff. That sort of schoolboy stuff is not going to do in this place. Let us examine the existing common law in relation to—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is a standard practice in this place not to attribute motive to people. Senator O'Chee has just attributed a motive to Senator Cook, and I ask him to withdraw it.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I was merely reflecting on the fact that Senator Cook did not have the good manners to sit in his place whilst he interjected.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, further to the point of order: that is not what I was objecting to. It was suggested that Senator Cook was leaving this place in a huff. That is completely inappropriate, Senator O'Chee, and you know that. Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask that the senator withdraw it.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: if anybody thinks that Senator Cook was in anything other than a huff as he left this chamber, I think they would be sitting on their lonesome because it is quite clear that Senator Cook has, all the way through this debate, shown an utter contempt of this parliament and an utter contempt of the right of people in this parliament to raise these matters. I merely reflected on his conduct as he left the chamber. I did not say why he was leaving the chamber; I reflected on his conduct as he left the chamber.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, further to that: Senator O'Chee has just confirmed my point of order by suggesting and claiming again that Senator Cook was leaving in a huff. You have no understanding—
—He was in a huff, Rosemary.
—You cannot assume that. That implies the state of the senator's attitudes.
—Come on, Rosemary; get serious!
—I am being very serious. Senator Cook had to leave this chamber, just as much as I came here, for all sorts of other reasons.
—Everybody is laughing at you, Rosemary.
—Order! Senator O'Chee!

—You are the person who is flying in the face of decent practice in this place. If you want to go by the rules of the Senate, let us do that. You have ascribed motive to Senator Cook that is clearly outside of the standing orders and I ask, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the senator withdraw it.
—Senator O'Chee, my interpretation of your comments was that you were indicating that you thought Minister Cook was misleading the Senate. Am I correct?
—Madam Acting Deputy President, that was not the point of order taken.
—No, but in the debate.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, if I may assist you on the point of order, at that point in time Senator Cook was in the chamber and took no offence whatsoever.

—Senator O'Chee, I would appreciate returning to the debate. I do not think there is a point of order. However, I would appreciate it if you would withdraw your later comments, if you made them, about Senator Cook misleading the Senate and if you could return to the subject and be perhaps a little less effusive in your language.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I did not say that he misled the Senate; I said he misrepresented the constitution.
—Okay.

—Senator Cook, in his address, accused honourable senators on this side of the chamber of misrepresenting the constitution. I think it is perfectly in order for us to reply to that matter and to reply in substance, which is what I am seeking to do. Madam Acting Deputy President, for clarification, I did not say that he misled the Senate.
—Thank you.

—But he has clearly misrepresented the constitution and the constitutional law. The constitutional law is very clear on this matter. It was considered in a case called The Parlement Belge, and it was held that there was no unfettered power in the executive to execute treaties. In particular, the court in that case—and it has been upheld on numerous occasions since—ruled that, where the executive signs a treaty which could have implications for the property rights of private individuals, the effects of that treaty are a nullity because the execution of the treaty is ultra vires. Senator Cook clearly either does not understand that or does not wish to understand it, and that is the problem that this parliament faces.

PARA.TAB: What we have seen from this government is nothing but obfuscation on the entire issue of its constitutional power and nothing but obfuscation on what is really behind this convention. For example, Senator Cook told this Senate just a couple of minutes ago that there had been a widespread process of consultation. That widespread process of consultation did not go so far as the tabling of this convention in this parliament. So much for the process of consultation.

This parliament is the forum to which this government must bring its ideas and its proposals. This parliament is the body with which the executive must consult. Has it consulted with the parliament? The answer is clearly no. It has not even had the decency to table the convention. So how can it say there has been widespread consultation? Nothing could be more offensive to the truth than to suggest that there has been widespread consultation, whereas, in fact, there has not.

What has this government done? This government has rushed off overseas with the idea of signing yet another convention. What is really behind this convention? Is it a concern for countries in Africa that are suffering from desertification? Or is it that this federal government wants to grab the land management powers off the states and grab powers off local authorities to manage their own shires? This is what it is really about, because Senator Cook gave the game away. Senator Cook said, in relation to the national action plans that are called for under the convention, that they were voluntary on affected developed countries.

That is true; they are voluntary. But once the government lodges a national action plan, it is bound by that plan. So, yes, the plan is voluntary, but once it is lodged it becomes binding. It is merely the lodgment of the plan that is voluntary and not the undertaking to follow that plan. As soon as this government lodges a national action plan it will say to the states and local authorities, `I am sorry, we now have the power as a result of this treaty to handle land management issues in the states.' The idea that a couple of bureaucrats sitting here in Canberra can tell a local authority how it should manage its shire is quite simply preposterous. There are over 300 local authorities in my state of Queensland alone. Goodness knows how many hundred local authorities there are in New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria, and all these affected areas.

This is what the federal government's real agenda is—it is all about power. It is not really about the environment. It was made clearer what the government's agenda was when Senator Cook said that the rangelands management strategy was part of the process of implementation. `Implementation' is the appropriate word, because the government intends to implement against the wishes of the states and against the wishes of local communities some sort of plan which was drawn up by UN bureaucrats. It is really offensive to me and offensive to many people in rural Australia that the Europeans, who have done a wonderful job of destroying their environment, will now get a say in how we run ours. That is a marvellous suggestion from the government, and that is where it is going.

One of the very disturbing things about this whole process is the manner in which people seem to suggest that there is massive desertification in Australia at the moment. It is a fact that, drought notwithstanding, there is more water in some areas of western Queensland than there was 100 years ago, and there is a reason for that. Senator Crowley laughs because she obviously does not understand the issue and does not understand that it was only 100 years ago that people started putting bores in western Queensland and started to put water into areas which were previously dry.

Senator Crowley represents that very narrow view of a small group of intellectual people who sit in Adelaide, who never get off the bitumen, who would not have a clue about Queensland, who would not have an understanding of the issues in question, and that is the danger in signing this convention. The best people to manage land management issues in Queensland are people who live there. People in Queensland—in Julia Creek, Richmond, Hughenden, Boulia and Bedourie—do not say how others should live life in South Australia.

People in western Queensland are not concerned about what Senator Crowley does with her backyard in Adelaide; that is her right. All they say is, `When it's our backyard, it should be our right.' That is where the government comes to a screaming halt because it does not believe that people in rural Australia ought to have the right to manage their own properties and manage their own shires.

TALK.START.PARA: —They mismanaged the Murray-Darling Basin.
—They want to manage it all from Adelaide. That is what this story is all about.
—You are in a bad mood today.

—The more Senator Crowley continues to interject in this rude fashion, the more it is patently obvious that Senator Crowley has no interest in listening to what people in western Queensland have to say, because she knows it all. I am afraid that Senator Crowley does not know it all. The more she listens and the less she interjects, the better this debate might be.

PARA.TAB: It is very clear that it is not necessary for us to sign this convention as it is. It is very clear also that we have other rights available to us—for example, the right to sign the convention with a reservation. Of course, if one listened to Senator Cook, one would believe that all the countries which have negotiated this convention will sign without reservation. Of course, this is a myth which the government puts around on a whole host of conventions but it is clearly not the case. For example, the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights is signed with reservation by large numbers of countries. Yet this is part of the myth that the Labor Party wants to perpetuate—that everybody is going off on this utopian global action thing. The fact is that we will probably be one of the few countries which signs without reservation and without any consultation with the parliament. That is how arrogant this government has become. So it is clear that this convention does need parliamentary scrutiny.

The next question is: what is the best way in which to scrutinise this convention? Do we go down the route that Senator Coulter is proposing? We in the coalition disagree because we believe the better forum for this matter is the rural and regional affairs committee. I am very concerned about the terms of reference that Senator Coulter has provided because they give absolutely no scope for the committee which he proposes should examine the matter having a chance to look at the issues for local authorities, to look at the issues for land management and to look at the constitutional powers of the states and the rights of local communities to determine what happens in their own backyard.

Instead, Senator Coulter's terms of reference in his motion seem more aimed, in paragraphs (a), (b), (c) and (d), at establishing a massive pattern of desertification in this country so that this country's land management can be further handed over to the scientific bureaucrats. For example, paragraph (a) states that the committee should examine—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the extent of desertification in Australia's rangelands, its causes and environmental, social and economic impacts;
(b) actions required to halt and reverse desertification in Australia;
(c) the means of monitoring the progress of programs directed at reversing desertification in Australia;
(d) the capacity of the desertification convention to contribute to Australia's efforts to halt and reverse desertification, both in Australia and overseas;

The terms of reference do not mention looking at the competency of the federal government to legislate with respect to these matters, and that is of concern to us. We on this side of the parliament do not believe in giving a blank cheque to the government. That is what the first part of this debate is about. The second part of this debate relates to who should examine these issues—who is best qualified to examine these issues. We clearly believe that these terms of reference miss the main point of the objections that people in rural Australia have.

PARA.TAB: The sad thing is that there is so much that can be done to make inland Australia more productive. One of the sad things is that if this sort of motion goes through and if this convention is signed without reservation we may lose the opportunity to deal with those problems, because the best way of dealing with problems of desertification and so on is through water storage, water conservation and irrigation.Our concern is that these terms of reference do not examine that at all. They do not give the scope to do that. They do not focus on the bigger issue, which is how to make inland Australia more productive, because there is nothing wrong with the soil in most of inland Australia, it is just that it does not rain. If we can get more water to these areas, we can really make the country productive and we can improve the capacity to care for the soil, certainly in western Queensland, which I know very well.

Yet, if we limit all our efforts to halting desertification, if it exists, we really miss the point of how we are to make Australia more productive. For those reasons, we on this side of the chamber cannot accept Senator Coulter's motion. We do not believe it offers anything to people in the bush; we do not believe it offers anything in terms of a grand vision for the productivity of this country. Therefore, we will oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly today in support of the motion from Senator Coulter. People would realise that I was involved in the debate some weeks ago on the motion by Senator Chapman to refer to a committee a reference on the desertification treaty. I find it a bit rich that Senator Chapman has suggested today that the Greens and the Australian Democrats, especially the Greens, were not prepared to look at a balanced inquiry.

PARA.TAB: What we did at that time was to talk in detail to members of the opposition about such wording as is included in today's motion being included in the reference which they were proposing to put to a committee—that is, a truly balanced proposition, not just treaty bashing—and about their being prepared to put their information where their mouths were—and not just in relation to the environment. I wonder about their ability to read in some instances because part (a) clearly says that the proposal includes the `social and economic impacts'.

The call always seems to be one way when the environment is concerned. When someone suggests taking action on the environment, the call is, `But this will cost money.' It may well do; but I do not know whether the opposition is aware that the federal government does not have any department whose job is to look at the social and economic implications of government decisions. In Western Australia the current state government has abolished the social impact unit and our federal government has put no resources into looking at the social and economic implications of any policy decisions, especially environmental ones. So what is being asked for is not being done officially, to my knowledge, by any other committee or unit in Australia at the moment.

Yes, there is a national rangelands management strategy being developed. No, it will not have any requirements for people to do anything in particular, other than what is happening now. The rural and regional affairs committee is looking at a landcare study, but it is not specifically looking at economic and social implications. Senator Cook says it takes into account the economic and social implications. Who is providing that information on economic and social implications? Again and again we see that both major parties in this chamber separate out the environment from the economy, except when it is convenient not to do so.

When there are economic implications of our turning a blind eye to the damage we are doing to the environment, we are not giving ourselves the ability to find out what those implications are. If it is true that irrigation in Queensland, as has been mentioned by Senator O'Chee, has reduced desertification there, that information is also the kind of information this proposal is looking at in terms of actions required to halt and reverse desertification in Australia. It does not mean that that information is not taken into account. But at some stage in this parliament, we have to work out whether or not we want to know not just about the environment but about the social and economic implications of decisions which impact on the environment.

So far, I have seen no evidence that either side wants to know. They perhaps want to make cheap points; but they do not want to know. Therefore, when we see that both the impact of desertification and the impact of the desertification treaty are mentioned in this motion, I find it extraordinary that the government does not want to know either. It cannot tell me which people are paid by the federal government to look into these kinds of implications and tell us what the implications are—because they do not exist.

As I say, we are prepared to support this motion. I also reiterate that we were prepared to support a sensible, properly balanced motion from the opposition which was not forthcoming. I am extremely disappointed that the government is prepared to allow this point scoring to continue. If we do not at some stage look at the way that we can integrate environment, economic and social issues, we will continue to have these arguments on every single occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested to hear Senator O'Chee talk about the right of parliament. He was painting for me a picture of an all-powerful organisation that really does not have to take into consideration a wide variety of views on issues that are dealt with by parliament. But might I just say that much of the legislation that goes through both chambers has been as a result of interest groups lobbying the government, asking it to put in place legislation which will assist them in furthering the interests of their industry and the people associated with it.

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee talked about the validity of a treaty affecting private property. It must be very clear to anybody who thinks about these matters that any law or any treaty of any consequence which has been signed by a number of people will almost automatically affect private property. It is a question of dealing with that in a very thoughtful and considerate way and making sure that people are not disadvantaged. But surely the public interest on many occasions has to override the interests of individual people.

The United Nations is, in my view, much more important to this globe of ours and to the future of young people in it than Australia or any other nation. Any nation is capable of being wiped out in the event of war. I believe that the United Nations, while it is imperfect, has played a great role in preventing any wars of any great significance, even though it has had to deal with many of the regional conflicts that now exist, and is the only organisation capable of really solving these problems and restoring peace in those areas.

If one looks at the way in which the United Nations deals with developing protocols or conventions and the role of nations within that concept, one is reminded of all sorts of negotiations that go on in various areas of interest. The suggestion is that representatives of this country should go to the United Nations, sit down with representatives of numerous other nations to try to get some sort of compromise or consensus on what should be applied on a worldwide basis in the interests of all nations, and say, `Look, this is the position. We would be prepared to go so far on this issue, if you will come so far on the other issue.' But then all those representatives have to go back to their individual governments and ask, `What do you think of this document?' Those representatives would be sent back to negotiate again and again.

I have been involved in many negotiations in the industrial relations field. Might I say that the key to the success of most of the negotiations is that the people involved in them had the authority to say, `Yes, our country will accept that. That is the view of our country.' It is not done in isolation; it is done because the people who are there should understand what the policy and position of Australia is in all of these negotiations. Senator Cook has already indicated that there was an involvement in the negotiations on the desertification convention. He mentioned the fact that the New South Wales government was represented by the district lands commissioner representing the north-western New South Wales districts, an area of rangeland that could well be, and has been already to some extent, affected by desertification.

Here we have a situation where we are going forward with people who understand the issues, drawing into the process people in the community. To me, that is democracy. These people understand the issues and are able to put forward a view, having in mind the general position in Australia. In relation to this convention, those people went into those negotiations with a knowledge of the development of what is known as the decade in landcare. Our landcare policy was put in place as a result of a lot of work done by the conservation movement and by the National Farmers Federation.

I can say in this chamber that, as the chairman of the inquiry into landcare, the two people we first interviewed as witnesses were representatives of the Conservation Foundation, which at the time was one of the generators of the idea of landcare, and Rick Farley, who is the Chief Executive of the National Farmers Federation. One might think that there would have been differences in that area, but we found that most of the goals they had set were pretty much the same. There were some differences in some areas as to how we should reach those goals, but each of them wanted sustainable use of the land and the land preserved for future generations in this country.

We found that landcare is operating reasonably well, based on evidence in various public hearings. How can we say, `We think landcare is a great idea; we have to preserve the land' and then look internationally at a proposal to do something about desertification? Of course it is a big concern for landcare. Senator O'Chee talked about irrigation, water points and the preservation of water. The facts are that in most cases desertification is caused by grazing cloven-footed animals on areas which cannot sustain them. They destroy the land cover and all the vegetation. Gradually the sand takes over and the desert encroaches on land that was once used by kangaroos and other soft-footed animals. So this raises the question of the use of the land and the number of beasts we might have on that land.

We went to that conference at the United Nations with this fairly long history of landcare and our concern for the land in Australia. No doubt there would have been views of a fairly conservative nature expressed as to what should be put in writing and accepted by the international community. I imagine that others who are fairly gung-ho would have suggested views and clauses in the agreement that would have created a situation where the land could not be grazed or used at all. We have a situation that is different from that of a compromise by the groups.

People on the other side of the chamber are concerned, as Senator O'Chee is, about the government having the scrutiny of this convention. One would think there was something terrible about that, and that it was going to endanger everybody. For instance, Senator O'Chee talked about the right of local government to decide what should happen in its area. The facts are that local government boundaries and state boundaries in this nation are nothing but a hindrance when it comes to landcare. One of the largest landcare projects, and an area where probably more degradation has occurred than anywhere else, is the Murray-Darling area. There is a body that looks at the Murray-Darling area right across state boundaries, let alone local government boundaries. Landcare issues cannot be solved on a state-by-state basis; they have to be solved over the whole catchment area.

In our inquiry, by having discussions, listening to witnesses and travelling throughout Australia, we gauged very clearly, very easily and very early that the most successful landcare programs to bring the land back to its health and to look after the land in the future were based on catchment area plans and cooperation between farmers in a catchment area, even if it is only a small creek in a catchment area. For instance, we were told of the silly idea that had been in vogue over many years that if land was being cut up for ownership by farmers, whether it be under leasehold or freehold, it was done in squares. But in fact, for somebody to look after that land, it is more obvious and more correct to, say, run a fence along a ridge line so that the person in that area could more effectively look after the land without having to ask the person next door, or encroach onto that person's private property or whatever.

That is being overcome by the idea of the catchment approach to management. Sensibly, many of the farmers are looking at how they work and are operating together. It is no good looking after the area down at the bottom of the catchment if the area above is creating problems. We went over with all this knowledge and we put our footprint on the international convention. We have used our skill and our credibility in these international forums.
Let us look at some of the provisions in the convention. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. National action programs shall specify the respective roles of government, local communities and land users and the resources available and needed. They shall, inter alia:
(a) incorporate long-term strategies to combat desertification and mitigate the effects of drought, emphasize implementation and be integrated with national policies for sustainable development;

(b) allow for modifications to be made in response to changing circumstances and be sufficiently flexible at the local level to cope with difficult socio-economic, biological and geo-physical conditions;
(c) give particular attention to the implementation of preventive measures for lands that are not yet degraded or which are only slightly degraded;
(d) enhance national climatological, meteorological and hydrological capabilities and the means to provide for drought early warning;

(e) promote policies and strengthen institutional frameworks which develop cooperation and coordination, in a spirit of partnership, between the donor community, governments at all levels, local populations and community groups, and facilitate access by local populations to appropriate information and technology;
So far I do not see anything to be concerned about and that should take up the time of the Senate. It continues:

(f) provide for effective participation at the local, national and regional levels of non-governmental organisations and local populations, both women and men, particularly resource users, including farmers and pastoralists and their representative organisations, in policy planning, decision-making, and implementation and review of national action programs; and
(g) require regular review of, and progress reports on, their implementation.

That fits in with some of the things suggested by Senator O'Chee regarding the involvement of local government. However, this convention says that no parliament should be given dictatorial authority to make these decisions.

PARA.TAB: Democracy is not about electing people for three or four years and then letting them do what they like; it is about people all across Australia in all walks of life being involved to make sure that those elected do the job properly and in the interests of the community as much as possible. As we know, there are conflicts and different points of interest. To return to the document:

SPEECH.PARA: Landcare has also found its way through a process of cross fertilization of international processes into other UN plans and strategies. The essential elements of the Landcare partnership concept was imported from the Desertification Convention to the program of action for sustainable development of small island developing states which was adopted in Barbados in May this year.

Here we have a situation where we develop a correct concept and attitude based on inputs from people in all areas of life in Australia because land care also talks about parks and gardens and areas around the urban parts of Australia. We have influenced people all over the world as to the correct approach to these things; yet we have people opposite suggesting that it is a matter where we are being dictated to by others in the United Nations. That is absolutely untrue. We have a great deal of influence and will continue to exert that influence for as long as our credibility lasts.

PARA.TAB: That credibility requires that we not only make these suggestions and have input into these conventions but also sign them and carry them out ourselves. A classic example of why we should ignore state and local government boundaries is a recent development where a number of people have got together in the mallee area of south-west Queensland and north-west New South Wales. The land there, which is used for grazing, is very similar on either side of the state border. The people there are developing a system and a plan which will ignore that state boundary but will be good for the people who live there—people who are really Australians first, people who are making an input to the plan and who will have ownership of the plan. If that experiment can be used and translated into the international field, as far as I am concerned it is a great idea, and any convention that might cover that area should be signed by this particular nation.

Hypocrisy has been shown on the other side in regard to this motion. I opposed the motion put forward by the opposition recently to refer the matter to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs because I think the convention is correct and the government has behaved in a correct manner. I oppose today's motion for the same reasons: I think it is a great convention and we should sign it. We should be proud of the input that we have had to it and we should be determined to give the same sort of input to other issues that will benefit everybody on this globe of ours so that we can create the circumstances where we can have a peaceful globe and a peaceful future for the children of every country in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I was really surprised at what Senator O'Chee had to say because he devoted at least half of his speech to really supporting the notion that these conventions should come in some form back towards this parliament; in fact, I think he was most eloquent in that respect. He then went on and quite inconsistently said, `but bringing it before this parliament by way of bringing it before a committee did not fulfil that requirement'. I am not too sure but unless he actually wants to—and I suspect that is the position of the opposition—actually get rid of this convention altogether and do nothing about desertification, the opposition is just simply using this process as an excuse to get rid of the convention and to get rid of an attack on desertification. And that is supported because going back to Senator Chapman's original address when he was moving his own motion, he spent most of his time arguing that desertification did not exist.

PARA.TAB: So, putting those things together, one finds the inconsistency in Senator O'Chee's argument and the lack of acceptance of this motion, which speaks specifically of the impact of the desertification convention on the sustainability of rural, pastoral, mining, economic, social and environmental communities and so on. It picks up the concerns which he has, genuinely, but does not go down the track of arguing that desertification does not exist. One is therefore unable to accept that inconsistency from the opposition. Again, I would enjoin the opposition to come in behind this motion and support it on the grounds that it is a mechanism by which not conventions in general but this particular convention can come before some parliamentary scrutiny.

Senator Cook seemed to argue that, because there had been consultation—and he specifically mentioned the ACF, the farmers union and the government of the state of New South Wales—in framing the convention, therefore, it was fully democratic. I am a member of the Australian Conservation Foundation; it is a democratic organisation but democratic within the bounds of those people who join the organisation. It is not broadly representative of all the people of Australia, as is this parliament. Similarly, the farmers democratically elect the National Farmers Federation and it is representative, democratically, of farmers; but, again, it is not broadly representative of all the people of Australia.

If one is concerned about democratic representation, the appropriate institution to review this convention and conventions in general is clearly the parliament. When one looks at the House of Representatives, one finds that that is a very unrepresentative organisation in which the government has the numbers. Simply bringing the terms of the convention before the House of Representatives would result in the government guillotining them without any further consideration. It is in this House, where no party has the numbers to do that, in which bills, legislation and conventions are properly considered.

Essentially, Senator Cook argued that it is dangerous to bring these matters before the Senate because the Senate might water down the requirement. He conceded that the Democrats and the Greens would be seeking a strengthening of measures dealing with desertification. Our collective wisdom may improve the terms of the convention in relation to management of desertification in Australia. Horror of horrors, wouldn't it be terrible if we improved the way in which we managed our environment with respect to this very important matter!

Senator Cook went on to say, `Yes, but we have 112 nations dealing with this matter, and 112 nations will come up with different results.' How inconsistent of this government simply to hand away its powers in relation to the environment by way of an intergovernmental agreement. Under this intergovernmental agreement, the government has handed to the arguments going on among nine governments the ability to undermine proper environmental concerns, the setting of proper standards for water, air, chemical exposure and a whole range of environmental issues. The government then came in here and said that, in relation to this international convention, it is not appropriate for this parliament to have a voice. The government does not have a logical leg to stand on with respect to that.

If this government wants unilaterally to sign these conventions, it should take up the powers—which it undoubtedly has under the constitution, and which are probably clearer with respect to environmental protection than in relation to international agreements—and it should appropriately legislate, but it does not do that. It wants two bob each way. It wants to argue one way with respect to international agreements and argue in a quite different direction when it comes to Australia's environmental protection under the so-called intergovernmental agreement.

This motion does what we believe is appropriate. It brings before the parliament the terms of the desertification convention as they will impact on Australia and elsewhere in the world—and it specifically mentions that. As world citizens—and I was pleased to hear Senator Cook at least pick up that part—we have a responsibility. Primarily, this convention is to do with those other countries to which Australia will give aid.

The 112 nations that came together were essentially represented by bureaucracies. They were not represented by the elected representatives of the people. That is the way these international conventions inevitably must be initially formulated. One can have no argument with that. It would be quite impossible to do it otherwise. It is appropriate that these international treaties and conventions come before the parliament. Contrary to what was said that this would necessarily lead to a weakening of these conventions and treaties, it may lead to a strengthening of them in which the treaty undertakings become the minimum requirement on countries. Each country can then legislate and move to impose stronger protective measures, in this case in relation to desertification in the environment.

Again, I would strongly enjoin the opposition in particular to support this motion because it picks up the point on which Senator O'Chee spent most of his time. It also brings back before the parliament the essential elements that were of concern to Senator Chapman. He was quite correct in commenting that it places emphasis on the environmental aspects of desertification, but I would have to disagree totally with his argument that desertification does not exist. I believe that the several scientists to whom he referred were right out of step with the many other scientists who have commented very extensively on this issue. I therefore strongly commend this motion to the Senate.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—In his remarks closing the debate on the proposed reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts a few moments ago, Senator Coulter claimed that, in my moving of a motion for a reference of the convention on desertification to an alternative committee a couple of weeks ago, I had said that there was no problem of desertification. I simply point out that that is not the case. What I did say on that occasion was that the United Nations bureaucracy had overstated the extent of this problem and, indeed, reputable scientists disagreed on the extent of the problem with regard to desertification. I also said in that context that reputable scientists disagreed as to the causes of the problem of desertification.

PARA.TAB: I at no stage made any claim that there were not deserts or that desertification was not a problem that needed some attention in certain countries. As I said, it has certainly been overstated by certain people and the nature of the problem is certainly a cause of disagreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Former Labor Deputy Premier Parker was gaoled for taking money from his electorate campaign fund and using it for private purposes. How does that differ from Labor Party officials taking money from the central campaign fund and using it to pay off candidates' gambling debts and to provide holidays for candidates' families? Is not such a payment a gross breach of trust to party donors who believe their contributions will go to legitimate campaign needs? Would not such conduct demonstrate a seriously deficient sense of public morality on the part of such Labor Party officials?

—For a start, the matters to which Senator Hill is referring obviously have to do with state candidates and state elections and nothing to do with the operation of Commonwealth elections or Commonwealth electoral law. Even if the funding in question that is referred to had related to a Commonwealth election, it would not have had to be disclosed under the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act as they stood at the time of Premier Burke's administration. It was not until 1992 that the act was amended to require third parties to disclose gifts made to candidates or parties, which would clearly have brought this sort of situation to light earlier on had that been the case.

PARA.TAB: The further point to be made about the particular case, however, of Mr Smith is that circumstances, as I am aware of them or as I have been advised of them, are manifestly very different in the sense that the transaction between the party and the candidate was completely open and straightforward, at least as between them. It did involve proper documentation and it did involve a very firm commitment for the funds in question being repaid.

The basis of the agreement was to ensure that a candidate who was in deep financial trouble did not have to resign his parliamentary seat. The money was advanced to him to resolve his pressing financial problem. There was a written agreement that he would repay the loan at commercial interest plus one per cent when he could or, at the latest, upon his retirement on the receipt of his considerable superannuation payout. It was authorised by the appropriate party officers. The transaction was one, under the circumstances, as I am advised, which manifestly did not operate as a disbenefit to the party, nor could it have operated as a disbenefit to any donor to the party from which the money was derived, because obviously it was to be repaid, and on a commercially appropriate basis.

I do not have to say any of that because it is all to do with state politics and all to do with state electoral law and state party administration. But I put the matters on the record because I think it is important to put the matter in context.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What we are seeking to explore are the moral standards of Labor Party officials and where this federal Labor Party government stands in relation to those issues. It has nothing to do with Mr Smith because Senator Chris Evans last night told us that Senator Beahan's comments did not relate to Mr Smith. What we are talking about are statements that campaign funds will be used to pay off candidates' gambling debts—not a loan—and for holidays of candidates' families. What I asked the minister was: if money is expended in that way, is it not a gross breach of trust to the party donors who expected the money to be used for legitimate campaign ends; and would not such conduct demonstrate a seriously deficient sense of public morality on the part of the Labor Party official concerned?
—What about the 10,000 bucks for the Northern Territory Chief Minister—
—Those who live in glass houses should not throw stones.
—out of Capricornia Pty Ltd?
—Order on my right!

—I hope Hansard has been taking down all those interjections because I want them incorporated passim in the record, if that is possible. It is the case, as Senator McMullan has been saying more noisily than most, that people in glasshouses should not throw stones. There is a long litany of matters on the record, or well known in political circles to be the case, so far as Senator Hill's side of politics is concerned, involving a whole variety of major corporate donors dealing in ways that I do not think he would be very keen to have exposed to the light of day, but which I will be perfectly happy to put on the record if he persists with this approach.

PARA.TAB: I have explained as best I can, to the best of my knowledge, the circumstance of the one particular matter that I am aware of so far as Western Australia is concerned. I am not aware of any other transactions that may have occurred. They are entirely speculative, hypothetical or the subject simply of gossip or rumour. They are not things about which I have any hard information at all. What I do know about, among other things, is the way in which some people on Senator Hill's side of politics have conspicuously misused taxpayers' funds—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. What will be the role of Social Security in the provision of new assistance measures for farming families affected by severe drought? How soon can families expect to receive this assistance?

—I particularly appreciate being asked this question. It is also very appropriate that it comes from Senator West, whose commitment to people in rural Australia is very well known. Under this initiative, families affected by exceptional drought will be eligible for new drought relief payments. The payments will be equivalent to jobsearch allowance with an automatic flow-on to eligibility for family payments. Austudy will also be extended. It means that a family with two children aged between 13 and 15 will be able to receive about $380 per week. This payment will not be subject to any assets test on the farm. The usual income test for jobsearch allowance and off-farm assets test will apply to ensure that the payment is directed to families in need. There will be no activity test on the payment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to that. Farmers will not have to put their properties on the market and they will not have to be rejected by commercial sources of finance. The payment will be available to farmers subject to the exceptional circumstances declaration by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and that definition of exceptional circumstances will apply uniformly across Australia.

PARA.TAB: The first payment will be made on 10 October and it will be able to be backdated to 1 October this year. The payment will continue for six months after the cessation of this declaration. The payment is part of a comprehensive package of assistance measures announced yesterday. It is estimated that farm families will receive a total of about $48 million this financial year and a further $21 million next financial year. If the drought breaks in autumn, under the drought relief payment that should see the payment assessed at about $21 million for next year. But if the drought persists beyond that, then a further $58 million is expected to be spent next financial year. These figures could increase if there are further exceptional circumstances declarations. The payments will be legislateable and will be available for as long as necessary and in any future exceptional droughts.

This initiative represents a major commitment by the government and a recognition of the legitimacy of the farm sector's argument that a targeted welfare response is necessary. The response is highly targeted to those in need as a result of severe drought. I acknowledge that the good news was accepted very favourably by a number of the senators opposite who spoke during yesterday's adjournment debate. They very much appreciated this payment package—in particular, the recognition that payments to families are a critical part of the assistance. This is not just ignoring the plight of the people out there, it is recognising very much that payments targeted to those families will be a very significant contribution to assistance during these exceptionally hard times. The package builds on the government's commitment to supporting families in need, particularly during this international year of the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to you. Last night Senator Chris Evans told the Senate that Mr David Smith was not the person referred to in your evidence at the Parker trial as the recipient of campaign funds for gambling debts. If this is true, who was the candidate that received campaign funds for personal purposes? How many other candidates benefited in a similar manner during your tenure as party secretary? How much money was involved? For what purpose were these funds used? And, on what grounds was it decided that these funds could be used for anything other than campaign purposes?

—On a point of order, Mr President: it pains me to take the point of order because it is directed at you, Mr President, and you thereby have to rule on it. But whatever duties you performed or activities you had as state secretary in Western Australia eight or nine years ago have no relevance to question time and your role as President. The only questions you can be asked concern your role as President. I know that raising the point of order puts you in an awkward position, having to rule on yourself. But had anyone else been in the same position, I would have taken the same point of order.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I also acknowledge that you have some slight difficulty in adjudicating upon a matter in which you clearly have an acute interest. But the fact is that this question relates directly to evidence given by you when you were the holder of very high office. We are not talking about actions of yours in the past, actions of yours as simply a party functionary; we are talking about very public actions of yours in giving evidence in a criminal trial. Those actions bear directly upon your current conduct and holding of high office. I ask you the question in that capacity.

—On the point of order: how can the same person stand in this parliament and say that to comment upon the current policy of the opposition is out of order but to comment on the political party activities of the government five years ago is in order? It takes to breathtaking proportions the capacity to say two different things with a straight face and pretend you mean them both.

—Order! The point of order raised by Senator Ray is, of course, correct. The other point I would like to make is that questions such as this and the answers that flow from such questions could well be sub judice since several other charges have been levelled against David Parker, the person to whom Senator Alston refers. Having said that, I welcome this opportunity to put the record straight on what I think has been some terrible misreporting of these events.

PARA.TAB: I did agree to give evidence at Mr Parker's trial. I gave evidence, firstly, as a character witness and, secondly, to comment in general terms on some of the problems faced by political parties in campaign fund raising. I was not asked about, nor did I comment on, any specific matters relating to Mr Parker's trial, nor was I aware, except through newspaper reports since that time, of the matters raised in that trial. In my comments on the use of campaign funds, I made two broad points. These points were consistent with the points I put to the royal commission prior to this. I made the point that the question of ownership of campaign funds has been a vexed and difficult one, since donations are frequently given to individuals rather than to the party and since the intention of the donor is frequently not known. I made the point also that the problem is experienced world wide, and I gave some examples of recent cases in America on this very thing. As I said, this was consistent with evidence I had previously given to the royal commission.

I made the second point that in expending campaign funds it is recognised that a wide discretion exists. Campaign expenditures sometimes involve judgments about whether certain things which may not appear to be directly related to campaigning are legitimate campaign expenditures. I indicated in relation to this that campaign funds had been expended on tidying up the image of a candidate. I believe that that is a justified use of campaign funds. I indicated also under questioning that I had heard of a candidate who had had a gambling debt met by what I thought was a campaign fund but which later proved to be party funds in a properly arranged loan.

At no time did I refer to specific matters relating to Mr Parker's trial. I also made it clear that funds under my direct control while I was state secretary from 1981 to 1987 were held under very tight control with complete probity and to strict accounting standards. All of those accounts have been examined by the royal commission and it has found nothing wrong with any of them—all of the accounts of the party over the period during which I was there. I have no reason to believe it has been any different since that time.

I made the point that the instructions that were given regarding other funds, such as the leader's fund and local funds, were that they should be run with the same standards and that under no circumstances should favours be given in return for donations received. As a result of the royal commission, the party's procedures have been tightened up and codes of conduct have been adopted by all states and nationally.

Disclosure legislation introduced in this parliament in 1991 now applies to all donations, state and federal. It did not at that time. I have always been a strong advocate of disclosure and I have also been an advocate of public funding, which I think is the only answer to this sort of problem long term. I have made a private submission to the royal commission to this effect. I did not condone the misuse of some funds that were not under my control during my term of office. I was simply trying in my evidence to convey some of the complexities of political fundraising and the expenditure that arises from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I welcome the additional material that is now before the Senate. Mr President, do I understand it from your remarks that when you went beyond giving character evidence for Mr Parker you were talking about party practices in such a way that you certainly did not dissociate yourself from them or disapprove of them? I therefore ask: on what basis do you say that it is a vexed question when funds are paid into a campaign account as opposed to a personal account? When you say that the intentions of donors are often not known, what attempts were made during your reign to ascertain the intention of donors before the moneys were given? On what basis do you now say that the code of conduct has been introduced, if it was not to improve practices which were clearly inadequate?

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the embarrassment and sensitivity of government senators. Mr President, do you now say that you dissociate yourself from the sorts of practices which you were quite happy to elaborate upon at Parker's trial, or do you still take the view that anything in the interests of the party is justified?

—Mr President, I take a point of order. You are not obliged to expose yourself to this kind of second rate, magistrate's court cross-examination. Under the standing orders, you have no obligation whatsoever to respond to questions other than those which are squarely to do with your administration of the presidency of this Senate. You chose to take the opportunity of an earlier question, which was manifestly out of order, to set the record straight. You have done so with dignity and in considerable detail. There is no obligation whatsoever on you to respond further; and I suggest that you do not do so.
—All I can say is that I have said in that statement all that I was going to say.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I understand that a meeting of the Cairns Group of representatives was held this week in Washington to discuss prospective developments in United States agricultural trade policy. Will the minister inform the Senate of the outcome of the meeting and any follow-up that is planned?

—It is a great pleasure to have the opportunity to take the Senate back to matters of national interest. This is profoundly in the interests of the nation and has the capacity to make a contribution to substantially improving the living standards of many people, many of whom the National Party purports to represent. I would have thought they would be interested and would not welcome attempted interjections, because they may wish to know about this.

PARA.TAB: There was a seminar of Cairns Group countries held in Washington on Tuesday this week. It was inaugurated during the meeting over which I presided in May, and was organised by the Australian Embassy in Washington. It was attended by ambassadors from the 14 Cairns Group countries. They came together for two reasons, the first of which—and that which I want to give most emphasis to today—was to continue the pressure for implementation of the Uruguay Round decisions, and the second of which was to maintain the pressure for agricultural trade reform which was initiated by the Uruguay Round.

The major preoccupation of the seminar was getting the Uruguay Round ratified and implemented by the US Congress. I would have thought that all would share that priority. The Cairns Group ambassadors agreed to step up collective pressure on the United States administration and the Congress—the administration is trying to get the legislation through; it is Congress that is causing the difficulty—to pass the legislation in time to allow the agreement to enter into force on 1 January 1995, with the benefits starting to flow accordingly. This action will serve to reinforce the message which I reported to the Senate earlier.

The Washington representatives of the Cairns Group agreed to write a joint letter this week signed by all 14 ambassadors or their representatives to key congressional committee leaders. The message they will deliver is that it is critical that they pass their legislation so that the World Trade Organisation and the agreement it is designed to implement can commence on 1 January 1995; that the United States must faithfully honour the commitments it has made, particularly in relation to agriculture, in the Uruguay Round; and that it would be unacceptable for the United States to turn its export subsidy practices into general market expansion and trade development programs.

The Cairns Group participants, of which Australia is one, are concerned that such proposals have been put forward in the context of the draft Uruguay Round legislation. In addition to that letter, the ambassadors have agreed to follow up by seeking appointments to ram home the message to key congressional leaders. I will be taking the opportunity to reinforce that message to the director-general of GATT, Peter Sutherland, when he visits Australia next week.

The other important issue before the seminar—it is more of a medium-term issue but relates to the same matter and is very important—is the early stage development of the 1995 US farm bill. The manner in which this bill evolves will be critical to all the Cairns Group participants and, in Australia, critical to Australian agricultural trade to the United States and as a model for what might happen in other important markets. It is of direct relevance to Australian agricultural exporters, particularly sugar, dairy and beef exporters. It is also significant in terms of its impact on the international agricultural market and export prices. It is important to note that in drafting the farm bill the US will be bound by the undertakings it made in the Uruguay Round to reduce agricultural protection. So there is a plus for us, but we must watch the way in which these decisions are implemented.

In recognition of the longer term significance of the 1990 farm bill for Australian agricultural exporters, Senator Collins and I have set up with farm leaders a farm bill working group—a government and industry group—to coordinate Australia's activity to maximise our chances of getting a decent farm bill outcome in the United States. We will be meeting again in November to assess the prospects for the bill, consider the debate and look at how we can maximise our impact on this important piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. We welcome the extensive range of assistance measures announced yesterday for farmers in Queensland and New South Wales who are suffering from exceptional circumstances due to four years of drought. However, farmers in many other parts of Australia, particularly South Australia and Victoria, are also suffering from exceptional circumstances, caused not only by lack of rain but by years of other calamities such as mouse plagues, frosts and rain during harvests. We can add to that low commodity prices as well as high interest rates. I ask the minister whether there will be any additional assistance for farmers in other parts of Australia suffering from exceptional circumstances who have little or no income. In South Australia in particular we are watching pastures and crops die, and dams empty—indeed, just this week we saw tens of thousands of sheep being trucked off properties in the west. How long will these farmers have to wait for assistance?

—I would hope, and I think most of the major farm organisations would hope, that they would never qualify for this assistance. I hope that that does not happen. I have actually seen expressions used such as `select group' which, I must say, I was extremely disappointed to see. People are in this `select group' because they have, as Senator Lees has said quite correctly, been droughted now for four years on the trot. The significance is that these are not marginal lands I am talking about. These are areas that for years have been renowned as Australia's most arable lands. In the Darling Downs of Queensland farmers have now suffered their eighth or ninth successive crop loss. They have had no income at all for four years.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Crowley said correctly, the criteria for this package apply nationally. I hope there would not be too many more joining. I am sure the present members of this group would be happy to opt out of it tomorrow. As I said, I am sure there is not a farmer in Australia who would not exchange every dollar of what has to be inadequate government support. Even if we put in a billion dollars, it would be inadequate. What farmers actually want is some good seasons and some decent rain.

The criteria do apply across Australia nationally and that is one of the most significant parts of the package announced yesterday. The whole point is, as I said yesterday, that if the drought does not break as is predicted by February or March next year, which could by then involve other areas of Australia, at that stage the whole country will be in diabolical trouble. There will be a major domestic crisis should we go past next autumn without any rain. We are all hopeful that the meteorology bureau will prove to be correct, as long away as that time is, and that rain will come.

I have convened a meeting for tomorrow of primary industry ministers. I had a meeting several weeks ago with the South Australian minister, Dale Baker, who approached me to ask whether the Commonwealth would give consideration to the rural adjustment scheme on a regional basis. I told him that not only would we do that but that it was also very much in accord with my own thinking and I was keen to regionalise as many of the Commonwealth programs across-the-board as possible.

We have demonstrated that in a very tangible way in the short time I have been in this portfolio, with a $9 million package for restructuring that we put into south-west Queensland. We offered a similar package to New South Wales, because the problem goes across that artificial border in the western division of New South Wales where restructuring is needed. The reason I raise that is that there are extensive areas of Australia where one of the fundamental problems, exacerbated by drought, is that major restructuring is required.

Decisions were taken generations ago by previous governments about the particular viability of certain blocks, which decisions we know were wrong. Sadly, there are a number of farmers around Australia who will never be viable if they have 20 good seasons. I can assure Senator Lees that, if farmers in South Australia should end up in the same unhappy state as the farmers are in northern New South Wales and Queensland who have suffered extensive years of drought, then under this package, the criteria of which are uniform across this country, they will receive assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister saying that, because the farmers in South Australia have had no income for three years for other reasons, he does not consider that they are therefore suffering from exceptional circumstances? To give an example: in the Wudinna area it has been three years since there has been a profitable crop harvested. They trucked 26,000 sheep out of there on Tuesday alone. Just at the time wool prices are increasing, they have had to get rid of the sheep—the very things that may have indeed saved them on those properties. Is this one of those areas that the minister is suggesting farmers should be phased out of? If he is saying that some of these areas should have farming phased out, then perhaps we should tell the farmers about that. What specific plans does he have to assist these farmers in South Australia, most of whom have totally used up their RAS entitlements?

—I do not think there are too many farmers around Australia who would argue with the central thrust of this proposal, which is to give this substantial package of assistance to the worst hit farmers. It is a drought package. I happily acknowledge that we are not in a position, nor will we ever be, to offer compensation for the myriad problems—mice plagues, frost, too much rain and other things—that a primary producer faces, including the ones Senator Lees has mentioned. We cannot. That is why this package has been identified as a drought package.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying—and I am delighted to have this piece of information—that today Premier Goss has publicly committed the Queensland government to match $20 million so that the funding we have provided in the exceptional circumstances grants will be matched by the Queensland government—Senator Boswell will be pleased to hear this—dollar for dollar to allow farmers in that state to get 100 per cent interest subsidies when they need them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I draw the minister's attention to the fact that the federal government's campaign to attract corporate regional headquarters to Australia has been recognised by an international award this week which was accepted by our ambassador to the Netherlands, Michael Tate. Given the emphasis placed by the government on the regional headquarters program in the May white paper, and the significant economic and cultural benefits that the regional headquarters can bring to this country, can the minister inform the Senate of the nature of the award and the stimulus that the award might bring to the regional headquarters campaign?

—It is indeed a very great honour for Australia that this week the Australian government received the best campaign award for excellence in 1994. The award gives international recognition to the government's campaign to attract regional headquarters to Australia. Our ambassador to The Hague, former senator the Hon. Michael Tate, did the honours by accepting this award for Australia at the Grand Hotel, Amsterdam, on Tuesday evening.

PARA.TAB: The best campaign award for excellence for 1994 was made at the fifth annual meeting of the Investment Promotion Agencies by Corporate Location, the international investment advisory arm of the Euromoney publication. It is an award for the best campaign mounted, and our campaign that attracted the award was for regional headquarters.

It is worth while remarking that, while the campaign attracted the award, the product that the campaign was selling is the Australian economy and the opportunity for foreign companies to set up regional headquarters in Australia. The Australian economy ought to take the bow here rather than the actual campaign to sell it.

I congratulate all those in my department who worked on this campaign. They have worked together with Austrade and the state and territory governments on a very targeted campaign to attract strategic investment to Australia. There are now more than 650 potential international targets that have been identified as companies that might establish regional headquarters in Australia. These companies are being systematically approached and introduced to Australia as an excellent business location for them.

I should also say that the efforts of the government sector have been strongly supported by the private sector. The regional headquarters leaders network is a group of some 20 key chief executives supported by the Australian Coalition of Service Industries. They have worked closely with us in a public/private sector push to join forces and represent Australia and succeed in winning a number of major companies to locate here.

Over recent months the numbers of companies deciding to locate their regional headquarters in Australia have increased. Let me name a number that have made the choice: Cathay Pacific is one; two major computer companies, Lexmark and Data General; the French international hotel chain, Accor; Novell and IBM—two other computer companies; Edelman, a public relations company; Hella, a company that manufactures headlights; the Campbell soup company; the Guangzhou Television company; and Oracle Computer. In fact, 23 multinational companies have established regional headquarters in Australia over the last 12 months. The best estimate is that regional headquarters have generated about $500 million in investment and about 1,000 jobs, as well as bringing major investment in information technology in particular to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins. The issue of easing eligibility criteria for the rural adjustment scheme for those without off-farm assets was not addressed by yesterday's drought statement; yet it is a major problem stopping many farmers from getting essential assistance to see them through the drought and beyond. Will the minister give a guarantee that the issue of eligibility will be sorted out in the next week or so? The minister does not seem to understand the question.
—No. Just tighten up the end of it.
—The question of drought eligibility under RAS is very hard to access because of criteria. Is the minister going to lower the criteria bar?

—A couple of significant policy changes that were made in yesterday's drought package involved providing significant additional resources into RAS in order to get more farmers into it. I think that is the bottom line. They are brought in by the eligibility criteria. That is going to be done in exceptional circumstances. I might add, for Senator Boswell's benefit, that one of the major problems we have identified over the last six months in the scheme in terms of access is that there are about 10,000 to 12,000 farmers out of a total of 125,000 in Australia who are in this serious situation.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, there are farmers in that group who will need access to rural adjustment assistance and who will now get it. Among the other identified problems raised with us was the restriction on the actual limits of the amount that could be borrowed. People who had borrowed to the limit and were still able, because of the very valuable nature of the basic asset, to borrow more could not do so because of the existing restriction on the caps. A major problem was that people who should have been getting 100 per cent subsidy—in other words, an interest free loan—were not getting it. One of the reasons for that, frankly, is that the scheme works in such a way that we fund the lion's share of it up to 50 per cent—90 per cent is provided by the Commonwealth—and over 50 per cent, not unreasonably, the states have to match us dollar for dollar. There has been some reluctance, and that is why I read out the statement from Premier Goss that I was delighted to see.

I do not want to indulge in any politicking on this because that is not how I handle it, but the facts were that, a couple of years ago when this happened, Queensland agreed to match us dollar for dollar. It was very aggravating for those farmers in northern New South Wales when farmers on the other side of the border were getting 100 per cent interest subsidies and they were not. We were putting our share in but the New South Wales government refused to match us dollar for dollar—there was plenty of rhetoric but no action. I hope that will change tomorrow at this meeting.

I am delighted to see a public commitment today from the Premier of Queensland—that state has been doing it; and he made the point in his press release that his state is the only state that is doing it—to put an additional $20 million into this desperate problem to help the Queensland farmers get that 100 per cent subsidy. So the caps have been raised on RAS to allow people to borrow more. More money has been put into exceptional circumstances to make it now a demand driven system rather than a cash limited system—a major breakthrough.

I conclude by saying that these are substantial policy changes which will require something like seven acts of parliament to be amended in this Senate, and I look forward to their being given a speedy passage. I hope that we do not have another Mabo debate, a gays in Tasmania debate or a land fund debate because, if we do, I have no doubt those opposite will be beaten to death by farmers in both northern New South Wales and Queensland. I will make my contribution to this by not speaking for more than five minutes on each bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Promise?
—Absolutely! Cross my heart and hope to die. Put the clock on me! Perhaps those opposite can give these bills speedy assistance—
—You promised to resign years ago.

—The sooner you get the better. I look forward to seeing these amendments passed speedily through the Senate so that this desperately needed assistance for the farmers in Queensland and New South Wales can be delivered.
—You're always promising to leave us.
—And a fat lot of good Senator Macdonald has been. He has not made a single representation to me on behalf of drought affected farmers in North Queensland—not one! (Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think I can give the minister a guarantee, an assurance, that the bills will not be held up unduly. In his answer the minister indicated that the criteria situation would be addressed but he was not specific in telling the Senate when he would do so.

—I have actually said it about 500 times on the public record over the last three or four weeks: we are doing it now. I can assure Senator Boswell that we will give it expeditious treatment. Once again, as I have done before, I commend Senator Boswell on his assiduous efforts on behalf of the farmers of North Queensland. Of course, he needs to be particularly active, considering that some of his other colleagues from North Queensland, like Senator Ian Macdonald, have been totally silent on the issue.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Has the Attorney-General received, over the last 12 months, repeated suggestions from the Australian Law Reform Commission that the minister refer gay and lesbian law reform to the commission for inquiry? Why has the Attorney-General not referred the matter of gay and lesbian law reform to the commission for inquiry, despite strong support from gay and lesbian groups around Australia? Does the Attorney-General intend to make such a referral and if not, why not?

—I am informed that the Attorney-General has received a submission from the new head of the Australian Law Reform Commission, Mr Alan Rose, outlining a number of inquiries which the Law Reform Commission may wish to undertake over the next year. The Law Reform Commission has nominated 16 topics for potential inquiries, covering the whole range of human rights, social justice, business and public law. The protection of individual rights, which would, of course, encompass the rights of all Australians regardless of sexual preference, is indeed one of the topics under consideration. I understand that the Attorney-General is yet to have discussions with Mr Rose to finalise the program, but I will bring Senator Chamarette's question to his attention so that he knows of her interest in the matter.
