PARA.TAB: I am certainly glad that the Greens do clearly understand the nature of the issues of principle involved in gay and lesbian law reform and, in particular, that they so obviously share the government's view—and the view of the overwhelming majority of Australians—that governments have no business whatever in anyone's bedroom and that sexual practices between consenting adults are entirely, and should remain entirely, their own business. In that respect, there is a conspicuous contrast to be drawn between the Greens' position, our position and the position of that once great party and once great coalition opposite, which manifestly fails to understand the basic issues that are here involved and which is presently divided. There is a large slice of them who regard the issues involved in the current government legislation, for example, as all about sodomy and other ways of encouraging godlessness; there is another group which argues that it is all about states rights; there is another small group of crazed eccentrics like Wilson Tuckey who say it is about genital mutilation; and there are only a tiny handful who understand that it is about—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I think the Leader of the Government in the Senate made a serious reflection on a member of the other house and he should withdraw it.
—I am sorry, I was not paying close attention. I ask Senator Gareth Evans to withdraw if he made such a reference.

—I withdraw the reference to Wilson Tuckey as a crazed eccentric, if that is a problem for Senator Panizza. This morning members of the shadow cabinet may have purported to do something about patching up their differences on this particular matter, but I understand the issue is still a live one right now in the party room. I am sure it will be the case that like a worm cut into two, three, four or more different pieces we are going to see the different bits writhing in the public on this issue as on so many others over the period ahead. It is a very tragic thing to see this once great party sacrificing and throwing away any shred of decency in its fundamental principles in this respect.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not think it would have escaped the notice of the opposition that the minister did not actually answer my question but took the opportunity to make a few cracks. I would like to repeat the question, which is: what priority does the Attorney-General place on the Law Reform Commission's request for a referral and when is that priority likely to be given?

—The Attorney-General is a deeply caring, sensitive and compassionate soul—as we are all aware—who does understand the nature of the issues that are involved in gay and lesbian law reform, as Senator Chamarette so obviously does. I am sure he will take that particular area very seriously into account in discussing with Mr Rose the priority areas of reference for the Law Reform Commission. But I cannot pre-empt his judgment on that. He has not yet had an opportunity to discuss the matter in detail with Mr Rose.
—My question without notice is directed the Minister for Foreign Affairs. How much longer is the minister going to tolerate that grossly insulting sign outside the Indonesian embassy in Canberra?
—I am not aware of the particular sign to which Senator MacGibbon is referring. Is he referring to the Timor embassy thing across the road?
—The East Timorese sign.

—I am not sure of the particular sign to which Senator MacGibbon is referring. In any event, these matters are essentially ones for the ACT administration rather than the federal government. There is a capacity for the government to act, as it has done in the past, in relation to certain things that constitute—I have forgotten the precise language of the statute—an interference, in effect, with the effective capacity of the mission to operate in terms of our responsibilities under the Vienna convention. I am not sure of the particular thing to which Senator MacGibbon is referring, but I do not think it is the case that there would be a foundation on which we could act in this respect at the moment.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I suppose I should not be surprised that the minister does not know what is outside the Indonesian embassy. But it is absolutely intolerable for a party that proclaims it is doing something to promote Australian-Indonesian relations to tolerate a huge multicoloured sign that has been in front of the embassy of a friendly nation for a long while. I would like the minister to instance how many embassies Australia has around the world which are subject to similar treatment. I would like the minister to name me the countries and tell me the number of Australian embassies that are similarly outraged.

—Mr President, while it is the case that we take the view that protests should remain within the bounds of the law and should also remain within the bounds of decent respect for property, for national symbols and for differing cultures and countries with which we might have differing points of view, it is the case that we continue to acknowledge the right of peaceful demonstration as a very valued and core part of our system of democracy and freedom of expression.

PARA.TAB: I am constantly in the position of having to live with situations that might desirably not exist in dealing with countries and issues of this sensitive kind. But over and over again I simply have to make the point that in the kind of democracy that we are, that is part of the deal—to tolerate that diversity, to tolerate that freedom of expression. I think that is pretty well understood by the countries in question. I am sure it is well understood by the Indonesian government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. It concerns Commonwealth education programs in Victoria. Is the minister aware of media reports, based upon a leaked state government briefing paper, that the Victorian education department has a budget blow-out of $143 million? Is the minister aware that the state government has already cut the education budget by $78 million this year, which follows extremely large cuts over the last two years? Can the minister assure the Senate that Commonwealth education programs in Victoria will not be undermined by further cuts by the state government to Victorian schools, education programs, staff or facilities?

—Being a Victorian, Senator Carr's concern in raising this question is obvious. I am aware that there have been reports about the Kennett government in Victoria cutting back on education. Apparently the reports canvass possible further redundancies of up to 1,000 teachers, the apparently unknown effects on schooling of cuts already made and the use of statewide testing for public comparison between schools. Throughout this turmoil, the Victorian education system has closed more than 200 schools and reduced teacher numbers by 8,000. Despite this, the Commonwealth government—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Gareth Evans, in an earlier point of order, pointed out that answers should be given only to questions that relate to the responsibility of the respective minister. I ask you to find out what possible responsibility Senator Schacht and his colleagues have for education in Victoria. And I ask you to enforce the standing order that Senator Evans brought to your attention earlier today.

—Mr President, on the point of order, I do not think Senator Kemp heard. Senator Carr asked a general question about schools but then went on to ask how Commonwealth funding, which is very substantial in the Victorian or any other state education system, would be affected. The question was entirely in order.

—Mr President, on the point of order, if the issue is, as Senator Ray says, the issue of funding from the Commonwealth government, we have not had one word of that from Senator Schacht—not one word. If Senator Ray is right, if the issue is Commonwealth funding, let us get the answer to that question.

—Mr President, on the point of order, just as Senator Kemp was starting to get excited and jump up and down, I was starting to refer to the Commonwealth funding for Victoria. I was going to then go on and explain, as I will, the Commonwealth funding for education in Victoria.
—Order! The question was in order and so was the answer.

—As I was about to say before Senator Kemp jumped up—or should I say the `jumped-up Senator Kemp'—with his unnecessary point of order, in this present year the Commonwealth government has provided in Victoria $296 million, which is the maintenance of funding in real terms. This contrasts with the Victorian government making a cut of $78 million in real terms in 1994-95. We have maintained our funding to schools in Victoria. The Victorian government has cut its funding by $78 million.

PARA.TAB: Of course, we acknowledge that we are not about to tell state governments how to run their school systems, but there are two points about the policy and practice which I think should be made. Firstly, this highlights the critical need for all systems to develop adequate methods of reporting the outcomes of schooling. Most states are investing considerable time and money working towards ways of assessing and reporting learning and management outcomes. Apparently Mr Hayward, the Victorian education minister, believes this type of approach is `a lot of rubbish'. Debate about education should be about the quality of outcomes, not about the input of resources alone. For the sake of this state's students, I hope the Victorian government will come to terms with this and will follow the example of other states in this matter.

Secondly, it is quite clear that the outcome reporting should not be reliant on simple basic skill testing. What children are able to achieve as a result of their schooling is dependent upon the interaction of parents, the principals in schools, the teachers, the resources and the students themselves. To reduce the outcomes of schooling to a pen and paper test undermines the quality of our schools. Using a year's basic skill test to generate invidious comparisons between schools is really an attack on the whole process.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are truly pathetic. The Kirner government absolutely mucked up the system, and you know it.
—Of course, coming from an elite school system, the representative of Geelong Grammar—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp!
—Scotch College.
—Downer's fag over here from Scotch College—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask that you ask Senator Schacht to withdraw that comment about Senator Kemp.
—I did not see anything unparliamentary in it, unless there is something I missed. In the interests of Senate harmony, I ask you to withdraw the comment please, Senator.

—In the interests of Senate harmony, but I must say that the term `fag' is well known in the private school system of this country and in Great Britain, which these people opposite represent. In deference to your request, Mr President, I certainly withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: The opposition supports Mr Kennett's move to reduce the outcomes of schools, as I say, to a pen and paper test. We on this side of politics will not take such a simplistic approach to education policy as that lot opposite. Mr Kennett is going about in Victoria reducing the quality of education for ordinary students, not the ones those opposite represent in the private school system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and relates to visits by the Prime Minister of Ireland, Mr Reynolds, and the Prime Minister of Singapore, Mr Goh. In asking the question, I would like it noted that I am a former member of the executive of the Australia-Ireland parliamentary group. Why is it, though, that when Mr Reynolds visited Canberra the government chose to honour him with an official dinner in the Great Hall of Parliament House, yet when Mr Goh visited he was merely hosted to a private dinner at the Lodge? Given that I am advised that the Prime Minister's department made all of the arrangements for Mr Goh's visit, and they were presumably approved by the Prime Minister, can the minister provide an explanation for the differing treatment provided to these two international leaders?

—The only reason I am aware of why there was not a full-scale Great Hall dinner for Prime Minister Goh was that a non-parliamentary sitting week was the only week in which he could be here and the government, I think rather responsibly, took the view that it would be inappropriate to spend the enormous amount of taxpayers' money in sending the usual invitations to members of parliament and others to come from all around the country. It has often been the practice when distinguished visitors have been here otherwise than during parliamentary sitting weeks that other forms of hospitality have been offered.

PARA.TAB: I might set the record straight for Senator O'Chee. It was not only dinner at the Lodge that was offered for Prime Minister Goh. There was in fact a lunch in Parliament House, attended by a number of ministers and a number of other distinguished guests, for some 80 or 90 people, which was appropriately targeted for the nature of the occasion and the nature of the visitor in a circumstance where the parliament was not sitting.

Moreover, Senator O'Chee's own leader, Mr Fischer, seconded the Prime Minister's speech of welcome to Mr Goh, and in a speech of great dignity and great charm responded in a way that was absolutely appropriate for the occasion. He showed a lot more charm, a lot more dignity, a lot more sense and a lot better information than Senator O'Chee has demonstrated on this occasion.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the rabble over there on the government benches would like to keep quiet they might actually find out that I knew about the lunch as well and was not intending to raise the matter to save them a little bit of embarrassment. Is the minister aware that there is a need for a certain sensitivity because when quite apparently different treatment is offered to two ministers within the space of a couple of weeks it reduces all the Prime Minister's rhetoric about becoming closer and more in tune with Asia to just so much puff? That is the concern that I have. I believe the government could have handled it much better. There was not even an invitation delivered to most members of parliament, and that is a matter of concern. If this government wishes to treat a leader like Mr Goh with a little bit of respect, at least that could have been done.

—There is only one thing that could possibly embarrass Prime Minister Goh arising out of his visit to Australia and that is the contribution that Senator O'Chee has just made in this parliament. Goh Chok Tong is a man of the utmost distinction, the utmost character, and someone with whom the Prime Minister of Australia has a very close relationship indeed, both in policy terms and in personal terms. He is someone who has been a very strong supporter, and has acted jointly with us, in the initiatives for trade liberalisation and regional security and otherwise that we have been mounting around the region. I believe there are some relationships as close as our relationship with Singapore and our personal relationship at the prime ministerial level with Mr Goh Chok Tong, but there is no leader or no relationship in the region that I think is more close. For Senator O'Chee to make that kind of point in that kind of cheap grandstanding way is not only to totally misunderstand the nature of that particular relationship; it is to demonstrate that he just does not have the character to sit in this place.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I want that comment withdrawn, Mr President. That is thoroughly and utterly reprehensible and despicable. It shows the contempt that Senator Evans has for proper parliamentary process.
—Order! I think you should withdraw it, Senator Evans. It is a reflection on the senator.
—It is certainly a reflection. It was a very deliberate one but, in deference to you, Mr President, I will withdraw it.
—I did ask you to withdraw, and that meant an unconditional withdrawal.
—It was unconditional, but I will repeat it. I withdraw unconditionally.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to reports that clear-fell logging and woodchipping are imminent in the high conservation value Hensleigh Creek catchment in East Gippsland, which contains old-growth forests, which is listed on the register of the national estate and which is a state site of rainforest significance. Will the minister provide urgent interim protection for Hensleigh Creek catchment in order to conserve the area for inclusion in the national reserves system, and when will he do so? Secondly, given the recent Victorian government report exposing the extent of breaches by the timber industry of the Victorian code of forest practices, is the minister prepared to establish a Commonwealth monitoring function to ensure compliance with state codes and Commonwealth woodchip licence conditions?

—I have received a letter which has been co-signed by a number of Victorian voluntary conservation organisations expressing concern about the planned commencement of logging operations in the Hensleigh Creek catchment in East Gippsland. The conservation organisations have sent me further information on the conservation values of the area. This has been brought to my attention only this morning; my portfolio has not had the opportunity yet to evaluate this additional information.

PARA.TAB: The conservation organisations have been invited to provide my department with substantiated information on areas considered to have high conservation values. I am committed to implementing the national forest policy statement and I will be advising the Minister for Resources on areas likely to be of high conservation value, which should be avoided prior to the issuing of any export woodchip licences for next year. In line with the national forest policy statement, an assessment of whole growth forest has been completed for the East Gippsland forests. In addition, the Australian Heritage Commission is currently finalising a study of national estate values for forests in that area. These two studies put my portfolio in a good position to assess the information supplied by the conservation organisations.

In the interim, I have referred the letter I mentioned to the Minister for Resources for further investigation. My department will follow up the new information with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Once more, information has been provided to me by my department and the AHC. I will consider what further action might need to be taken in consultation with my colleague the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall.

Since becoming the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, one of my priorities has been to address the implementation of the national forest policy statement. It has certainly been reflected in the nature of the advice I gave to the Minister for Resources over the Sawmillers Export Pty Ltd—better known as SEPL—export licence. I also proposed to the minister that SEPL report annually on its woodchip export activities and that this particular mechanism be backed up by a monitoring capacity. My department has had preliminary discussions with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy concerning monitoring compliance with export licence conditions. Once those options have been further developed, which, of course, is a process that is continuing, then I certainly will be discussing those options further with Mr Beddall, the Minister for Resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, but seeing that the Hensleigh Creek issue is particularly urgent, can he give the Senate some indication of the time scale for responding to that particular aspect of the question?

—I can add very little to what I said to Senator Spindler. I had received some advice in relation to what was occurring and, as I mentioned, my office has received this morning further supporting evidence from some voluntary conservation organisations. I indicated in my answer to Senator Spindler that I would examine that advice as quickly as possible, and that is in train now. But I do stress to Senator Spindler that it literally has been made available and passed through to me only within the past few hours.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —A question was asked of Senator McMullan by Senator Watson on Tuesday concerning a recent draft taxation ruling on the investment and development allowances and the effect this will have on public infrastructure projects. I am informed it is on page 963 of Hansard.

PARA.TAB: I have obtained the following answer to this question from the Treasurer: taxation draft rulings represent the preliminary though considered views of the Commissioner for Taxation. Draft rulings are released publicly to allow a period of consultation before being finalised. The Commissioner has advised that the draft taxation ruling TR94/D37 does not represent a change to the approach of the Australian Taxation Office to the grant of rights to use property. The draft ruling is a consolidation with improved explanation of years of case law and of past public rulings by the Australian Taxation Office.

Granting rights to use an asset can preclude access to the investment allowance and the development allowance. That restriction has been part of such provisions since 1976 and is the subject of several public rulings by the Australian Taxation Office and of several reported decisions of courts and tribunals. The provisions of section 51AD also may be triggered by granting rights to use an asset to particular classes of taxpayer or for particular purposes. This provision has been in effect since 1982.

As the ATO has not changed its approach to the application of these provisions the commissioner said there were no cases of which he is aware where public infrastructure projects entered into on the basis of the ATO's approach would be prejudiced if the draft ruling became final without changing. If, in a particular case, a taxpayer has a private ruling from the ATO in respect of a particular arrangement, generally the taxpayer will be able to rely on that ruling for the year to which it relates, notwithstanding an inconsistent public ruling.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 September 1994 Senator Patterson asked me a question without notice regarding Strathdon Lodge, a dementia specific unit for aged care. I seek leave to have a further answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's policy recognises a wide range of approaches to the provision of dementia care, including special dementia units, and encompasses a diversity of aged care services and facilities for people with dementia.

The progressive nature of dementing illnesses, the uneven development and differing manifestations mean it is not possible to divide residents into two groups, one of which should be segregated from the other.
Research suggests that dementia specific services have not yet demonstrated any special value over dementia programs in mainstream services.

A wide range of other approaches are known to have a significant effect on improving the outcomes for residents. Research and "best practice" demonstration projects are being funded under the National Action Plan for Dementia Care to identify the efficacy of approaches such as more innovative care practice, carer training, environmental design, staff and community education.
Hostel funding levels have increased from $40 million to $310 million over ten years, recognising the provision of higher benefits for people with higher care needs, particularly those with dementia.

The 1991-92 budget provided additional funding of up to $15 million to hostels caring for people with high personal care needs. In addition the Government funded $30 million over five years for a National Action Plan for Dementia Care.

Some hostels which segregate people with more difficult care needs claim that this funding is inadequate to support their method of operation. There is evidence that other hostels with similar operational structures but different accounting and staffing approaches are operating viably.

To provide better information about the residential care needs of people with severe dementia and challenging behaviour, a research project is being undertaken to investigate the many care options. This project will identify those elements of care which are successful in meeting the needs of people with severe dementia and challenging behaviour.

The 1994-95 budget also allocated $12.4 million for psychogeriatric assessment and support, which includes top-up funding for periods of residential care of people with dementia and disruptive behaviour.

Strathdon Community is an aged care complex auspiced by the Uniting Church. The complex includes a 60 bed nursing home, a day therapy centre, 106 hostel places in total and 57 self-care units. Strathdon Lodge was constructed as a dementia specific unit within the hostel and offers 24 places.

Departmental officers have encouraged examination of other, viable, stand-alone dementia units to identify factors that make them viable and have had ongoing contact to explore with Strathdon ways of helping with the problems identified for example by treating the whole facility as a single cost centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation under standing order 190.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Senator Schacht's answer there was a very unpleasant—
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is it a personal explanation on the basis of claiming to have been misrepresented?
—Under standing order 190, that is the provision.

—During the answer from Senator Schacht there was a very unpleasant attack on all people who attended private schools. I would like to defend the many hundreds of thousands of Australians who go to private schools. I point out to Senator Schacht that the children of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, go to private schools. Senator Evans's children have gone to private schools. Indeed, large numbers of people on the frontbench have sent their children to private schools. I ask him on the next day of sitting to supply information to the Senate on the number of Labor ministers who have sent their children to private schools.
—That was a fairly dubious personal explanation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not in any way attack all people who attended private schools. I was talking about those opposite, some of whom attended private schools. The interests they represent seem always to promote the interests of the rich schools vis-a-vis the rest. That is the point I was making.
—Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht referred to my colleagues and me, describing us as representatives of the private school system. That is an exact quote; I took it down. I was educated entirely by the state school system, as were many of my colleagues. It is simply incorrect to classify me as such, although maybe I might have preferred—who knows?—had I had the opportunity, to go to a private school.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that a large proportion of members on this side had the benefit of a state school education. I am proud of that education. Not only was I educated by the state school system; I attended North Sydney Boys High School. Many of my colleagues attended similar schools. It is divisive and a case of trying to generate class consciousness, which is totally unacceptable. For Senator Schacht to behave in this way demeans the parliamentary process and, what is more, it demeans him, if that is possible.
