SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Lees this day, relating to the recently announced drought relief package.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) had to leave the chamber, but he did give me the courtesy of saying that he was sorry that he could not stay. I know that the minister and certainly all senators on this side would be well aware by now that the measures announced yesterday by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with regard to drought specifically exclude South Australia because that state is currently unable to declare drought in affected regional areas.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister said that in his approach to the problem of exceptional drought circumstances he was fulfilling his commitment not to leave behind farm families which were in distressed circumstances. I know that is what he said in his statement, but I am wondering how he can explain that statement to a large majority of South Australian farmers, particularly to those on the Eyre Peninsula and in the Murray Mallee, who are seriously drought affected and who will continue to suffer unless funds are provided urgently.

The Australian Democrats often feign some interest in rural affairs. I was interested to note that when Senator Lees asked this question she mentioned that truck loads of sheep had left Wudinna to be taken to the markets—some 26,000 having left the area. If the Democrats had their way, their policy at the last election being to add an extra 18c a litre to fuel, would those farmers have been able to afford to send those sheep to market?

I know the problem is that drought cannot be declared in a regional affected area. Two weeks ago Senator Collins agreed to a request from the South Australian Minister for Primary Industries to accept scientifically based criteria for the declaration of drought within regions of that state. I understand that the scientifically based criteria were forwarded to our Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Prime Minister at lunchtime today. I understand that these criteria, once received, could be used to trigger regional drought declarations in South Australia. I know that a process does have to be gone through before that can happen, but I would hope that Senator Lees and the Democrats—

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the problems is that it hasn't been declared in South Australia.

—There are regions affected in South Australia and this measure needs to be put in place so those regions—not the whole state—can be declared drought affected. I hope that Senator Lees and the Democrats will immediately support the actions of the South Australian Liberal government, and certainly support the actions of coalition senators in this place, when it comes to the time for this trigger to be put into place, because it is absolutely essential that people in South Australian regions be helped.

PARA.TAB: Because of the diversity of South Australia it is very rare for the whole of the state to be in a drought situation, but there are many large areas of South Australia that have been suffering adverse conditions for a number of years. On the northern Eyre Peninsula and in parts of the Murray Mallee there are people who will not get a crop this year. I will be going to visit that area next week. There need to be special circumstances for areas such as this—and they are very large areas and very large grain-producing areas.

One of the problems we seem to face is that the only way an area can be declared a drought area or the only way any assistance can be provided is for the Prime Minister to visit. It has taken months and months for the Prime Minister to be dragged into the areas of New South Wales and Queensland where the drought has been so severe for so long. I would have thought that, with all that has been said in this chamber and in the public arena regarding the drought in northern New South Wales and Queensland, a visit would have been paid to these areas by the Prime Minister far sooner than this. It does not seem to take much effort to get the Prime Minister to visit areas affected by bushfires or floods. We have a prolonged serious situation, and have had for a number of years, in many parts of South Australia as well as those areas in northern New South Wales and Queensland that have suffered so much.

I hope that relief measures can be made available particularly to those farm families which are suffering so greatly in many parts of South Australia. I certainly urge the federal government to do what it has to do to act as quickly as possible now that these criteria have been forwarded to it, so that the current suffering of these people in such adverse conditions can be put right in the same way that many people in the rest of Australia have benefited from drought assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate too long. At about 20 minutes past seven this morning I was appalled to hear the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) on the Alan Jones breakfast program on 2UE take what was a blatant and cheap political shot by saying he hoped that coalition senators would not delay the passage through the Senate of the seven acts, I think it is, that require amendment to implement the drought package. I thought it was a very cheap shot.

PARA.TAB: I happened to be on the program straight after Senator Collins explaining to Alan Jones and a not inconsiderable listening audience about the money that the government has wasted in its various failed business dealings through DAS. I was going to go across to Senator Collins during question time and say that I thought it was a cheap shot and that, even though he was talking on Sydney radio and we were all in Canberra, we had actually caught him out.

The coalition, as you know, Mr Deputy President, has been very pro-active on the issue of coming up with a broad ranging drought package, which was announced many weeks ago. There is no doubt that we all welcome the government's commitment to the drought package. Certainly it was a belated package but one that we no doubt welcome anyway.

It was even more surprising, I thought, for Minister Collins—even though he takes the cheap political shot whenever he can—to repeat what he said on the radio this morning in the parliament this afternoon. The coalition understands very well the plight of those who are stricken by drought right around Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —And have understood it for years.

—And have understood it, I am sure, far better than the Prime Minister, specifically, for many years, as Senator Ferguson quite correctly interjects. If Senator Collins wants to score cheap political points on radio programs, that is not the way to handle what is a national crisis that has the potential of ruining the lives of thousands of Australians right across this nation, be they the people who suffer because they are on the land and suffering the consequences of the drought or other citizens right around this nation whose own economic wellbeing and living standards will be affected by a continuation of this national disaster by way of the drought.

—I welcome the package that the government has brought down to assist the farmers suffering in the drought. But, while doing so, I question where exactly that assistance is to go. It seems to me that the problem is in how we define extreme drought. I know that the RAS has a way of describing or defining it, but I do not really know how many people have really understood it and worked out who is able to get the assistance.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned this morning that the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia is in financial difficulties. When it comes to the families in that area putting bread on the table, they could be in exactly the same situation as people in New South Wales, Queensland and parts of Victoria. The government has to tell us what it is going to do for them. As I mentioned yesterday, the Esperance area, in the south-east region of Western Australia, is in a pretty bad way this year, even though it had a reasonable year last year. As Senator Ferguson mentioned, the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia could be in the same situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Mallee.
—And the Mallee in Victoria; that is correct.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chapman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely it does not stop at the border. Droughts do not follow borders. I welcome the measures in relation to social security because it gets to the core of the family. I also welcome the Austudy measures. There is quite a push to change the RAS guidelines to make finance more easily available. I caution the Senate on that because I saw the experiences in Western Australia of the 1976-77 droughts and the 1983 drought. The money got the farmers into more strife than it got them out of because it was too easily available.

PARA.TAB: I believe in the RAS system, as long as it is administered properly. I have always said that it was not administered properly in Western Australia for the reasons I have mentioned. There were deserving farmers who were going to be viable in the long run. They were not helped. There were others helped who were not going to be viable in the long run and the money helped those farmers to go over the line completely. The ones who battled for themselves got there in the long run and are solid now. So I caution the Senate on moving too far down that line.

We have to look forward to when this drought is over. The government has to put measures in place to make sure that resources are built up and made available to farmers when this drought finishes because, as sure as we are on this Earth, there will be another drought somewhere at another time. We have to work towards that time by that conserving fodder and cash.

The government has mentioned in the release on drought that it is looking at an investment allowance for building storage and extra dams for water. I do not think that will provide too much help to farmers who are coming out of the drought. For at least four or five years they will have low incomes. What is the point of allowing a further investment allowance if they do not have any income to pay tax on? So that allowance does not mean much.

The government has to look at putting back in place the sorts of IEDs we had under the Fraser government. They used to work all right. A massive amount was available and used, including during the 1982 drought in the east and the 1983 drought in the west. The IEDs become very useful. Unfortunately, Peter Walsh, a friend of mine who used to be on the other side of the chamber, reckoned that they were being rorted. I could not see where they were being rorted. The system was changed and the fund total dropped from about $300 million to about $50 million or $60 million. So the fund is useless as it stands and I ask the government to bring the total back to where it used to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to join Senator Ferguson in expressing my great concern and disappointment that the drought relief package announced yesterday does not, as the situation currently stands in South Australia, apply to those farmers on the Eyre Peninsula and in the Murray Mallee of South Australia, who are suffering the devastating impact of drought at this stage of the season. The reason for that is that in South Australia there are no criteria whereby the concept of extreme drought can be determined to enable the relief package to apply to farmers in that state.

PARA.TAB: The blame for that lies fairly and squarely with the Labor Party because for a decade in South Australia we had a Labor government that paid scant regard to the needs of the rural people of South Australia. That scant regard is no better demonstrated than by the fact that during that long period in office it failed to put in place appropriate criteria whereby extreme drought could have been recognised when it struck. So we now have a drought package, announced last night, that will not be applicable to those farmers in South Australia.

To his great credit, the Minister for Primary Industries in the new Liberal government in South Australia, Dale Baker, has been working assiduously to develop appropriate criteria which might be acceptable to and recognised by the federal government. He will be putting those propositions to the federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, at a meeting tomorrow.

The proposal will be that there be specific scientifically based criteria whereupon South Australian farmers could trigger the exceptional drought circumstances and thereby benefit from the package that was announced last night. It remains for me, along with Senator Ferguson, to urge Senator Collins in the strongest possible terms to give very favourable consideration to the proposals that Dale Baker will be arguing before him tomorrow.

Unless those criteria are accepted, South Australian farmers—who are suffering equally with farmers in other states from the devastating effects of drought this year—will be left high and dry. Contrary to the claim of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he visited rural areas a couple of weeks ago, which claim he reaffirmed yesterday in announcing this drought package, the farmers in South Australia will be left behind unless these very worthwhile criteria which Dale Baker and his departmental officials have worked hard to develop are accepted—criteria which they have worked hard to develop in the face of years of neglect by the Labor government that was thrown out of office at the end of last year. They are viable criteria, and I can only urge Senator Collins to accept them, to ensure that South Australian farmers obtain this much needed relief.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Carr this day, relating to education in the state of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a great disappointment to me that the minister's answer was so misunderstood by those opposite who have raised questions concerning private schools. The issue at the heart of this matter was the effect on the state education system in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it is understood just how severe the changes to education have been in the state that I represent. I do not think it is understood what sort of impact the cuts and disruptions that have occurred in Victoria are having on Commonwealth education programs.

In the last two years we have seen some 230 schools close—a very large number of schools. We have seen teaching numbers reduced by about 8,000—8,000 teachers taken out of the education system in one state. We have seen a decline of some 7,000 in the number of students attending school. We have seen cuts of $370 million.

All that has a very dramatic impact on the quality of education outcomes in the school system. As far as the Commonwealth is concerned, the prime objective of its educational support programs is to supplement state school funding so as to provide equality of opportunity for students right across Australia.

The Commonwealth currently provides nearly $300 million for education in Victoria. My grave concern is that, as we move increasingly to global budgets for individual schools at a state level and as we move towards greater devolution of educational authority in the states, we are likely to see the substitution of Commonwealth funds for state funds where cuts are occurring.

This model has an impact on the quality of services that are available for the education of students right across Australia. The issue that arises is whether or not state government attacks on education ultimately undermine the educational objectives of the Commonwealth government. That to me is a very important matter.

Ultimately, it will be seen as an extremely important matter for this whole country. In Australian education we are placing increasing emphasis on the development of skills necessary for a flexible and mature work force. One cannot have that while simultaneously undermining the very foundations of the education system in this country. The importance of this matter is that the model that is being expressed in Victoria is now being copied in South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania. The Commonwealth spends nearly $3 billion a year on schools programs. If this sort of pattern of behaviour is allowed to continue where state governments undermine national programs, we will be entitled to ask whether or not very large sums of money are being put at risk through the service provided to young people in this country. Ultimately, such an attack on education will impact on the economy as a whole. So, for this reason, I am very concerned.

Mr Kennett in Victoria has indicated that the basis of this report was a device whereby a high jump bar was established to make sure that scenarios are put to each minister in each department so that they remain focused on the overall objectives. If this is a question of a high jump bar to keep ministers focused, I am concerned, ultimately, whether we are entitled to ask, how long it will be before Mr Hayward, the Victorian education minister, is up for the high jump himself.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator MacGibbon this day, relating to the Indonesian Embassy in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it very hard to believe that, as conscientious and as diligent a minister as Senator Gareth Evans is—and I mean that quite sincerely—in the discharge of his duty, he has not visited the major embassies many times in this capital city of Canberra. In fact, I would have thought he would have visited all embassies.

PARA.TAB: But, putting that aside, we have a grossly offensive sign about East Timor that has been across the road for quite a long while in front of the Indonesian Embassy. To argue that somehow or other the Indonesians have to put up with the most robust elements of Australian society and at the same time argue for the development of good Australian-Indonesian relations is to show that the minister knows nothing at all about Indonesia. The sensitivity, the obliqueness of dealing with the Javanese, the dominant culture in Indonesia, is as remote as possible from the bar room behaviour of parts of Australia. It requires tact, sensitivity and respect for their position, and this sign to them is grossly offensive. Furthermore, it does not reflect Australia's official foreign policy. Australia's foreign policy is to support or recognise the incorporation of East Timor into Indonesia.

My main concern about it relates to the weaseling answer that the minister gave, saying in effect, `This is a democracy; you have to like it or lump it.' This is not a libertarian society—people do not have a licence to behave as they see fit. They certainly have a right to freedom of assembly, freedom of association, freedom of speech. All of those things are not transgressed or denied, though, by good manners. We have here a permanent insult—not a transient one like a group meeting outside the gates of an embassy demonstrating a point of view. What we have here is deeply offensive to the Indonesians and it is deeply offensive to me as an Australian. Because we have emissaries in this country, the representatives of other powers, other nations, we have an obligation to treat them courteously, not discourteously in the way we are treating the Indonesians at the present time and have treated them for quite a long time.

I would ask the minister to really consider his position quite carefully. If he is sincere in his aim to develop better relations between Australia and Indonesia, the very first thing he will do is improve the manners of the host country and get rid of gratuitous insults like that East Timor sign.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point that Senator MacGibbon raised is very important, and many of the things that he said are true. On the other hand, if we are in a robust democratic society, I ask Senator MacGibbon where are we going to stop? If we stop people expressing views that we do not like or if we stop people expressing views that we think our friends overseas might dislike—and with good cause in this case—where will it end?

PARA.TAB: The fact is that we are one of the world's most robust democracies. We are a true democracy. Once we stop people expressing themselves and saying what they want, we are in trouble. If we are a democracy, we cannot move to deny people the right to say things that we or others might not like.

I will paraphrase the great statement that is quoted again and again: I might not like what you say, but I will give my life to defend your right to say it. If we forget that, we start going backwards as a democracy. I sympathise with the sorts of things that Senator MacGibbon said. On the other hand, if we go down the line that he is suggesting, we start diminishing those freedoms that we so much cherish in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on 19 September 1994 in relation to the determination of the President that a motion relating to a matter of privilege raised by Senator Vanstone should not have precedence under standing order 81, Senator Vanstone invited the President to reconsider his determination. He has since done that, and I incorporate his statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: The document read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: MATTER OF PRIVILEGE RAISED BY SENATOR VANSTONE

In speaking on 19 September 1994 in relation to my determination that a motion relating to a matter of privilege raised by Senator Vanstone should not have precedence under standing order 81, Senator Vanstone invited me to reconsider my determination.

The basis of my determination was that the matter raised by Senator Vanstone involved an allegation that the Chairman of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, Mr Cleeland, had made unauthorised disclosures of the Committee's deliberations and false and misleading reports of the Committee's proceedings, and such an allegation could not be the subject of inquiry or action by the Senate, but could only be examined and dealt with by the House of Representatives. I drew attention to a very similar case in 1988 in which my predecessor made a similar determination.

Senator Vanstone suggested that my determination involved a presumption that Mr Cleeland was responsible for the alleged unauthorised disclosure and false and misleading reports, whereas inquiries may reveal that Mr Cleeland was not responsible for the disclosures or the reports.
I dealt with this point my initial statement, when I said:

. . . it is clear that it is the chairman of the Committee, Mr Cleeland, who stands accused of making the unauthorised disclosures of Committee deliberations and of giving the false and misleading accounts of the Committee's proceedings.
While it is theoretically possible that the journalist concerned falsely claimed Mr Cleeland as his source, Senator Vanstone's letter makes it clear that this is not the case.

It is clear that the matter raised by Senator Vanstone involves an allegation against Mr Cleeland. The press reports referred to by Senator Vanstone quote Mr Cleeland as their source. Senator Vanstone's letter, which I tabled in the Senate, indicates that the Committee had already, as she put it, admonished Mr Cleeland in relation to the alleged unauthorised disclosures. In order to conduct an inquiry, the Privileges Committee would have to question the journalists concerned and Mr Cleeland as to whether Mr Cleeland was their source. As I said in my determination, therefore, it is inevitable that any inquiry by the Senate Privileges Committee would be an inquiry into the conduct of Mr Cleeland.

Contrary to the suggestion made by Senator Vanstone at the end of her speech, my determination was not based on any presumption that Mr Cleeland had actually engaged in the conduct alleged, but simply that the matter raised by Senator Vanstone would clearly involve an investigation of whether Mr Cleeland had engaged in such conduct.
I therefore see no reason to alter my earlier determination, in accordance with precedent, that a motion relating to this matter should not have precedence under standing order 81.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Knowles proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: In light of statements made by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women the Senate notes the hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party policy of quotas to get more women into Parliament while recent pre-selection results demonstrate the reverse.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that the Labor Party has got an intended quota system for female parliamentarians is a matter of great concern to the coalition. This will be the way in which its numbers are bolstered in the future, because it goes nowhere to removing the barriers which presently block or limit the entry of women into the parliament, and it may work to create reverse discrimination against male candidates.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that over the past few months, while this system has been debated within the Labor Party, the figure started at 50 per cent, it was dropped to 40 per cent, it has now dropped to 35 per cent, and the Labor Party still cannot decide how it will deliver such a quota system by the year 2002. Originally, it was going to be brought forward even further than that. It is amazing that someone like Dr Lawrence can lower her ideals so much that she needs to indulge in tokenism and belittle the role that women can play within the parliament.

The Senate does note the hypocrisy of the Labor Party on this issue and the terms of the mismatch of rhetoric and record. While the party has been arguing about affirmative action since 1981, it has still not done anything whatsoever to improve the situation. This is the Labor Party that for some 13 years has been talking about affirmative action and, on its track record, it has gone in the opposite direction in many cases.

For example, the coalition government of New South Wales has three female ministers. Why does the Labor Party not take an example being set without quotas? Why does it not have more female ministers? Why does it not bring more female ministers into this federal parliament? Why does it not have more female ministers in the Queensland government? It is purely and simply because it needs to have the quotas to do it. It does not just do it on its own behalf; it has to have quotas.

In the Western Australian Legislative Council, for example, the Labor Party had five female members; it now has two. It is going in the opposite direction. It had nine female members in the lower house; it now has five. What is the Labor Party talking about? At the same time that it is talking about quotas it is actually consistently dropping female representation. The Labor Party is clearly making no progress on the issue of women in parliament, either in Western Australia or in a number of other states.

The Labor Party puts up women as lambs to the slaughter. We should look at what it did to Carmen Lawrence and Joan Kirner. While both of those women were participants in ministries, leading their respective states into the ground, their Labor Party decided that they had to be the sacrificial lambs and taken to slaughter. Both of them then had to lead unsuccessful governments to defeat. That is the track record of this Labor Party—it actually leads its women to slaughter.

Part of the Labor Party's resolution on this quota system states that the national executive will have the responsibility and the power to determine the outcome in any public office preselection progressively between now and the year 2002 in order to ensure that the rule is complied with. That is what it has to do; it actually has to get intervention to make sure that the rule is complied with. But, of the several opportunities to get the ball rolling so far available to the Labor Party at the state and federal level, very few of them have been taken.

Only last Saturday week there was a by-election in the Western Australian state seat of Helena. Until that election was held, that was a Labor-held seat. But what did the Labor Party do? Instead of complying with its own so-called demands of quotas and getting in good women, it endorsed a man against the Liberal Party candidate, a very competent female who is now the member for Helena.

All of this tokenism, all of this flapping of the jaws, is leading absolutely nowhere in the Labor Party. Senator Gareth Evans may well displace a female candidate in running for Holt. We can only wonder whether he is prepared to endorse a female to fill his vacancy here in the Senate. But the deal has been done for Senator Evans to go into Holt, giving no consideration whatsoever to a female taking that seat. Yet the Labor Party is still saying that it has to get more women into winnable seats. It just does not gel.

Then there is the case of Jenny Beacham, the candidate for the marginal seat of Ballarat in Victoria. Ms Beacham is one of the Labor Party's highest profile and—as it tells us—most competent women, a former party state secretary. Why, if it thinks that much of her, did it endorse her for a marginal seat? Why has it not given her Holt? No, it gives her a marginal seat.

If it is the ALP's idea to endorse more women candidates only for marginal seats such as this, the policy can be little more than hot air at best and tokenism at worst. But that does not seem to worry the Labor Party. As Dr Lawrence has said, `I'm not into women coming up via male patronage.' I do not know what she is into but there is no way that this Labor Party is demonstrating what it is talking about.

The plan to introduce quotas may well and truly backfire by violating anti-discrimination guidelines and opening the floodgates to damages claims by unsuccessful male candidates. That remains to be tested but it is inevitable that it will be tested if a man is excluded from preselection by the Labor Party on the basis of his sex.

A number of legal opinions have been given to the effect that this government, this Labor Party, is actually contravening the anti-discrimination legislation which it brought into this country. I ask Senator Crowley when the government will be introducing legislation to make its decision on quotas retrospectively legal. Quite clearly, according to so many legal opinions, what it is doing is illegal. When will the government introduce such legislation?

Even allowing for the normal retirement rate of male politicians, there will not be enough seats available to come anywhere near the quota being demanded. Does that mean that men will simply be pushed onto the scrap heap? Certainly the men in the Labor Party in Western Australia are starting to dig in their heels because four of them have been earmarked for retirement and replacement. They are pretty cross about that. But does it matter to the Labor Party? No, it does not. Does it matter that it is contravening its own legislation? No, it does not. No wonder those people are pretty angry because the policy threatens to end the political careers of many good male politicians. But the Labor Party does not care about that because it is quite happy to indulge in reverse discrimination.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) says that this is just and wise. I wonder how the 60 male members of parliament who are going to be given the flick feel about that. I wonder whether they consider that it is just and wise. The policy is a classic bandaid measure. It is ill-conceived, it is clumsy and, above all, it is jolly patronising.

Does the Labor Party not recognise the achievements made thus far by women in parliament in the past and present? Does it think that without male intervention women will never get anywhere on their own in the future? The attitude is appalling. It is the most appalling indictment of the many notable achievements of women not just in the parliament but in sport, in the arts and other areas—professional women who, through their own blood, sweat and tears, have actually succeeded.

I was disturbed to learn that the other night Dr Lawrence made some inane quip on a program in which she and two other politicians—a British member of parliament and a Swedish member of parliament—were being interviewed. The British member of parliament said that the House of Commons is such a boys' club that it actually has a shooting gallery. Dr Lawrence said, `Oh, we have squash courts'—in other words, insinuating that women should not play squash. I wonder whether Dr Lawrence has ever heard of Heather McKay, Michelle Martin or Rachel Grinham, because they all happen to be Australians, they all happen to be champions, they all happen to be women, and they all happen to be squash players. But what does Dr Lawrence do? She belittles women again by saying that they are incapable of competing in sports.

I wonder whether Dr Lawrence would like to recall the good work that the Australian women did at the Commonwealth Games. But no, she belittles women because there somehow have to be quotas. These women achieved on their own behalf. They did not have to have quotas. They did not have to have some artificial crutch to get them there. But that is what Dr Lawrence is talking about.

It is interesting to look at the progress made under the Liberal Party in comparison to the Labor Party. The Liberal Party has traditionally encouraged women to play an active role in many facets of our society, including the parliament, and under the Liberal Party women have been encouraged to make real achievements. It has never been the intention of the Liberal Party to implement a quota scheme whereby the numbers of women in parliament or the judiciary are artificially bolstered merely as an act of tokenism. The Liberal Party has the runs on the board. We had the first female member of the House of Representatives, the first female senator, the first female minister, the first female cabinet minister responsible for a government department—

TALK.START.PARA: —Shaking your head is not going to change the facts.

—Yes, exactly. Shaking ones head is not going to change history. The Labor Party rewrites history on everything else—there is no point in it rewriting history on this as well. The Liberal Party had the first women opposition whips, it had the first women government whips, and it had the first ethnic women in parliament—the first woman of Chinese extraction and the first woman of Singaporean extraction. There have been firsts all the way along the line without quotas.
—Why should it be a competition?

—I repeat, just so that Senator Crowley and Senator Kernot might understand: this has been achieved without quotas. Of course, there is always room for improvement in terms of numbers of women in the parliament. But I believe that members of parliament, be they male or female, should be preselected on the basis of their merits and qualities as potential politicians. We do not subscribe to the Labor Party's concept of quotas, and we never will.

PARA.TAB: We need to also bear in mind at some stage what women themselves feel about it. Many of them do not wish to enter parliament because of their family and personal commitments. But what is the Labor Party doing? It is drafting women into the parliament and working against its own legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what Senator Knowles is doing in here with this ridiculous and peculiar debate. Is she in fact campaigning for fewer women in parliament, or is she actually wanting to have a kind of `Liberal Party women are better than Labor Party women' debate? Let me state a couple of things. I will say this for openers: I think the colt from Kooyong will not be replaced by a filly.
—Aren't we funny?

—Yes, it is. Secondly, according to the Age of 16 September 1944, Robert Menzies discovered he needed women. In securing support to create the Liberal Party he struck a deal with 40,000 members of the Women's National League in Victoria, assuring them that 50 per cent of executive positions at every level of the state Liberal Party would go to women in return for their support and finances. What does Senator Knowles call that? Is that not a quota? In fact, we know why he did that. He did it because the women held Robert Gordon Menzies to ransom by saying, `If you don't guarantee us 50 per cent of all executive places, you won't get the money that our large families can give you to establish this party.' That is what Senator Knowles's party is founded on—quotas for women to keep them in the backroom. The quotas for these women did not deliver them into parliament.

PARA.TAB: I do not mind if Senator Knowles comes in here to whack and slang around the place but, for goodness sake, she should do it on facts and with an understanding which is better than what she has as to what this is all about. One of the extraordinary things Senator Knowles said—and Senator Knowles looks as though she is beating a hasty retreat from the Senate—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not.

—She is not; that is good; she is staying. She is prepared to listen and really understand that what she was saying was absolute rubbish. For a start she said that legal opinion tells her that there could be complaints brought under the Sex Discrimination Act by anybody who is dudded of a seat on the ground that a woman might be preselected. It would be hard to decide that because there are no guaranteed seats for men.

PARA.TAB: In fact, if Senator Knowles understood the Sex Discrimination Act she would know that that is not possible. Political parties are exempt from the effect of that act. Senator Knowles does not even know the legislation that applies, and why would she? Eight of her colleagues crossed the floor to support the Sex Discrimination Act because her party was in such disarray about the act that her party actually opposed it. Those opposite thought it was going to wreck and ruin the world. But Senator Knowles does not understand it. No complaints can be brought: political parties are exempt from that act.

Indeed, it is important and interesting to note what happened to the people in the opposition who crossed the floor and supported the advancement of women. What happened to Mrs Kathy Martin? She was sent to an early political grave for wanting to support women. Senator Knowles could ask Peter Baume where his career went after he had the courage to support women. Senator Michael Baume would know that very well. She could also ask a number of other people in the opposition about what happened to their careers when they took the difficult step of crossing the floor to support the government's legislation on sex discrimination. They knew it was a very important thing to do. They knew what would happen to them.

I will cite former Senator Chris Puplick who wrote in his very good book that the Liberal Party lost a generation over Vietnam, it lost another generation over green issues, and right now it is losing another generation over the republic. Through all of those generations it has lost out because of its attitudes to women.

This Labor Party and this government are totally unashamed of making it clear that voluntary affirmative action in our parties has not delivered a sufficient number of women. That is no longer any good. We want some rule changes to ensure that women are fairly represented across safe seats and marginal seats in future parliaments starting from the year 2001 where a minimum only must be both men and women. It is perfectly possible to have far more than that number of either gender. Of course, the Labor Party will sort it out in the reasonable way that it always does. Senator Knowles could pick her seat.
Senator Michael Baume interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Baume really wants to get dirty or into tough details, he could ask what is happening about preselections in Western Australia at the moment with the Liberal opposition for its Senate ticket, for example. I will not trawl it all out here, but those opposite can hardly sheet home to the Labor Party difficulties about preselections or the challenge of trying to fit four people into three spaces. That is an absolute nonsense.
—What about South Australia? South Australia is a classic example.

—South Australia has seen the departure of Lyn Arnold, an extraordinarily excellent candidate and a wonderful representative of the Labor Party. It looks very likely—and one can never presume these things, of course—that the caucus in South Australia will be increased by yet another woman, taking the percentage in South Australia in the Labor Party to 35 per cent. We are very serious about it.

PARA.TAB: I want to take issue with another remarkable piece of nonsense that Senator Knowles referred to, that is, that women in the opposition get there on their merits and have never had the assistance of men, but that Labor Party women only get advanced because of the assistance of men. Actually, I have never felt that the assistance of men is an insult, particularly if it achieves things for candidates, and for women.

This year in South Australia we are celebrating an extraordinary achievement in which men assisted. They had to. I am talking about the centenary of suffrage. The vote for women in South Australia, and the right to stand for parliament, was won 100 years ago. We were the first democracy in the world to give that advance to women. As the parliament of the time that was bound to change the law was made up entirely of men, what were women to do? They needed to accept the assistance of men to change the laws, of course. For Senator Knowles to claim anything contrary to that is sheer and utter nonsense. Women accepted the support of members of parliament, all of whom were men, who were prepared to see that the future for a real democracy would be based on having fair representation for women. Certainly at least they saw there should be the opportunity for women to have a say in the shaping and formulation of the laws of the land through electing the people that they preferred.

I inform the Senate that Alexander Downer's grandfather at that time promised that he would support that legislation but, when it came time to vote, he did not do so. I am very pleased to remind Mr Alexander Downer of that at every opportunity. His grandfather said he would vote for women's suffrage but then did not. Senator Knowles might tell us what she has to say about that. Was Alexander Downer's grandfather for her or against her? Did he assist in progressing the advancement of women? Is Senator Knowles wanting to give away the right to vote that men won for her?

What happened in Western Australia? Did women win the vote for themselves there, or did male parliamentarians win it for them? Senator Knowles has put a nonsense argument. Perhaps it is not clear to listeners why those opposite want to argue as they are doing. They are castigating the Labor Party for making moves towards a rule change in an attempt to make serious its intention of having a fair representation of women elected to parliament. I would have thought members of the Liberal Party should be in here celebrating that.

There is no insult to women here. The women to be preselected, as is the case with the ones who have gone before, will be selected on merit, on their ability to perform as good candidates in the community in a House of Representatives seat or as an adequate and comprehensive person in the Senate. Different qualities may be needed. Women candidates have always been chosen on merit, and not because they are incompetent and men choose only incompetents. That is a pathetic and puerile argument.

I do not understand Senator Knowles's argument, except to say that apparently the Liberal Party thinks that women should be left to manage by themselves and not be given any assistance. This Labor Party and this government are absolutely committed to ensuring that our promises to women make a difference.

Those opposite are the first to come in here saying, `Why aren't there more women on boards? Why don't you do something about that?' We can only urge boards to further the appointment of women; we cannot force them. We are leaving it to boards to understand the changing society that we have. In one way those opposite want more women on boards. They either want them to achieve, or they do not. Senator Knowles cannot have it both ways. Is she not pleased about the success of the Labor Party in getting an increased number of women in parliament, or is it that she only wants Liberal women in parliament? If she only wants Liberal women in parliament, she should come out and say that only certain sorts of women are acceptable. Is it a disadvantage to have the Australian Democrats represented by men and women? If she is serious about more women in parliament, she should embrace all women in this parliament. But when it comes to the political crunch, then of course we are down to our usual party disciplinary lines.

But Senator Knowles is confused. She is not at all clear about what she is trying to say. She wants women in parliament, but she does not want to take steps to assist them. She is suggesting that a quota system does not guarantee merit, but she is absolutely wrong. She objects to quotas, but the Liberal Party was founded on quotas. I have to say to Senator Knowles that she should not come in here and point the finger at us. If those opposite cannot guarantee a filly for Kooyong but just another colt, I think they should put their own house in order before they criticise the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit unfortunate that this motion should get us to reduce the bigger debate about women in politics to some sort of obscene competition about `my party's got a better record than your party'. That is a bit of a masculine approach, if I might say so. It is true that women are under-represented at virtually all levels of senior decision making in this country: 13 per cent of the federal parliament, five per cent of professors and associate professors in Australian universities, three per cent of company board members. Those are just a few examples.

PARA.TAB: It is not about who is going to be moved on the government benches. What it means, Senator Knowles, is that while it is easier for Australian women to get themselves heard, that visibility does not necessarily translate itself into concrete action. I recently launched a collection of papers called Women in Government, in which Dr Elaine McCoy summed up the situation very well. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . while the modes of publicity available to women to express protest against conditions of subjugation have increased, the incidence of discrimination and exclusion from the centres of power have not changed much in over a century.

While we might get more money for things like child care or women's health, and we might see and hear more about violence against women, we are not getting much closer to the real sources of power in this country.

PARA.TAB: Virginia Woolf said that the history of men's opposition to women's achievements was as interesting as the achievements themselves. And nowhere has that been more apparent than in Australian politics, where we have managed the grand total of just over 60 women in federal parliament in the 93 years since Federation.

There are many reasons for that poor record, not the least of them being that party loyalty rather than gender loyalty has effectively dictated the political behaviour of Australian women. But, as many women have observed over the years, the rewards for party loyalty have often been very few. And they continue to be.

The history of women's involvement in Australian politics shows that not too many women have made it into leadership positions at a federal level or into the ministry, the cabinet or the shadow cabinet. I say to Senator Knowles that it is a bit rich to come in here and have a go at the Labor Party when the coalition is not exactly bursting at the seams with women shadow ministers. Bronwyn Bishop is the only woman in shadow cabinet.

We all know that there are some particularly competent women in this place—both parties—who have been overlooked for positions in favour of considerably less competent men. But having said that, I will acknowledge that the Liberal Party overall has a better record than the Labor Party. Despite the Labor Party liking to trumpet itself as the great party of equal opportunity, its structural and historical biases against women have been very difficult ones for women to overcome.

It is interesting to note that from 1901 to 1975 the ALP fielded only 35 women candidates for the House of Representatives while the major non-Labor parties fielded 51 candidates. But while their record may be marginally better, the conservative parties in Australian politics also have a structural bias against women. As many women in the Liberal Party have pointed out over the years, the party suffers from a paradox.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know that?

—I am going to explain that to Senator Ferguson. The Liberal Party suffers from a paradox because, on the one hand, we have an historical willingness to incorporate women into internal party structures but, on the other hand, we have an ongoing failure to articulate policies which address discrimination against women. Time and again, the Liberal Party has chosen to see women's policies primarily in terms of family policies, or to see women's concerns as being defined by their family responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: That sort of thinking fails to address the fundamental political and economic inequality of women. It is limited thinking. It is thinking which reflects the Liberal Party's inability to see the need for structural changes in a whole range of areas, not just in terms of women. So I do not think that the Labor Party has a monopoly on hypocrisy when it comes to getting more women into positions of power where they can influence and change party policy. I am not entirely sure that quotas will be the solution, although in the Labor Party's case at least it represents an acknowledgment of how much work it needs to do to get the reality matching the rhetoric.

It worries me that quotas could be used as a cop out and as a way of avoiding long-term structural reform. I will be very surprised—I hope I am wrong—if that 35 per cent of women being preselected in winnable seats translates into 35 per cent of senior party positions or 35 per cent of cabinet positions being held by women by the year 2002. I bet it does not. It will not work if it is not really about structural change; it will not work if it is about imposing quotas on a system which is not a good one in the first place.

The Democrats have not had a need for quotas, mainly, I suggest, because of the importance of our participatory structures. This is something which is rarely acknowledged when people talk about the involvement of women in Australian politics. These are processes which have delivered the election of the first woman leader of a political party at a federal level in Janine Haines.

I acknowledge that the Democrats do not come with a lot of historical and political baggage, and we have not had to battle with the sorts of vested interests or entrenched male hierarchies which exist in other parties. But that is the very thing that appealed to me and to other women when I joined the Democrats. Right from the start, the male and female founding members set up our party processes along participatory principles, inclusive principles; that is something which many women find attractive. I am not revealing anything new when I say that participatory structures can be very difficult to work with at times, but I do think it is one argument that has to be acknowledged. It is one of the major reasons why women have done so well in the Democrats, compared with other parties.

I want to finish by mentioning the matter of electoral reform. There is not much point in political parties running around sniping at each other about who does or does not care about getting more women into parliament if we do not address the fundamental question of major electoral reform. I think it is very clear that multi-member electorates are essential to achieving better representation for women, and I do not think we should be afraid to start looking at various ways of improving our electoral system to make it a more representative one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess I am disappointed that this debate has not been possible in terms of cross-party support for the fundamental issues. There has been a bit of opportunistic sniping about what the Labor Party or the Liberal Party might do, and I am going to avoid indulging in that level of debate. The issue is about women's equity in this country. It is about women taking their place in the democratic processes of the national and state parliaments and, indeed, at local government level as well. I do not think it really helps for us to say almost like schoolgirls, `We are better than you.' We are all in exactly the same boat.

PARA.TAB: Recently, a colleague who was battling to gain recognition in the business sector said to me, `He's your colleague, your equal, a post liberation new sensitive age guy. But compete with him and you'll find this new dog knows some very old tricks.' That quote refers to Liberals, to Democrats, to Labor men, to men in business and to men in the public sector. The women who have actually made it into parliament are all in the situation where we can start to raise these issues, to try to get greater public awareness of the issues and, in the case of the Australian Labor Party, I am proud to say, we are prepared to do something about it.

I could tell some horrendous stories about my party's record—and I see some of those opposite looking very interested—but I am not going to. I do not think that serves the debate for the future. What I can say, though, is that the Australian Labor Party next Tuesday, as a result of the rules debate that has been flagged by the decision of the national executive and led very ably and very strongly by Prime Minister Paul Keating, will reject the chauvinism of the past.

We will say, sure, we have not got it right in the past; far too many men have been promoted and merit has had nothing to do with it. Far too many women have been overlooked. Far too many women have been ignored. We confess that, but that is in the past. We are looking to the future. We are finding a new way, and that is the quota approach or the target approach, depending on one's preference of terminology.

There are some people in this parliament and, indeed, in the community who seem to think that setting a particular target or quota is somehow revolutionary or radical. What will the Labor Party's decision, this rule change, mean next Tuesday? It will mean that one in three vacancies, as they occur, will be negotiated through the factional system so that one in three vacancies are filled by women. This process will proceed over the next eight years. That is not particularly revolutionary. If many of my women colleagues were asked how they would do it, they would have done it very differently; it might have been much more radical. This is a realistic, logical compromise; it is a sensible decision which I know will be endorsed by the national conference next week and I am proud to be associated with it.

A recent Inter-Parliamentary Union survey revealed that the proportion of women in the world's houses of parliament has dropped significantly in the last five years. This concept of setting a target or quota is not something particularly radical. Twenty-three countries with social democratic parties currently operate some form of quota system to ensure that more women are represented in parliament. Canada and Great Britain have adopted a 50 per cent quota for women by the year 2000. Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Germany have adopted a 40 per cent quota for each gender. Other countries, including Austria, Belgium, France, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Spain and Turkey, have each introduced quotas which range from 15 per cent to 33 per cent. Quite clearly, this is a way to start to bring about reform—reform that is long overdue.

When I was minister with responsibility for the status of women, I used to wonder when the private sector directors would attack me for expecting them to comply with affirmative action legislation while within my own ranks we ignored such principles. The Labor Party has a very proud tradition in terms of our commitment to social justice, to recognition of equal opportunity, to recognition of equity. The only thing is that somebody forgot to tell us about it when we were working on the inside, when we were working on our home bases, if you like, within the party. Now is the time for us to change. That change has been announced through our national executive processes and it will be endorsed next week.

To those who say it cannot work, that we are going to force men out of parliament, I say: you would have to be joking! Do people really think that the handful of women who actually have any power or authority within this parliament are going to have the power and authority to march men out of the parliament by force? What nonsense! The 35 per cent target is a realistic and logical way to proceed. Women in the party will be monitoring it very closely. Women in the community will also be watching it very closely. If the 35 per cent target is not being met, if jobs for the boys are continuing to be delivered to the boys, if the mates and the favoured sons are being put first, it will be not only women in the party but women in the community who have something to say about it, because women expect more representation of women not only in parliament but at the upper levels of all decision making around this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anyone in this parliament denies the fact that there are not enough women in parliament, particularly in the major parties. That is why I thought Senator Kernot's contribution in general was a very positive one. Her party probably needs quotas for men rather than women to create some kind of equality. But the key point is this: the Labor Party's hypocrisy in going down the track it has gone down—that is, having quotas—is aimed at covering up a deep-seated tradition which has been anti-women. That is the key and unequivocal issue which cannot be denied.

PARA.TAB: Despite its veneer of reform, deep down inside the Labor Party retains quite a lot of its worst traditions. It was the last major party to give up racism as a formal policy. It retains its old-fashioned, long-held view of women, particularly in the right wing in New South Wales, as people who are somehow subservient. Its actions confirm that view. That is why its rhetoric has to be so absurd—to make up for the lack of meaningful action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at the back of you.

—But the rhetoric gets the media attention, and that is what these latest measures are all about. They are about getting media attention to say, `What good people we intend to be in the future; we haven't delivered yet.' If Senator Ray is looking at his two female colleagues who are in the chamber as evidence of having delivered, can I reaffirm the point: you have not delivered yet.

PARA.TAB: This is all about getting phoney media headlines. I agree with Senator Kernot who made the very strong point that quotas could be a cop-out to avoid real reform. How many women are sitting on that front bench?
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably, because of illness, one of our most outstanding women had to withdraw from our frontbench. So I do not take that very kindly. The other point that Senator Kernot made that I think is well worth noting is her concession that overall the Liberal Party has a better record than the Labor Party on this issue. She is absolutely right. I quote her directly: it is without quotas in the parliament.

PARA.TAB: There is no point referring to what Senator Crowley said; it was all so incredibly nonsensical. But what did interest me is that she was praising some members on this side of the house for having crossed the floor. What humbug! If only her party would allow people to cross the floor, we may be able to see what some of them really think—if they think at all. Clearly, this is a matter largely of humbug. The quota system, as Senator Kernot said, can and will be used as a cop-out, just as the rhetoric in the past from the Labor Party has not been met by action.

The Liberal Party has a well-established and very proud tradition in selecting and promoting women into politics—a fact that is all too often overlooked or deliberately ignored by those who are in the business of rewriting history, like the people opposite. The Liberals are extremely proud of the way this party has recognised over the last 50 years the enormous contribution that women from all walks of life can and do make to Australian public life and politics in particular.

Women have had an important role to play in the Liberal Party since its inception. Our record is certainly much more impressive than Labor's. There is still a lot to be done, I concede, but I underline Senator Kernot's point: our record is better than Labor's. I guess Senator Kernot would probably say it is less worse; nonetheless, it is better—without quotas.

While the Liberal Party has always promoted and encouraged women, Labor has only recently—and quite cynically—realised that women have an important role to play in the Australian political system. Let us recognise that the first woman elected to the New South Wales parliament—I speak strongly of New South Wales as a representative of that state—was Millicent Preston in 1925. She was a member of the Nationalist Party, which was a precursor of the Liberal Party that opposed the Labor Party in New South Wales.

At the federal level, the Liberal Party was the first in appointing a woman to cabinet, in 1949—Dame Enid Lyons. The first woman to serve in a cabinet and have responsibility for a government department was Senator Margaret Guilfoyle in 1976. Naturally, she was a Liberal. In New South Wales, Rosemary Foot was the first woman to be elected to a senior leadership position. That happened 11 years ago when Mrs Foot was elected deputy leader of the parliamentary party.

Importantly, there are four women in the New South Wales state cabinet. That is the highest proportion of women in any ministry in Australia. That is a proud record for the New South Wales Liberal and National parties. The New South Wales cabinet has twice as many women as does the state Labor Party's shadow ministry, which has only two females. If Bob Carr, the state leader of the opposition in New South Wales, and the ALP are serious about promoting women, the shadow ministry is not a bad place to start; unless, of course, Mr Carr thinks there are no women of merit on his back bench.

The fact is that the only way for a woman in the Labor Party to be promoted up the ladder is for her to belong to the right faction and be married to one of the self-styled power brokers. As the Australian said only last week, the New South Wales Labor Party idea of affirmative action is `giving your wife a job'. Perhaps in view of the Cabramatta preselection going on at the moment, we should add `or your fiancee'.

If the Labor Party is not being hypocritical it should replace with women those male Labor members who are poor performers in this parliament. I would rather see an incompetent male replaced by a female, even if she were equally incompetent. In particular, in the Macarthur electorate, Mr Chris Haviland, a particularly undistinguished member, should be replaced by his challenger—as yet unannounced—from his faction, Miss Meg Oates. I do not know when that is going to take place but I understand there is a recognition that Meg Oates would make a `less worse' member than Chris Haviland. It would not take much. In Gilmore, it would not take a woman of very high calibre to improve on Mr Peter Knott, whose main contribution as a member of government has been to threaten to shoot local councillors. In Throsby, a mature spinster may be an appropriate replacement for Mr Hollis whose record, in every sense, particularly his record number of overseas trips, is less than satisfactory.

While the Liberal Party has plenty to be proud about when it comes to the promotion of women in politics, certainly there is a long way to go and there is much improvement to be made. I have to recognise that; I concede it. I hope that one of the results of this kind of debate is that more women will be selected in winnable seats by both parties. The Liberal Party believes in equal opportunity in our society and the presence of women in all spheres of politics is necessary to legitimise this belief. We believe it to be true and something we should support strongly, particularly on merit.

The extent to which women of merit are failing to get into the parliament is a matter of major concern. We do not resolve the problem of merit, however, by having quotas. We reject this tokenistic solution being peddled by our opponents—in particular these proposals to introduce a strict quota system for women—because such proposals are not only tokenistic; they are simplistic, counterproductive and demeaning to women. They are saying to women, `You are sufficiently politically incompetent that you cannot get into a parliament without some kind of special deal.'

While our opponents talk about quotas, we are getting on with the job. I will cite one example of what we are doing in New South Wales. An initiative of the Liberal Party's women council in New South Wales a few months ago was the publication of a document called Take Your Seats. I must say it is very timely. This practical guide to help women seek preselection is yet another very practical and very public indication by the Liberal Party in New South Wales and by the Fahey government of the commitment to enhance the status of women in that state.

That is why the state government created a separate Ministry for the Status and Advancement of Women, the first ministry of its type in Australia. This ministry provides the government with high level advice on a wide range of issues affecting women right across the state. It is a slight change of pace from Prime Minister Hawke's Office of the Status of Women, whose major contribution was to provide $11,000 for the left-handed curious female surfboard inventor who had never learnt how to ride a surfboard. The Liberal Party, as I said, has much to be proud of in relation to women in politics, but there is clear room for improvement.

Let us look at the state Labor opposition's record in New South Wales: on women it is a giant embarrassment. That is why senior female MPs such as Jeannette McHugh have attacked this proposal as nothing but a joke and a ruse. Even Mr Carr's own shadow minister for women, Pam Allan, has described the proposals being pushed as a move by the right wing of the ALP to promote women who are, in her words, `fairly compliant or cronies of head office'. That is what this hypocritical nonsense from the Labor Party is all about. Let us remind people about the abandonment of ALP preselection in Gosford in 1992 when Carr's male candidate was under strong threat from a local woman, Anne Rees. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —You know nothing about the issues you discuss; you are ignorant and an embarrassment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is quite obvious, Senator. I am saddened by the contribution we have just heard because what this debate should be about is not whether we are better than those opposite. That is playing the boys' games—for my sisters here. That is getting back into the arguments that are colouring and confusing the issue. What we have to say is that none of the major parties has a particularly good track record on having women in parliament. That is what the issue is, not the fact that they have four women in the cabinet in New South Wales and we have only two in the shadow cabinet. That should not be a debating issue.

PARA.TAB: What should and must be the issue is the fact that both parties need more women in parliament and in cabinet. It does not only apply and rest in parliament; it rests everywhere women are involved. Let us not confuse the issue by playing these little boys' games of `mine's bigger than yours'. That is not the way we should be looking at this debate. If members of the Liberal Party believe in equal opportunity and think they care for their women, why was it necessary for them to put out a document called Take Your Seats? I have to say it is a very good document. It has a lot of good information for both male and female candidates.

But if the Liberal Party cared so much about getting women into parliament—it claims they have equal opportunity and no impediments are put in the way—why was it necessary to put out this document to assist women going to preselection? Those opposite cannot answer that question because they fail to recognise that there is any impediment and that women have a problem. However, the women there obviously have. I would also like to draw members of the opposition back to an article by Karen Middleton that appeared in the Age on 16 September. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1944, Robert Menzies discovered he needed women. In securing support to create the Liberal Party, he struck a deal with the 40,000 members of the Women's National League in Victoria, assuring them that 50 per cent of executive positions at every level in the state Liberal Party would go to women, in return for their support and their finances.

PARA.TAB: The 50 per cent rule got there because it made good electoral sense at the time and, despite the party's general aversion to quotas for women, it is still there today.

SPEECH.PARA: If anyone is being hypocritical it is the Liberal Party, because 50 years ago—the Liberal Party is only 50 years old—it put that into its documentation and its rules. Members of the Liberal Party conveniently forget that today. Let us not get bogged down in the debate of `we've got more in parliament than you have'. I am proud to be one of the two females out of the four New South Wales right-wing senators. I think the Liberal Party has to do better than that.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, The Shape of Things to Come, is a welcome recognition of the importance of small businesses and the need to foster them. As the report shows, the majority of employment in Australia comes from small business. As big companies continue job shedding, more and more people will be involved in small business or will be self-employed. Some of the measures suggested here are important and have our support. Certainly programs to make some training available for owners, managers and workers in small business will be of help. Having a freely available publication of examples of other small businesses that have done well and having the database are good ideas. Recommendation No. 9, which suggests that the role of intermediaries such as accountants, banks, lawyers and other service providers should be examined and made more supportive of small business, seems a crucial task to engage in.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, there is an extremely heavy weighting on training and the assumption seems to be that, as with the unemployed, government training programs are all that is required to make small businesses go. The database idea is good, but it appears that the report recommends it essentially as a way of accessing or slotting into the right programs. In fact, the training industry appears to be the one heavily stimulated here, and there is some tie-in with the idea of privatising employment training and services functions carried out by DEET and the CES.

There are other worrying recommendations. Recommendation No. 16 suggests that another level of certification should be imposed upon society. Small businesses would have to qualify for certification as a small business. Recommendation No. 5 talks about setting benchmarks for best practice. Recommendation No. 15 seems to involve picking winners. Recommendation No. 13 works on incorporating `entrepreneurship' into education to create `desired' small businesses.

If this is the shape of things to come, I, for one, am concerned enough to suggest that that shape should be radically changed. While there is no requirement yet for small businesses to take up various areas of government training or any particular program, making it a requirement to do training sufficient to get a competency certificate in small business management simply puts another barrier or set of barriers between small businesses and any program meant to help. It is another set of hoops to jump through at a time when small business already complains about the level of bureaucracy it must contend with. It seems that government has decided to be heavily paternalistic and not only assist but also direct small business, one of the few places where diversity and vitality are still allowed.

This could be very positive. The database, for example, could be used to assist small business to connect with other small and medium enterprises that are potential suppliers and customers or for cooperative arrangements. We could have seen some suggestions to move towards a less bureaucratic treatment of small business. We could have seen some major suggestions about improving the economic climate in which small business has to exist.

This economic climate is one where it is very difficult for small businesses to access loans. It is expensive to rent properties. Very often they have to pay expensive overheads for things they do not need or use. For example, they may have to split water costs even though there is no tap or toilet on the premises. They also have to compete with large national and transnational corporations that may effectively dominate wholesale markets and are able to manipulate prices to the detriment of small businesses. There are often no means of bringing goods effectively to market at costs that are affordable to small business.

There are numerous good ideas around, some of which small businesses themselves are working at implementing, sometimes over government resistance. I refer to LETS as an example. One meaning for this acronym is `local enterprise trading scheme'; another is the `local energy transfer system'. But no matter what the acronym specifically means in a specific area, LETS is where small businesses can get resources or services through direct exchanges where cash is short. The government actively resisted this until recently, when the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) began to realise how much genuine good the system did for the battlers.

Likewise, there is no reason why we could not implement a Grameen Bank style of scheme to help small businesses to get access to capital. The Grameen Bank is where a number of borrowers, small borrowers, can join together and each of them serves to guarantee the repayment of loan from others in the group. This has worked very well in other countries and especially in developing countries.

There are a number of ways in which we could positively act to create viable, diverse and creative local economies with small business as a basis. They would require a certain amount of political will and reversal of government policy. It is a shame such ideas are not found in this report. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support Senator Margetts and the great bulk of what she had to say, particularly the points she made about the risk of too much bureaucracy intervening in this area of small business and in governmental support particularly in terms of basic skills and so on. Also, I must say that I accept her view that access to finance appears in many instances to be discriminatory in relation to small business.

PARA.TAB: The important thing we have to recognise is that small business is not a small part of the Australian economy. There are over 780,000 non-agricultural private sector businesses in Australia. I mention `non-agricultural' because all family farms are small businesses and their number would enormously boost this figure. Ninety-six per cent, or 757,000, of these private sector businesses in Australia are small businesses. These firms employ 2.57 million people, or about 51 per cent, of the non-agricultural private sector work force and contribute almost 30 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. So small businesses are obviously a very important part of our economy.

A substantial proportion of these businesses, about 55 per cent or I think about 418,000 of them, are self-employed people—in other words, they do not employ anyone—or are working proprietors in partnerships. Together they account for something like 801,000 people.

A further 212,000 firms—that is, 22 per cent—employ fewer than five people. So they are very personal small businesses. This is an area where so many Australians feel that they have the right—and they should—to have a go, to try to be their own person and to make their own contribution. This is the area in which there have been in the past the greatest number of failures, the greatest number of problems and—during the recession we had to have—an excessive number of families and their livelihoods destroyed.

There is no doubt that improved skill levels are an important element in improving the situation. The report notes that there are some positive signs that the average level of skills among small business owner-managers is on the rise, that small business recognition of the need for continuing skills development is also increasing and that small business owner-managers appear to have a positive attitude towards employing people with post-school qualifications. I am strongly in support of those moves. I believe that this report merits serious attention. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: The payment is required to compensate Mr Jonathan Cole for the amount of $167.33.

DEBATE.TITLE: RIGHTS AND EXPLOITATION OF THE CHILD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend motion No. 1068 standing in my name.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
