SPEECH.PARA: (a)reaffirms Australia's opposition to the economic exploitation of children, as expressed in Article 32 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, ratified by Australia in December 1990, which states that:

`1. State Parties recognise the right of the child to be protected from economic exploitation and from performing any work that is likely to be hazardous or to interfere with the child's education, or to be harmful to the child's health or physical, mental, spiritual, moral or social development.

2. State Parties shall take legislative, administrative, social and educational measures to ensure the implementation of the present article. To this end, and having regard to the relevant provisions of other international instruments, States Parties shall in particular:
(a)Provide for a minimum age or minimum ages for admission to employment;
(b)Provide for appropriate regulation of the hours and conditions of employment;
(c)Provide for appropriate penalties or other sanctions to ensure the effective enforcement of the present article.'; and

(b)calls on the Australian Government to examine the feasibility of legislation to prohibit the importation of goods produced by child labour, consistent with its commitment under the Convention on the Rights of the Child, and to report to the Senate in the sitting week commencing 7 November 1994.

EMPHASIS.TAB: Paragraph (b) was subsequently amended by Senator Spindler to read:

SPEECH.PARA: ``(b)calls on the Australian Government to play an active role in developing within the international community effective measures to eliminate such exploitation of children and to examine the feasibility of legislation to prohibit the importation of goods produced by child labour and to report to the Senate in the sitting week commencing 7 November 1994.''.
I begin by quoting a report from the Chicago Tribune of 10 December 1991. It states:

Police recently raided a Bangkok sweatshop that produces paper cups and rescued 31 children who had been locked in a small room. Not one was older than 13. A shocked police officer said the weeping children clung to the legs of his officers. They were emaciated and suffering from malnutrition. They had been beaten so badly that most needed to be carried to freedom. Many had skin diseases. They told of being thrashed if they failed to make 700 paper cups a day: by hand. Police suspect that to keep them awake during sadistically long workdays, the owner . . . gave them amphetamine tablets . . . One 13-year-old told police he had been beaten unconscious twice when he tried to escape.

It would be easy to stand here and recite horror stories one after another about child labour exploitation in Third World countries. Examples such as the one I have just given are not rare and that example related to only 31 children.

PARA.TAB: The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions estimates that between 100 million and 200 million of the world's children between the ages of four and 15 are `labouring in mines, making matches, selling gum in the streets, cooking, washing clothes, working as domestic servants, weaving carpets, making clothes, sewing underwear, and working in the fields, at the plantations and on building sites round the world'. Two hundred million children are being robbed of their childhood and suffering appalling conditions—much of it, let it be said, in the employ of Western multinationals. It would be easy, as I said, simply to stand here and recount these horror stories. One might think that doing that would be enough to shame our government into action.

However, on Tuesday when I asked the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, about child labour he acknowledged the problem. He said, `We recognise that the problem of child labour exists in our region.' To recount horror stories would serve no purpose. The government acknowledges the problem, but still refuses to take action. That bears repeating: the government acknowledges the obscene exploitation of children in factories in our region, but it still refuses to take action. It will not restrict imports produced using child labour. It will not legislate to control the behaviour of Australian firms operating offshore in their treatment of labour. It continues to push its economic rationalist trade deregulation agenda, both in GATT and in APEC, without demanding the inclusion of social clauses to protect workers and the environment.

Not only does the government not take action against child labour exploitation in other countries and not only does it refuse to legislate to ensure at least that Australian consumers and firms do not inadvertently support such practices, but it continues to pursue a trade agenda in international forums which blindly ignores that child labour exploitation is an inevitable consequence of so-called free trade. That freedom from regulation for the work that is being carried out in our region includes the freedom to mistreat and to exploit some of the most vulnerable human beings.

What are the reasons given for the government's failure to act? Apart from Senator McMullan's accusations in his response to my question on Tuesday that I was proposing `feel-good' measures, he advanced a number of rationalisations of this government's appalling failure to act. So rather than recite horror stories, it would be more productive to address those rationalisations. Firstly, let me quote a report from the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 August 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: The President of the ACTU, Mr Martin Ferguson, also called on the Federal Government to take a stronger line on Australian companies not observing basic workers' rights and international labour conventions overseas. `I think the Commonwealth Government should be more aggressive on these issues,' he said.
I trust Senator McMullan phoned Mr Ferguson and told him that his suggestions were also, as he said to me, half-cocked and feel-good.

PARA.TAB: In his first words in answer to my question on Tuesday Senator McMullan expressed puzzlement that I referred to the passage of legislation against child sex exploitation, saying that he could not see how that added to the debate. The point is that the Australian parliament has now set a precedent. It has taken the view that it has a responsibility to control the behaviour of Australians abroad where that behaviour is exploitative and obscene. But it is no less obscene for children to be beaten senseless and fed amphetamines to keep them working 14 hours a day in dangerous and unhealthy conditions for a pittance than for them to be exploited for perverted sexual gratification.

Why, then, can we not legislate to control the behaviour of Australian firms overseas? One of the direct results of the government's trade liberalisation agenda is that Australian firms are increasingly under pressure to relocate production offshore so that they can remain cost competitive. Like it or not, this means that some Australian firms—perhaps inadvertently or unknowingly—are supporting or sanctioning child labour exploitation, if not directly, then through the subcontractors that they use.

The quintupling of the rate of Australian investments offshore over the last four years—which Senator Cook, in answer to another of my questions in this chamber, cited as a healthy trend—may in fact be contributing to one of the world's greatest human tragedies. As the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) has said in the other place, `Pimp or factory owner: what is the difference?' Until we legislate, the difference is that an Australian who exploits children for sex offshore faces up to 17 years imprisonment, while an Australian who exploits children as factory fodder offshore gets increased profits.

The second argument for obscene inaction advanced by Senator McMullan on Tuesday was that child labour was `fundamentally a result of poverty'. He argued against trade sanctions `which will do nothing to reduce the level of poverty in the country and may make it worse'.

Senator McMullan would have more credibility in taking this line if the government's record on aid matters were not so disgraceful. Our aid budget has fallen from 0.5 per cent of GDP in 1983, when Labor took office, to 0.34 per cent of GDP at the present time. The government's once strongly stated commitment to increasing that ratio to the UN target of 0.7 per cent gets expressed more fuzzily and more half-heartedly every time we hear it.

Within that aid budget, despite continuing pressure from the non-government organisations community, more and more of it is addressed to programs focused on generating commercial returns to Australia rather than poverty alleviation in Third World countries. The most direct impact we could have on child labour through the aid budget would be to support primary education. Primary education, combined with free school food, has been shown in many surveys to keep children out of the work force. Yet of the roughly $200 million a year spent on education in the aid budget, over 90 per cent goes on tertiary education, and most of it is aid aimed at the rich to get them to attend and therefore support our own universities. One should ask the question: how many scholarships for poor and disadvantaged school children and students have we funded through our aid program?
It is also fallacious for Senator McMullan to argue that acting against child labour might worsen poverty. As pointed out in the Far Eastern Economic Review of 9 July 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: The tiny wages actually drawn by the children make little difference to family income, child workers not only seem to displace the adult workers but also seem to depress the incomes of adults doing similar work.

In other words, failing to take action may worsen the poverty. Senator McMullan's argument is also weak when we consider the extent to which multinational firms are involved in child exploitation. It is not as if these companies cannot afford to hire adult workers or pay decent wages. By letting them continue to exploit child labour, we actually facilitate greater appropriation of labour value added by Western capitalists and consumers. We help them to rip-off developing countries and keep the Third World in poverty. Demanding that these firms pay a fair wage for adult labour is one of the best ways to fight poverty in developing countries. These are two of the arguments Senator McMullan used.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the next one. He argued that we should not take action against some imports which we know use child labour because we cannot identify all the offenders. `So the people who are good at disguising their obnoxious behaviour should continue to trade with us, but not the ones that do it so openly!' he exclaimed. All I can say is I am glad that he is not the Minister for Justice. Since we cannot catch all the murderers and rapists, should we let the ones that we do know go scot-free?

Senator McMullan also argues that it would be extremely difficult to identify goods that are produced with child labour. For one thing, he is not right. International networks do exist, and organisations such as the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions undertake inspections and report on instances of child labour exploitation. Even if he were right, does the difficulty of catching a crook justify letting him or her get away with murder? There are many Australians who are sickened by child labour practices. Few, if any, would knowingly support such practices by buying products based on the destruction of a child's life.

Australians do not want to buy such products. How much harder will it be for individual consumers to identify products than for the government? Obviously, very much harder. The government has a responsibility to prevent Australian consumers becoming unwitting accomplices to the crime of child labour exploitation.

The difficulties with identifying offences and offenders in the sex tourism area has not prevented us from passing legislation directed at combating that particular obnoxious practice. We have anti-dumping legislation where we need to identify producers, the costs of their production and the products that are being dumped on our markets. Yet that information is not only obtainable, it is being obtained on a regular basis. So the argument that it is difficult to identify the products and their origin does not hold much water.

The last argument Senator McMullan put to defend the gutless inaction of his government was an assertion that, `It will have to be a multilateral solution; it cannot be a bilateral solution.' If by `multilateral solution' he means continual international talkfests where everyone stands up and denounces child labour exploitation but no-one actually does anything, then I have my doubts. Senator McMullan said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are trying very hard to work on improving labour standards in our region . . . through our support for the ILO in Asia, through our tripartite government, union and employer delegations.

But what have we really done except talk about the issue, and maybe exhort foreign governments? Do we expect a gale of hot air blowing up through South-East Asia from down south to be enough to beat down practices which are exploiting millions of children?

PARA.TAB: The sociologist B.N. Juyal has made it very clear that the main impetus for change comes from implicit threats of import bans by consumer countries. This is even recognised in the countries threatened by such sanctions. In the Indian Express in an editorial on 1 February 1994 it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The only piece of legislation on child labour that seems to have had a wholesome effect in India is ironically the Child Labour Deterrence Act introduced into the United States Senate by Tom Harkin.

That bill proposed the establishment of a labelling system where products guaranteed as being made without child labour will be sheltered from restrictions. Even before this bill was debated in the United States Congress, the Bangladesh Textile Exporting Industry Association had put increased pressure on its affiliates to clean up their factories and their practices. The biggest impact of the debate generated by such legislation is the pressure it puts on manufacturers. They will take action; they will respond if their markets, if their sales are threatened.

PARA.TAB: Firms like Levis and Ikea have taken internal action to ensure that child labour does not occur in their production lines or at the subcontractor level. The potential brand-name damage that could be done to such companies by failing to qualify for a `Guaranteed free from child labour' label is a tremendous force for change but it will only follow if legislation exists that is directed towards keeping such products out of our markets.

Bilateral action is possible and is effective. The Americans insisted upon, and actually got, a so-called `side agreement' with Mexico on environmental standards as part of the NAFTA negotiations. Why can we not insist upon similar social clauses in any trade liberalisation agreements arising out of APEC negotiations? Why can we not push for side agreements on child labour?

On 25 November 1993 I gave notice of a motion calling on the government to establish an APEC international social and ecological development authority advisory committee to look at issues such as this. What has the government done about it? I suspect the answer is: nothing. The government's trade deregulation agenda for APEC might lead to gains from trade for all and a general rise in living standards and working conditions; but it may also lead to a race to the bottom as countries compete to become lowest cost producers by slashing labour and environmental standards. In this scenario investment will be attracted by regimes which offer cheap labour and minimal interference.

Such a driving down of standards would hurt even Australia. Indeed, the growth of a sweatshop outworker industry in Melbourne as detailed by Paul Heinrichs in a series of articles in the Age recently demonstrates that it is already happening. Either of these outcomes is possible: trade can bring plenty or poverty. We have to push for trade regimes that raise standards rather than lower them, and that means insisting on `social clauses' in any trade deregulation agreements. This is not neo-protectionism as Prime Minister Goh of Singapore claimed recently but a real concern for workers in developing and developed countries alike and for the children in particular in these countries.

There really is no excuse for inaction. Pursuing multilateral solutions is commendable but it is not enough. We support the call by the ACTU for social clauses to be included in GATT; but to wait for multilateral sanctions may be like waiting for Godot. ILO convention No. 5 from as long ago as 1919 called for a minimum age in industry. Where are the enforcement provisions?

Someone has to go first but we would not be first. Senator Tom Harkin in the United States was first; he showed us the way, so why do we not take similar action? International restrictions on trade in goods made from child labour must start somewhere. If Australia imposes such restrictions others are more likely to follow. If every country self-interestedly says it is too hard to take action, as Senator McMullan does, then 200 million children around the world will continue to suffer, including an additional 80,000 who are estimated to start work every day.

Without sanctions child labour will always be attractive to unscrupulous employers. Children are easier to discipline and children can be forced to accept hazardous working conditions. They are also, of course, cheaper to employ. The International Council of Free Trade Unions reports that in Nepal children in the carpet industry are often not paid at all. That certainly does not do much for poverty. The only cost to the employer is when he or she buys the children from their parents. This is just obscenely wrong, and right and wrong should not wait on collective decision making, getting everybody under a head.

Australia's failure to take action is no less wrong if no other countries are taking action. This is an issue where Australia should lead, where Australia should act unilaterally, as in fact Australia has acted unilaterally to reduce tariffs.

The Australian Democrats call on the Australian government to act now and to take substantive, tangible action rather than limiting itself to going, `Tut, tut' at international meetings of bureaucrats. We demand: action to restrict imports made from child labour; introduction of a labelling system to identify imports guaranteed free from child labour; legislation to ensure Australian companies operating offshore meet minimum standards in employee working conditions; Australia to take a lead role in the negotiation of social clauses as part of GATT; Australia to take a lead role in ensuring that any APEC trade liberalisation agreements include social clauses addressing labour rights and the environment; immediate establishment of an APEC international social and ecological development advisory committee to advise the Prime Minister on social and ecological issues which should be addressed in Australia and in the region as a result of the initiatives taken by participating countries in the area of trade, finance and industry; and, to underpin it all, the government should at long last, after being two years late, discharge its obligation to provide a progress report to the United Nations on the degree of implementation of the convention on the rights of the child.

Australia should not be importing goods that have the blood of children on them. Immediate action is imperative. In my amendment to paragraph (b) I have suggested that the Australian government investigate the feasibility of some of the measures I have been suggesting. I have suggested that the government report to the Senate in the week starting 7 November.

No-one is denying that some of the measures I am suggesting are difficult to implement. There are challenges that we must investigate and challenges we must meet. I am asking the government to start the process—to collect the information, to investigate it—and to do it in the spirit of knowing that what we are witnessing and what we are part of, whether we like it or not, is simply not acceptable to a decent civilised nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise to move an amendment to Senator Spindler's amendment which, I understand, has been circulated in the chamber and is now subject to discussion. I do not think that anybody disagrees with Senator Spindler on the point that there is a major problem. It is a problem of obscene proportions. It is a problem on a scale that requires concerted international action at a number of levels.

PARA.TAB: Where Senator Spindler and the government perhaps disagree is on the means of effectively addressing the problem and the best way of ensuring that the problem is not only identified but addressed and solutions found. I do not think that we disagree for one moment on the fact that an intolerable situation is apparent in a number of countries in the region with respect to the exploitation of children. That is a reality and it is a very real concern. The question for debate this afternoon is how definite results might be accomplished.

In my view and, I believe, in the view of the government, it is a question that requires concerted international action. I take as an example a situation with which you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would be only too familiar: the concerted international campaign to dissolve apartheid in South Africa. That could not be achieved bilaterally; it could not be achieved by unilateral action on the part of countries, however well intentioned—and I refer to Canada and India, as well as Australia. It required concerted international action.

If we take a circumstance such as the continued abuse of human rights in Burma, where Australia has continually urged multilateral action, it has only been in very recent times with ASEAN post-ministerial consultations that Australia could achieve broad agreement on a range of policy propositions directed to ensuring that change could be effected in that country. The experience is there.

I take issue with Senator Spindler to the extent that he tended to brush aside the issue of concealment. That issue is very real. No-one should be under any doubt about the fact that concealment of this obscene trade is intrinsic to its continuation; concealment is intrinsic to it flourishing. Where it is identified and exposed, measures can be taken, international pressures can be applied and it can be brought to an end. Concealment is central to the continuation of the abuse of these youngsters.
Bearing those remarks in mind, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph (b), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

(b)calls on the Australian Government to continue to play an active role in developing within the international community effective measures to eliminate such exploitation of children, and asks the Government to report to the Senate during the sitting week starting 7 November 1994 on the effective action the Australian Government can take to give effect to the concerns of the Australian people on this matter.

I think there is a fairly narrow area of disagreement between the proposition as amended by Senator Spindler and the amendment I have moved on behalf of the government. I stress the use of the word `effective'. It may be that a simple legislative approach turns out to be too narrow. There may be other means that can be adopted in concert with the trade union movement, the business community, the media, multi-lateral agencies and through international pressure whereby more can be achieved than by simply carrying a law in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I should stress that Australia is a strong supporter of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. We were closely involved in the development of the convention itself. It was adopted in 1989 and we ratified it a little over a year later in September of 1990. The task before us is to translate that into concrete action.

The convention imposes an obligation on the parties to it to take such legislative and other action with respect to children within their own jurisdiction as is appropriate to bringing an end to the kind of abuse we are debating this afternoon. Obviously, the government is totally committed to that.

More broadly, we are also concerned with abuses of children wherever such abuses occur internationally. But I reinforce Senator McMullan's observation at question time yesterday: the key to a responsible approach on this matter is not just feeling good about what we say—about our rhetoric; it is a matter of actually achieving good, of actually seeing concrete accomplishment.

The government is taking particular steps to support the improvement of labour conditions in our region—obviously, that has to be a priority and it is—and that includes those circumstances that pertain to child labour. There are a number of programs but, in particular, there is Australian support for the ILO objectives in Asia program, ASILO. For example, in Vietnam, the program is directed towards strengthening the relationship between labour laws and practices with an aim to ratifying international labour conventions on workplace safety, developing industrial hygiene practices, introducing industrial relations practices more generally and strengthening legitimate worker bodies.

In Indonesia there is a memorandum of understanding on cooperation on industrial relations issues signed in 1993 which provides a framework for cooperation on issues affecting child labour. That is a matter where there has been a positive response.

From my own perspective, I have much sympathy with introducing the social clause into the new world trading arrangements, particularly relating to labour standards and environmental measures. I say that quite openly. But I do not simply dismiss Prime Minister Goh's remarks the other night that that clause may potentially be exploited by neo-protectionists; that it may well prove to be a weapon for protectionists operating under a new guise. I support the clause but I think we need to be careful about the manner in which people may seek to use it for ends not consistent with the spirit of it.

Senator Spindler also tended to brush aside the key concept of poverty. There is no doubt in my mind that there was more than a grain of truth in Senator McMullan's observation about poverty alleviation being a crucial response in the reduction of the problems of child labour abuses and the appalling conditions in plants in which children are currently working, particularly in our region.

Poverty alleviation is a key objective of the Australian aid program in promoting sustainable economic and social advancement of people in developing countries; particularly those more vulnerable groups such as women and children. The Australian government's program includes support for activities which expand the range of employment and income earning opportunities as well as measures which build human resource and institutional capacities across all sectors of society, particularly in respect of health and education.

I will give just a couple of examples to advance the argument in the chamber this afternoon. In partner countries, for example, basic education for children and adults is a priority area, as identified by UNICEF. Total expenditure on primary and secondary education activities through the aid program in 1992-93 was of the order of $15 1/2 million. Another program involves support for an income generating project in Thailand implemented by ECPAT, End Child Prostitution in Asian Tourism, through the small assistance scheme administered by our embassy in Bangkok. A further program involves a current assessment of a larger longer term ECPAT project through its South-East Asia regional program aimed at eliminating child prostitution in Asia. I can think of few more worthwhile examples.

I do not think it is in question that Australia is a strong supporter of key ILO conventions pertaining to child labour, freedom from forced or compulsory labour, freedom of association, freedom from discrimination, the right to organise and bargain collectively, and certain absolute minimum work conditions. Currently, the government is consulting with the states and territories as a matter of priority so that we can proceed to ratification of the ILO's minimum age convention No. 138 which deals with the issue of child labour comprehensively. That is a concrete example of the kind of action that we have taken and are taking.

Australia looks, with good reason, to the International Labour Organisation having the central role in strengthening adherence to internationally recognised labour standards and continually supports proposals to make the ILO more effective, in not only our region but globally. With regard to child labour, Australia is monitoring the ILO International Program on the Elimination of Child Labour, IPEC, which was launched in 1992.

IPEC mobilises at grassroots the forces best placed to translate ILO principles into practice—governments, employers, worker and non-government organisations in the field. The government is currently considering means by which it can contribute to the program. Measures include support for efforts to put an end to intolerable situations such as the employment of children who are very young or in hazardous occupations or working under slavery conditions.

I add a personal note by saying that I was very moved by the report that Senator Spindler read from the Chicago Tribune. I doubt whether any senator in this place could have failed to have been moved. It is an absolute disgrace that in 1994 on this planet such things occur, regardless of where they occur. But again it comes back, in my view, to the best means of addressing the problem.

In terms of IPEC, the Australian government currently is also looking at information and awareness measures to try to change attitudes and behavioural patterns and the effective ways that that might be accomplished. It is also considering further measures which, without explicitly targeting child labour, nonetheless act very directly on the underlying causes—unemployment, poverty, inadequate social protection and educational systems and passive acceptance in the host countries of this appalling problem. I think it is fair to say that programs already in place and to which reference was made a little earlier have already served to contribute to the aims of IPEC, and the government intends to contribute further.

The Australian government supports the improvement of labour standards in our region, including those pertaining to child labour, through a number of other programs—in particular, through one to which I referred very early in my remarks, the Australian support for ILO objectives in Asia, ASILO, program. This program began in 1993 with over $1 million committed to activities in China, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam. It is a project with a tripartite basis, with resources drawn from the ACTU and the Australian Chamber of Industry and Commerce.

In Vietnam and Indonesia there are endeavours already under way. Taking a broader perspective: in China the program is directed at strengthening China's ability to implement the provisions of conventions relating to construction safety, developing industrial hygiene practices and normalising industrial relations practices in a general sense.

In Malaysia, on the other hand, the program is directed at strengthening Malaysia's capacity to address issues of chemical safety and occupational health and safety as well as structures for remuneration and productivity based wages. In Thailand, similarly, the program addresses issues of industrial hygiene and occupational health and safety. These are concrete steps in place. The important point in such cooperative programs is that they greatly enhance the access and influence of Australian labour practitioners and, from that, greater acceptance of a range of labour related issues, including moves to abolish unacceptable child labour practices.

I will conclude my remarks on the note with which I began. I doubt that anyone in the chamber would argue that Senator Spindler is wrong to raise the issue and to canvass it comprehensively in the chamber this afternoon. There is no doubt that the debate is necessary and focuses on a very real concern. But in terms of a response, a comprehensive response is what we require. That is why I believe the amendment which I have moved on behalf of the government is a better way of the Senate seeking to address the problem by having the government, as Senator Spindler asked, come back by 7 November with propositions on how we in Australia might effectively respond—not by simply focusing on the aspect of legislation but, within the context of a range of measures, including legislation. The government can come back to the chamber and say that the nature and scale of the problem are such and it requires a comprehensive answer, thereby making specific recommendations to the Senate. For that reason, I commend the proposition which I have moved by way of amendment this afternoon to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler has raised a topic of importance today asking that the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . re-affirms Australia's opposition to the economic exploitation of children . . . recognise the right of the child to be protected from economic exploitation and from performing any work that is likely to be hazardous or to interfere with the child's education, or to be harmful to the child's health or physical, mental, spiritual, moral or social development.

As Senator Loosley has said, I do not think anybody in this chamber would disagree with the sentiments in Senator Spindler's motion. I believe there would be few Australians who, irrespective of whether we have signed an international convention or not, would not support the sentiment of this motion that we abhor exploitation of children in any form, whether it be sexual exploitation or economic exploitation. I am sure that we would have to go a long way to find somebody in Australia who would disagree with that statement.

PARA.TAB: Child labour is probably the most pernicious form of child abuse. It is to be condemned because it robs children of the building blocks of a healthy and positive adulthood. When a child is forced into labour, it usually means that that child is unable to experience the activities that we see young children here in Australia having the opportunity to enjoy, such as playing, growing and of learning through play. All that is taken away when a child is forced into labour.

I am sure that those of us in this chamber who are child psychologists—there seems to be an ever increasing number of people who have had some experience in psychology, especially in developmental psychology, coming into parliament—would agree from our professional point of view, and I do not want to speak for the Acting Deputy President but I am sure she would agree, that that early part of childhood when a child plays and experiences freedom and the opportunity to enjoy life without having to work for no pay or for pay is a time when their adulthood and the building blocks of their adult life are being constructed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The parents would certainly agree.

—I am sure parents would agree. I am sure that Senator Zakharov would agree with me, although she has not nodded her head, and she is not in a position to do so. I am sure that if she were speaking on this, she would agree that that period of life is very important for later development. We may think that is a foregone conclusion, but one only has to read our own literature and look at our own heritage to see that people did not always believe that. They thought that children were little adults, that they could work and that it did not have any effect on their later development. It was with hindsight and understanding about child development that we realised it was important that children have love and the opportunity to play, because we discovered what children learn through those activities. So it is not something that we have always known.

PARA.TAB: It is always very easy to be critical of others when, in fact, we only have to look at Dickens and some of the child labour that went on in Britain to know that even within our own culture that has happened. The Director-General of the ILO, Michel Hansenne, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Childhood is a period of life which should be devoted, not to work but to education and training.

I would add, `and to play'. I would also add that it should be a period when there is time and opportunity to grow physically, socially and emotionally and to play and enjoy a real childhood. I agree with the rest of his statement, which says:

Child labour, by its very nature and the working conditions in which it is carried out, often compromises children's potential to become productive and useful adults in society; finally, the use of child labour is not inevitable, and progress toward its elimination is possible whenever there is political will to oppose it with determination.

Millions of children around the world are involved in child labour, and it would appear that the numbers are growing. There are millions of child-bonded labourers—children who are kidnapped to be imprisoned in sweatshops or brothels, millions who work unseen in domestic service who are given or sold at a very early age to another family and often receive little or no pay and have no control over their lives. In many cases, neither do their parents.

PARA.TAB: My colleagues Senator Spindler and Senator Loosley have outlined some cases of exploitation of child labour. In looking at this issue, I have read about children as young as six from poor rural families in some countries who are sold or given to better off families to work in involuntary servitude. I have read about cases in Thailand where there have been numerous allegations of widespread use of forced child labour for labour intensive workshops and the child sex industry.

I was recently talking to somebody from one of the Asian countries who said that as Thailand tightens up its laws, we will see some of the sex tourism shifting to other Asian countries where the rules are less tight. We have to be very vigilant to ensure that when one country tightens its rules, there is not a shift to another country where the rules are less tight, thus affording the opportunity to exploit children.

A couple of weeks ago I read a book written by an Irish woman who was a street child in Dublin. I cannot remember the name of this book and I do not think anybody in the chamber would be able to help me. This woman recently visited Australia. She has been working in Vietnam. One only has to read that story to hear some of the tragic cases of child exploitation. She lives with and works amongst homeless children. It is a very sad story. She was a homeless child and an abused wife. As a young woman, she had a dream that she wanted to help children in Vietnam, and she believed that she could make that dream come true.

She went to Vietnam with almost no money, and she finally convinced various authorities that she would set up facilities for homeless young children, in particular children of a very young age—four, five and six. After hearing her talk about extracting children from hotels at the age of four and five when they had been enticed into the hotel room by people wanting to exploit them, one realises that it happens and it is often perpetrated by people not from the developing countries. So it happens and it shifts from one country to another. I would love to remember the name of the book so I could recommend it to honourable senators, because it is a very salutary book.

As I have said, in Thailand and rural areas, child capturers and recruiters travel around taking children from poor families. At the same time, certain shops in cities specialise in selling children and teenagers. In January 1992, the Thai government reported to the ILO that it had filed charges against the owner of a sweatshop in Bangkok where 31 workers aged between nine and 20 were employed making paper cups. Senator Spindler referred to that example. It was reported that some of the children had been rescued, and they had been so badly beaten that they could hardly walk. They had all been forced to work 18-hour days, sitting on a cement floor to fill their daily quota, and they were never allowed to leave the sweatshop.

As Thailand tightens up its conditions of employment, especially those applying to children, we may see—especially if there are multinational corporations employing children—those people with wealth who are setting up the companies, and even people from those countries, moving to other countries where the rules are less tight. So we need to be vigilant.

There are other stories where one reads about children as young as six in Colombia working in coal mines. Senator Spindler has outlined examples of children working in carpet factories in Nepal and India. One such story that I read was about a young boy of eight years of age in Bihar state, India. This would have been in 1991. He was working as a cowherd for 20 rupees, about US78c at that stage, when a carpet manufacturer came along. In an article about this case, there is a quote from the young boy. He said:
They told my father that your son will get good clothing, good food, plus Rs 350 a month . . .

SPEECH.PARA: So his father said, `Okay,' and three of the children from that family went off to work for the carpet manufacturer. They spent the first two months without pay and, if they were slow, they were beaten very hard with sticks on the back. The young boy said, `They used to lock us up at night.'

PARA.TAB: After six months, the young boys got a letter out. Somebody literate who was working with them got a letter out to their father to tell him what was happening and that they were not getting paid. The father came down and the carpet manufacturer said, `We will pay them in the long run. We will pay them in two months, and we will send them back with their pay.' That did not ever happen and the boys escaped. They were picked up by a welfare organisation and, under the legislation that now exists in India, they were released. The young boy was interviewed, and he was asked what he wanted to do now that he had been released. He said, `I want to go to school.'

That is just one example of where parents were tricked into believing that these young people were going to be paid—whether or not they were paid is another thing. Not only were the parents cajoled into letting their children go into the work force, but they were not paid for it. So it is exploitation at its very worst form in that situation.

A study in the Far Eastern Economic Review in July 1992 reported that children as young as six were working in appalling conditions in carpet factories and tea plantations in India. It also stated that child workers in India typically worked from 5 a.m. to 7 p.m. with half an hour for lunch and would sometimes work until midnight. Payment was on a piece rate. Food was normally watery. There was also a high incidence of TB, worm infestations, skin ulcers and enlarged lymph glands and physical and verbal abuse was routine.

I think we have to be very careful that we do not miss the mote in our own eye when we are looking at the splinter in our neighbour's eye. I do not think that child labour occurs only in developing countries. I believe that if we were to search we would also find examples in the developed countries, such as the United Kingdom, the United States and even, dare I say it, Australia. We also need to be aware that some of this child labour can be directly or indirectly through multinationals controlled by western countries which are either wittingly or unwittingly involved in child labour.

That places me in some difficulty with Senator Spindler's first motion: it may not be possible because there may be hidden exploitation which we cannot identify. I think Senator Loosley referred to that. Even with legislation prohibiting the importation of products made using child labour, we cannot always be sure that we are not purchasing or importing products where the fact that children are exploited in the processing of that product is hidden. We have to try to find other methods of indicating to the international community our view that the use of child labour and the exploitation of children is totally unacceptable.

While I support the sentiment behind a move to prohibit importation of goods produced by child labour, as I have indicated it is not that easy to implement. It is difficult to place and police restrictions on importing goods produced by child labour both in Australia and in the originating country.

I do not claim to be an expert on child labour and the exploitation of children—I am glad Senator Spindler has raised this matter because it makes me and my colleagues more aware of it—but I read a document this afternoon whilst researching this matter that said, `Let them bring in legislation. We can tell them that we are not employing children and we can get away with it.' I guess we have to change the culture and indicate that it is unacceptable worldwide to exploit children.

As I said before, we cannot look at the splinter in our neighbour's eye and not look for the mote in our own. Currently in Australia we have 70,000 young homeless people, we have acts of violence against young people that would have been totally unknown in the time in which we were growing up, and we have a youth unemployment rate which is totally unacceptable.

While we look at some of our neighbours and ask them to address some of the issues that they need to look at, we also need to call on our own government to look at some of the issues which are affecting young people in this country, because we stand condemned and this government stands condemned in the way it has dealt with its own youth in the areas of homelessness, violence against our children and in youth unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank both Senator Loosley and Senator Patterson for their contributions. I am particularly pleased that both speakers representing the government and the coalition parties expressed such strong support for the basic issue that I have raised and for the need to continue action, to the extent that we have taken action—it has not been much in the past—and to determinedly now take urgent action to put an end to child exploitation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Loosley suggested that the government would prefer a different version of paragraph (b) of my motion. However, during the closing stages of Senator Loosley's speech the representatives of the government, the coalition parties and I had a look at the wording in an attempt to get a unanimous resolution from the Senate on this extremely important issue. We thought we should not be thwarted in achieving what I would say is an historic agreement on the urgency of action to be taken by quibbling over a few words. I am happy to say that we have arrived at a version that is acceptable to all parties. I will seek leave to amend the amendment that has been agreed upon.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Loosley, I seek leave to withdraw the amendment moved by him.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that we will be supporting the amended amendment of Senator Spindler's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move an amendment to paragraph (b) of my motion.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (b), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: (b)calls on the Australian government to play an active role in developing within the international community effective measures to eliminate exploitation of children and to examine the feasibility of legislation to prohibit the importation of goods produced by child labour and to report to the Senate in the sitting week commencing 7 November 1994.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)supports the comments made by the former Prime Minister, Mr Gough Whitlam, that the World Heritage wilderness of Hinchinbrook Island should be protected and that the Government should think very carefully before reaching any decision on the area;
(b)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the letter of agreement signed by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the Queensland Office of Coordinator General states that there will be `full public disclosure of all information relating' to the Port Hinchinbrook development, and

(ii)the Department of Environment, Sport and Territories, in its portfolio response to the Queensland Environment Review Report states that `We believe the management agreement should be based on . . . public consultation and the document should be publicly available'; and

PARA.TAB: (c)calls on the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) to release the Peter Valentine report into world heritage values and the deed of agreement, in keeping with these two documents, prior to the Minister making a decision on the development.

SPEECH.PARA: In my motion I mentioned two reports which I believe should be in the public domain. These two reports were Deed of agreement, which would reveal that the Queensland government is hell-bent on getting the Port Hinchinbrook development up and running.

PARA.TAB: I suspect that it is quite prepared to pursue a high risk strategy, gambling with the conservation of World Heritage values in order to get this development off the ground. I believe the role of the Queensland government in this development needs to be fully exposed. The environmental assessment process has been a complete sham. It was taken out of the hands of the environment and heritage department and put into the hands of the Office of the Coordinator General.

The Office of the Coordinator General is a fast-tracking unit. Its proper role in some circumstances is to promote development in Queensland. However, it perceives environmental laws as an obstacle to development. It is totally inappropriate for the Queensland government to give responsibility for the environmental assessment of this project to a development agency rather than an environmental agency. Not only that, but the Office of the Coordinator General is arrogant and even antagonistic towards conservation agencies.

Let me give the Senate an example. I will quote from a document produced by the Office of the Coordinator General which gives reasons for the conflict between developers and the wet tropics administration. It makes clear that its sympathies and support lie with development as defined by it. Some of the criticisms it levels are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The principal reason for the conflict outlined above is the fact that the Authority—
that is, the wet tropics administration—

is a single purpose organisation; it focuses on its charter of rainforest preservation and feels no responsibility for economic development in the area. One aspect of its charter—the presentation of the WHA—could be viewed as compatible with promotion of the tourism industry in the Cairns region. However, this task is pursued less energetically than are those of protection and conservation.

While some Authority members are far from extreme in their views on reasonable development projects, they are somewhat constrained in the action they can take since the Authority's charter says nothing about the economic development of the area.
There are strong personalities on the Authority with deeply committed anti-development beliefs who often manage to persuade other members to adopt their views on issues.

The recruitment of staff for the Agency has ensured that most are also prejudiced against development, seeing themselves as having little or no responsibility for the strengthening of the economic base of the area.

If the Office of the Coordinator General has that attitude towards the environment and the environmental agencies of the Queensland government, it is little wonder that one would question its environmental credentials in preparing the environmental report on the Hinchinbrook area.

PARA.TAB: The Office of the Coordinator General took control of the Port Hinchinbrook assessment. It took staff and resources out of Molly Robson's office and put them into the Office of the Coordinator General. The Queensland environment minister has been left out in the cold on this development—and, I believe, for deliberate reasons. The Office of the Coordinator General, with input from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, has produced what has been called an environmental review report. This report is supposed to be an environmental impact assessment. I fear that it is a very poor imitation of such an assessment. I will quote from the response from the federal Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories to the Queensland government's environmental report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Environment Portfolio remains concerned about the project proceeding at this time as there is insufficient information to justify the need for the development and to properly assess its environmental impacts.

The federal department was critical of the poor attempt at environmental assessment carried out by the Office of the Coordinator General. It is indicative of the superficial regard it gives to environmental concerns.

PARA.TAB: The federal department recommended that a statement of the natural and cultural values of the area should be prepared. It should include values relating to world heritage and national estate significance; the importance of the area as habitat for endangered and migratory species; and the cultural relevance of the area to the local Aboriginal community. The federal department recommended that the statement should assist the Queensland authorities to prepare a more comprehensive impact assessment of the proposal. It would also fulfil more effectively the first undertaking of the letter of agreement between the Office of the Coordinator General and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I will quote part of that undertaking:

SPEECH.PARA: the environmental impact assessment for the project will adequately take into account the possible impacts the project may have on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

Yet the Office of the Coordinator General has done neither of these two things. Indeed, it has refused to develop a more comprehensive environmental assessment. It has refused to develop a statement of natural and cultural values and instead it has thumbed its nose at the federal government and proceeded with the finalisation of a deed of agreement between the Office of the Coordinator General, the Cardwell Shire and the developer. The deed of agreement is a legal document which should have been prepared after the proposal was agreed to and after the publication of a full environmental impact assessment. I believe it is outrageous that the Queensland government has so flouted due process.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, Senator Ian Macdonald questioned the integrity of Peter Valentine and the report he has produced for Senator Faulkner. I must say that I fully support the comments made by Senator Reynolds concerning the qualifications and international experience of Mr Valentine. I would like to question the assumptions made in the Loder and Bayly report. Page 4 of the report lists a set of assumptions. I will quote from the assumptions:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this assessment it was assumed that:

.a high standard of environmental control and monitoring will be effected and that appropriate financial and human resources will be allocated with sufficient legal support to ensure that impacts are kept within the limits of acceptable change.
It also says:
.effective independent environmental auditing with real incentives/disincentives to ensure that it is not expedient or cheaper to accept impacts and pay a small fine.

How can we assume that independent monitoring and auditing to a very high degree will be carried out when the assessment process is so flawed? Unfortunately, the Queensland government has a history of choosing consultants who will tell it what it wants to hear. Given that, it is revealing that the Loder and Bayly report does state that a number of impacts will occur in the Great Barrier Reef world heritage area. It is interesting that they are prepared to admit as much.

PARA.TAB: They admit that there will be minimal direct impact on the values associated with the Great Barrier Reef world heritage area, direct impact on national estate values, and minimal direct impact on endangered and migratory species. They say there is a moderate risk of direct impact from the initial canal dredging operation and subsequent maintenance dredging operations. Given the very narrow framework and terms of reference, even the Queensland government's report admits that there will be impacts, although it qualifies these as being minimal.

I believe the Goss government has been deliberately irresponsible in managing this project. The environmental assessment should have been managed by the Department of Environment and Heritage, which was, instead, frozen out of the process. The release of the Peter Valentine final report would reveal that there are serious concerns over world heritage values on account of this development. I call on the minister to release this report along with the deed of agreement. The minister should approach the Premier of Queensland, who is responsible for the Office of the Coordinator General, as it is the Office of the Coordinator General which is making decisions on this matter, not the Queensland minister for the environment, Molly Robson. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating an issue which is very important, not just for the environment in North Queensland, at Cardwell in the Hinchinbrook area. There are principles at stake that we have to address seriously in terms of environmental issues being decided on the best possible basis of information so that we get solutions that combine federal, state and local government working together, rather than federal government deciding one way, state government deciding another and poor old local government, as usual, effectively being left to pick up the pieces.

PARA.TAB: We are talking, remember, about world heritage. We are talking about an area that has very special values, not just at the local, state or national level but internationally. The Australian government has ultimate responsibility for making the best possible decision to protect world heritage values.

I would like to quote from a book that was written and prepared by Arthur and Margaret Thorsborne. The Thorsbornes are well known in North Queensland. They are well known in the Cardwell community because they were responsible for gaining the understanding of many bushwalkers and many environmentalists in relation to the values of this unique region. I might just read some words of Margaret Thorsborne in opening my contribution to this debate. She states:

When we first visited Hinchinbrook in 1964, seeing another boat was a rare occurrence and it was only on a few occasions that anyone else camped at the same time as we did. At that time, as the island first touched our lives we felt secure in the discovery of a wild and beautiful world and gloried in the knowledge that as a national park it would always be so.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose what concerns many of us is how we can ensure that the values of Hinchinbrook—these very special, now recognised world heritage values—can be protected in the way that Arthur and Margaret Thorsborne first saw as being so necessary as long ago as 1964.

PARA.TAB: I think it is appropriate to mention at this time a book that was launched this week—it has been quite a week for book launches—entitled The Reluctant Nation: Environment Law and Politics in Australia by Phillip Toyne. I believe that Phillip Toyne's book will dramatically change and certainly influence for many years to come the debate about the environment, environmental law practice and the behaviour of local, state and federal government in this country. It will be a very significant debate in the coming years. I would like to quote from chapter 1 of his book. Honourable senators might wonder how this has anything to do with Hinchinbrook, but I hope they will see that it does. Chapter 1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Imagine for a moment that you are a green turtle trying to come to grips with Australia's constitutional arrangements. You are a female, swimming in international waters but heading for an island on the Great Barrier Reef to lay your eggs. You enter Australia's exclusive economic zone 200 miles off the coast; you enter Australia's national waters 12 miles off the coast; as you approach the reef you enter the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park which is the joint responsibility of the Commonwealth and Queensland governments. While in the sea of the Marine Park, approaching the island, the waters are Commonwealth (unless you are within three miles of the coastline, but outside the Park, in which case you are in State waters). But once you climb slowly onto the sand and above the low water mark, you come under the jurisdiction of Queensland. You would need to be a very astute turtle to work out which law is responsible for your protection because the Commonwealth and Queensland have different opinions regarding the definition of low water in relation to an island on a coral reef.

PARA.TAB: This complexity is not unique to the Australian sea, to Queensland or to turtles. But it is a reflection of the extraordinary system of federalism we have in Australia, where powers are reluctantly surrendered by the States and assumed by the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, that introduction to Phillip Toyne's book highlights the complexity of the debate that we are having in relation to whether or not, or indeed in what form, Keith Williams's proposal at Oyster Point should proceed.

PARA.TAB: The decision is not just that of the developers, the local council, the state government or the federal government. We have to work those four interests, including that of Keith Williams, into a decision that is appropriate to protect the unique World Heritage values of Hinchinbrook. Of course, we could give other examples, as does Phillip Toyne in his book when he says:

Perhaps the most significant development in this respect is the increasing number of international measures being initiated by nations aware that many environment problems now require multi-national responses.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a party to many of these international measures, such as the world heritage convention, the biodiversity convention, trade in protected species, the controlling of whaling, and those protecting migratory birds. There are many other international measures with more being prepared, such as the convention to combat desertification around the globe. These will add to the increasing range of issues under which the Commonwealth will have international obligations, even if they would normally fall exclusively within the responsibility of the state.

PARA.TAB: A good example mentioned by Phillip Toyne would be the approval of a tourist resort on the coast. This would usually be a state matter. But, if the site chosen were the habitat of migratory birds which each year fly the length of the Pacific, our treaty obligations with Japan to protect both the birds and their habitat might be involved. Of course, in relation to Hinchinbrook, I come back to this being World Heritage and we have to ensure that we protect this unique region.

There has been a lot of debate about how much support there has been and how much work the state government and the federal government have each done, whether or not we should be listening to the Queensland government's consultants or to Peter Valentine. I have already placed on the public record the international reputation of the federal government's consultant whose field of expertise is eco-tourism and the protection of World Heritage values. I now just remind the Senate of the concerns that were originally raised with the Queensland government, and I would stress that they come back to the Office of the Coordinator General where I believe there was a misunderstanding about the extent of its authority in the area.
I have here a letter which was sent to the Office of the Coordinator General on 3 June 1994. In the letter, the conclusion that the assistant secretary of the world heritage unit came to was:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Environment Portfolio remains concerned about the project proceeding at this time as there is insufficient information to justify the need for the development and to properly assess its environmental impacts.

The Portfolio believes that the documentation inadequately considers the potential impacts of the Oyster Point proposal on the World Heritage values of the area. We recommend that a much more comprehensive assessment of the proposal be undertaken before any approvals are granted for the continuation of work on the project.

What happened then was that the Queensland government, to its credit, did seek out a consultant, but I have not seen any more than a couple of pages of the work of that consultant and its final conclusions. Senator Macdonald has quoted in this place that Loder and Bayly were, effectively, unimpressed with the argument that has been put up by the Commonwealth and, indeed, by Peter Valentine. But I think what we have to ask ourselves is: where is that report; has it been open to public scrutiny? No. I have seen a couple of pages, but where is the detail so that we can analyse and make judgments for ourselves on the degree of expertise had by the Queensland government consultants?

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I understand that a very comprehensive response to the Valentine report is with the federal minister at this moment together with a draft agreement. The Queensland government has already put together a draft agreement before the federal minister has had a chance to assess these reports and to sit down and work this issue out around the table with Mr Williams, with state government and with local government. It is this pre-empting that sometimes occurs in state governments and in local governments that we have to address in the way that Phillip Toyne has challenged us to in his book. The environment does not just stop and the impacts do not just stop because we have created state and, indeed, local government boundaries. That criterion should be assessed.

We need to get an approach that involves the three levels of government. We need to be open in our debate. We need to ensure that we not only recognise the short-term needs of the community—a tourist resort next year—but also recognise what is needed to protect this unique area for the next 20, 50, 100 years and more. We have to start taking the long-term view. It is a matter of ensuring that those unique values are protected.

I hope that all the material relating to Hinchinbrook will very soon be open to public scrutiny. I hope the draft agreement that Queensland has put forward will also be open to public scrutiny because we cannot have issues of such significance decided by bureaucrats and others behind closed doors. We have to ensure that the public has the opportunity to assess how effectively these decisions have been taken. The Australian electorate expects this high level of scrutiny. The Australian Nature Conservation Agency is very concerned as a result of the confusion between state and territory laws and how they conflict with federal responsibilities. This has prompted some market research. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a clear majority of Australians believe that the Commonwealth should have the power to fix national problems in the environment. 73 percent believe that the Commonwealth should set uniform standards for air and water pollution. 68 percent believe it should protect plants and animal species, and 62 percent believe it should set uniform standards for soil and land degradation. A minority—between 25 and 35 percent believe these matters should be left to the States.

Therefore, in assessing what is needed in terms of decision-making at Hinchinbrook, Australians seem to believe that the Commonwealth has more power over the environment than is sometimes assumed by state and local government authorities.

PARA.TAB: Finally, one of the major issues that has to be addressed about this proposed development—aside from the world heritage values—is where the local water supply is coming from. I do not believe that the Cardwell Shire Council has been able to convince many people that there will be an adequate water supply to service such a resort, unless a dam is ultimately proposed in world heritage listed area in the hills behind Cardwell. In that instance, we would have to go through the same debate that we are going through at the moment. So I urge caution on all sides. I urge open debate to ensure that all parties are involved and that we look to the future, not to short-term interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating Senator Woodley's motion No. 1077, which previous speakers have not specifically addressed. They have used it, perhaps appropriately, to have a general discussion about the Oyster Point development. However, I want to deal with the motion before the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Senator Woodley's motion is in three parts. First of all, it asks the Senate to support some comments made by a former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, about the protection of the world heritage wilderness of Hinchinbrook Island. It also says that the government should think very carefully before reaching any decision on the area. Secondly, the motion asks the Senate to note various reports on the matter. Thirdly, it calls upon the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, to release the Peter Valentine report.

Generally speaking, the coalition supports the motion, although we have some difficulty with the wording of paragraph (a). As I said, it asks us to support some comments made by a former Prime Minister, Mr Gough Whitlam. I would be very reluctant to agree with anything that Gough Whitlam said, particularly when Senator Woodley has not informed the Senate of exactly what was said.

I refer to an article in the Townsville Bulletin by a very respected and accurate journalist, Michael Madigan. This article reports on that incident, although it gives only extracts; it does not give a transcript of what Mr Whitlam said. The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Whitlam said, while he did not have all the information surrounding the area and the Oyster Point tourist development proposed, he had "no doubt" the World Heritage wilderness of Hinchinbrook Island should be protected . . .

So Mr Whitlam is admitting that he really does not know much about it. As I said, asking the Senate to agree with anything that Mr Whitlam has said would be a danger, particularly when he has commented on something which he admits that he knows little about. I would have thought the better route to follow would be to delete paragraph (a) of Senator Woodley's motion and replace it with the words `supports the protection of Hinchinbrook Island'. Senator Woodley's motion further reads:
. . . the Government should think very carefully before reaching any decision on the area . . .

I would hope that the government would think very carefully before reaching a decision on any matter. Again, asking this government to think carefully on any matter is a bit like asking us to support anything that Mr Whitlam has said: it is just something that we would not imagine that it would do. Again, I do not think that will mean much in the motion.

PARA.TAB: I have supplied to the other parties in the chamber copies of my amendment, which seeks to delete paragraph (a) of Senator Woodley's motion and substitute the words `supports the protection of Hinchinbrook Island'. Senator Woodley has indicated to me privately that he is happy enough with that. If that is the case, then it seems that we all agree.

I wonder why the Australian Democrats chose to have this motion debated today. Yesterday, both Senator Kernot and Senator Woodley quoted at some length from the Peter Valentine report. As far as I know, the Peter Valentine report is confidential. It has not been released. In fact, this motion is calling for its release. I wonder how the Democrats came to have a copy of the Peter Valentine report. Unfortunately, I was too slow to move that Senator Kernot table the document from which she was quoting yesterday, but I was able to do so with Senator Woodley.

As I recall, Senator Kernot was quoting from quite a thick document; it was not just the three pages from which Senator Woodley was quoting and which he tabled as a result of my motion in the Senate yesterday. The Senate may be aware that this morning I gave notice that, on the next day of sitting, I will move a motion requiring Senator Kernot to table the Peter Valentine report which she appeared to have in her hand yesterday. I ask Senator Coulter: how has a confidential report that has not been publicly released ended up in the hands of the Australian Democrats?

One could be excused for agreeing with me that this simply shows that the Australian Democrats are part of the mates network, part of the Labor Party, part of the left wing group that is currently running Australia. It would seem that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, or someone in his department, has made a copy of the Peter Valentine report available to the Australian Democrats. Maybe that is not true. Maybe Senator Woodley will indicate to me where he got it from.

It would seem that if it is a confidential report, and one that has not been released, someone has some explaining to do as to where that came from. As far as I am aware, the only people who would have a copy of that report are Mr Peter Valentine and Senator Faulkner and his department. If the Democrats have a copy of the report, it can have come from only one of three places: from Mr Valentine, from Senator Faulkner or from his department. In any event, it would be outrageous if any of those three leaked a copy of a confidential report to the government to one particular political party while ignoring the other political parties.

My notice of motion, which hopefully will be debated on the next day of sitting, requires Senator Faulkner to explain why he or his department or Mr Valentine gave a copy of that report to the Australian Democrats and not to us. It also calls upon the minister to share his largesse equally by making a copy of that report available to us.

With the amendment that I propose moving, the coalition is happy enough for the Senate to agree that Hinchinbrook Island should be protected. There has never been any doubt about that. Perhaps of all of us in the chamber, I know Hinchinbrook Island the best. A year or so ago I was fortunate enough to be able to take a houseboat through the Hinchinbrook channel. It is a quite magnificent area. Certainly it is an area that must be protected. I do not think anyone would hesitate with that proposition at all.

However, I insist that all Australians be given the opportunity of experiencing the beauty and emotion of that magnificent area. We will never do that if we lock away those very beautiful areas of Australia. We agree that it is a beautiful area and that it needs protection. We have always been a political party that believes in protection of the natural environment. Our record on the environment is second to none. We have only to mention Fraser Island, which Liberal governments were instrumental in protecting.

We agree with the first part of the motion. The second part of the motion calls upon Senator Faulkner to release a copy of the report and some other documents, and we agree with that. I have given a notice of motion myself to require it. I do not know why the Democrats are bringing this motion on. Between Monday, when they first gave notice of the motion, and today, when it is being debated, they somehow seem to have been given a copy of the report.

I want to make a couple of comments on the documents that were tabled by Senator Woodley yesterday as a result of my motion. It would appear that Mr Valentine is suggesting that the whole boundaries of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park or the wet tropics area should be amended. That is an interesting development. I wonder whether the minister is intending to do that and whether, if he does, he will get the consent of the Queensland Labor government?

The Senate might recall that when the boundaries of the wet tropics World Heritage area were set some years ago the Commonwealth government completely ignored the Queensland government and insisted on those boundaries in direct opposition to it. As I have always said, I do not think anyone objected to World Heritage listing of the wet tropics rainforest, but it should have been done cooperatively and in consultation.

Because the government is now going to change the boundaries, I wonder whether the minister will get the agreement of the Goss Labor government or whether he will ram it through. I understand that the minister, who is from the Left of the Labor Party, and the Goss right wing Labor government do not get on very well. So it will be interesting to see whether the current federal Labor government treats the current Queensland Labor government with the same disdain as the previous federal Labor government treated the previous non-Labor state government.

The summary of the report from Professor Valentine mentions the World Heritage values of the Hinchinbrook area. As I said, I know them only too well. Anyone who has been there would understand the absolute beauty and value of that area. Mr Valentine then lists 15 impacts of the Oyster Point development on the World Heritage values. As I said in the Senate yesterday, it is quite interesting that his report seems to say that there are 15 very direct impacts whereas the Loder and Bayly report that the Queensland government commissioned seems to say that there are nine only very possible impacts and that none of them are particularly significant.

In the Senate yesterday, Senator Reynolds went to some lengths to give the background of Professor Valentine's qualifications. I am sure the fact that Senator Reynolds's husband works with Professor Valentine has nothing do with it. I also know Professor Valentine; I meet him when I am at James Cook University.

I understand that Senator Reynolds is suggesting that the Loder and Bayly people are not qualified.
