I do not want to sing the praises of any particular group, but I have taken the trouble to get some details of the Loder and Bayly Consulting Group. It is a very professional and well-recognised consulting group in this area. Some of its clients include the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, the federal Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, the Gold Coast City Council, the Melbourne zoo, the Noosa Shire Council, the Wet Tropics Management Authority and the Urban Land Authority of Victoria. There is a page-long list of its clients. So, obviously, many people think it is very good.

Loder and Bayly has done some major indicative projects. I will mention just a couple of them. The wet tropics recreation strategy is one. The Mary River visitors action plan—the Mary River is part of Kakadu National Park, and the plan has had wide acceptance—is also one of the projects that Loder and Bayly was involved in. I do not want to delay the Senate by going through its long background at length. It is obviously very professional and well respected in this field.

In the course of yesterday's debate, Senator Woodley claimed that he had been threatened by Mr Williams. He was lucky enough to get one of the people in the press gallery to run his story; I think it appeared in the Australian Financial Review. According to Senator Woodley, it is in black and white that Mr Williams has threatened him.

Yesterday in the Senate, Senator Parer and others on this side challenged Senator Woodley to give us the details of the threat that had been made. We pointed out to Senator Woodley that there are certain protections of this parliament for parliamentarians who have been threatened. I have not heard from Senator Woodley since. I again say to him, `You should either tell us where Mr Williams threatened you and give us the evidence or you should publicly apologise to him.'

I am aware that Senator Woodley has had quite a bit of correspondence and contact with Mr Williams. Mr Williams has exposed him in the past for the inaccuracies that he has been mouthing to the press. Mr Williams has criticised Senator Woodley quite severely for coming into the cowards castle under parliamentary protection and telling untruths about him. He has invited Senator Woodley to speak outside the parliament. I do not think he has done that yet, although I understand that one of his colleagues did. As I understand it, she has been sued and will have the opportunity of showing whether she and Senator Woodley are right or whether Mr Williams is right.

I again invite Senator Woodley to let us have details of the threats made against him. I understand that Senator Woodley has written to Mr Williams a number of times. I wonder whether in any of Senator Woodley's correspondence to Mr Williams he at any stage put on record and in writing the details of the threat Mr Williams made against him or any complaints about the threat that Mr Williams may have made against him, or whether Senator Woodley has mentioned it in any of his correspondence to Mr Williams by referring to the threats that he has made. I also wonder whether Senator Woodley has invited Mr Williams to meet with him. If that is the case, I wonder whether that is the action of a parliamentarian who has been threatened by the man with whom he then seeks to have meetings.

So it seems that if Senator Woodley is to retain any credibility at all in this matter he must put up his evidence on just what the threat was by Mr Williams. Mr Williams has pointed out publicly that Senator Woodley went around saying the Mission Beach tourism authority was unanimously opposed to the Oyster Point development. Mr Williams quite rightly points out that, following Senator Woodley's claims, the Mission Beach tourism authority actually paid for advertisements to be put in a paper denying its opposition to the Port Hinchinbrook development. Again, that simply indicates that Senator Woodley comes in here and says anything he likes without any regard for the truth, so much so that the parties he quotes actually have to put in paid advertisements to refute some of the rubbish that he has said about this particular matter.

Senator Woodley has also roundly criticised Mr Williams about Hamilton Island. I have never met Mr Williams. I am not here to defend him. But, again, I understand Mr Williams, in correspondence to Senator Woodley, quite accurately pointed out the efforts that Mr Williams made to ensure that all creditors of the Hamilton Island project were looked after. I have not heard Senator Woodley correct his statement and apologise to Mr Williams in relation to those particular matters.

Senator Woodley says that Mr Williams threatened a Mr Arthur Bull of Cardwell. I think he said that in the paper or he mentioned it in this parliament. I am informed that Mr Bull and Mr Williams have had conversations and that Mr Bull has admitted to Mr Williams that he should not have made his statements and has actually apologised to Mr Williams in connection with that matter. Senator Woodley has also made some wild accusations about the permits Mr Williams sought—accusations that simply do not bear any reference at all to the facts of the matter.Hopefully, Senator Woodley will have some time at the end of this debate to respond. I await eagerly his answers to those particular matters.

In concluding, I will briefly refer to a couple of the matters raised by Senator Reynolds. She says that she has not read the Loder and Bayly report. Neither have I in any detail; I have not had a copy of it. It is a report commissioned by the Queensland government. The Queensland government was obviously quite happy with the Loder and Bayly report and it approved this development subject to environmental conditions. Again, I am not familiar with those environmental conditions. But I would assume that the Queensland government is a responsible government and one which can weigh up the tourist values, the jobs that will be created in this project and, at the same time, have an understanding and an appreciation of the sensitive environmental area that is the Hinchinbrook Island and the Hinchinbrook Channel.

One can only assume that the Queensland Labor government—Mr Goss's government—was responsible in its attitude to this, and I am prepared to accept that it was. I am prepared to accept that the Loder and Bayly report was relevant. I do not quite know what place the Commonwealth has in this. I have a copy of an advice from the Attorney-General to the federal government back in 1991, indicating that the Hinchinbrook Channel is outside the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth government and is, in fact, within the sole jurisdiction of the Queensland government. As I say, that is an opinion from the Commonwealth Attorney-General to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. So I again wonder what Senator Faulkner is doing in this, unless, as I have suggested before, it is simply part of the Labor Party indulging in its factional brawls and the left wing trying to pay back the Goss government for getting rid of the left wing president of the Labor Party in Queensland, and the left wing of the party and its mates in the Australian Democrats calling them to account.

Mr Tip Byrne, the mayor of the local shire council—the Cardwell Shire Council—is a lovely fellow and a good North Queenslander. He is a member of the Labor Party, but still a good man who does a good job in the Cardwell shire. I understand that, with some qualifications and conditions that the shire has imposed, it is pretty happy with the project. In the Senate yesterday, Senator Parer referred to a meeting in a hall in the small seaside town of Cardwell which over 1,000 people attended—something pretty unusual these days—to demonstrate their support for this particular proposal. I think that the Cardwell Chamber of Commerce wrote to all senators from Queensland correcting the mistakes that Senator Woodley and Senator Kernot have been guilty of and urging support from the Cardwell people for this particular project.

In arranging some informal times, we were allowing for Senator MacGibbon to speak. He has had to return to Brisbane and will not be able to speak here, so I have actually taken a bit of his time. In conclusion, the local authority seems to be in favour of it, the Queensland government seems to be in favour of it and certainly the people of the area are in favour of it. This is an area of very high unemployment and certainly, as a North Queenslander, I can say that we need the jobs—not only the jobs of construction but the jobs that the development itself will create in time to come. I think that everybody, except, if I might say, the loony Left down here in Canberra, is in favour of it.

I am not saying—and never have said—that that development should go ahead willy-nilly. Mr Williams has approvals already and, if he wanted to, he could start building tomorrow and ignore the rest of us; but he does not want to. He has asked for a new approval on a more sensitive development. I have always said—and certainly the coalition says—that there must be the most stringent environmental conditions imposed upon that development but, subject to those stringent environmental conditions, the development should go ahead for the jobs, for the export dollars and for the business activity and tourist dollars it will create.

I understand that the Queensland government has looked at it fully and has imposed the sensible environmental conditions. On that basis, one would think that the proposal should proceed. As far as the motion that we are debating today is concerned, as I indicated before, I will move my amendment and, subject to that amendment, the coalition will be supporting Senator Woodley's motion. I move:
Paragraph (a), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
"(a) supports the protection of Hinchinbrook Island;".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Ian Macdonald's amendment is to substantially change paragraph (a) of Senator Woodley's motion so as to remove any reference to Mr Gough Whitlam. That is not an amendment that I would be minded to support. Gough Whitlam was in Townsville on Friday 16 September to open the new offices of the North Queensland Conservation Council. I am aware of the comments that he made in relation to World Heritage in a general sense, and the Oyster Point development in particular.

PARA.TAB: If ever there was a person who was well qualified to speak about World Heritage matters, it is certainly Gough Whitlam. He is a former ambassador to UNESCO. He led many Australian delegations at meetings of the World Heritage Bureau and also the World Heritage Committee. During his time at UNESCO, the wet tropics in Queensland, Kakadu stage 2 and the New South Wales rainforests were inscribed on the World Heritage List. Turning to what Mr Whitlam is reported to have said, I am indebted to the Townsville Bulletin for reporting this. Mr Whitlam said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that while he did not have all the information surrounding the area and the Oyster Point tourist development proposed, he had `no doubt' the World Heritage wilderness of Hinchinbrook Island should be protected and maintained as a World Heritage area.

He is also reported as saying that the government had to act very carefully in reaching any decision affecting this area. As I have said time and again, when asked either in this chamber or in public about my role as the federal environment minister, I take very seriously my responsibilities in relation to ensuring the protection of World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: It might be useful in this debate to briefly outline the process that has been undertaken to date to ensure that proper consideration is given to ensuring the protection of the World Heritage values of the Hinchinbrook area and the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage listing. In June my department provided to the Queensland Department of the Coordinator-General a submission in relation to the proposal. My department engaged Dr Peter Valentine of the James Cook University in North Queensland to undertake an investigation of the World Heritage values of the Hinchinbrook Channel and its environs and the possible effect and impact on those values of the proposed development at Oyster Point.

This report was sent to the Hon. Molly Robson, the Queensland Minister for Environment and Heritage, for her comment. Considerable discussions have also been held between my portfolio and the relevant Queensland departments about the conclusions of the Valentine report. I am now in receipt of a long and detailed letter from Ms Robson to which is attached a draft of the deed of agreement between the state of Queensland, Cardwell Properties Pty Ltd and the Shire of Cardwell. I have asked my department for detailed advice on those documents. I expect to receive that advice shortly and provide a response to the Queensland government.

It seems to me that the process that has been undertaken has meant that there is maximum opportunity for both the state and the federal governments to look at the complexities of these issues. I stress to the Senate that the issues involved are complex.

Part (c) of Senator Woodley's notice of motion goes to the issue of the public release of the Valentine report. Turning to this issue in a general sense, I have indicated that the Queensland government's draft deed of agreement and the Valentine report and their release were the subject of a question to me, I think yesterday, in question time from Senator Kernot. I cannot add very much to what I said to Senator Kernot during question time yesterday. The draft deed of agreement is a Queensland government document and therefore its release is properly a matter for the Queensland government. I did indicate that this was a matter that I was willing to take up with Ms Robson, and I will do that.

I believe in the interests of full public disclosure that it is appropriate in these circumstances to release the Valentine report. Given the nature of the consultations that the government has had with Queensland on this matter, I think it appropriate that I consult with Ms Robson before that occurs. Therefore I certainly cannot agree to release the document now—and I use the words of Senator Woodley's motion—prior to making a decision on the development. Let us be clear about this. It is not up to me to make a decision on the development. This is an important point for Senator Woodley to understand. The involvement in relation to my responsibilities and powers as the federal minister for the environment is to ensure that there is not an impact on the World Heritage values of this area and that those World Heritage values are protected. So I cannot accept that aspect of the final part of Senator Woodley's motion.

I foreshadow that the motion be amended by deleting the words in paragraph (c) `prior to the minister making a decision on the development' and substituting the following words `after consultation with the Queensland government'. I have provided copies of the amendment to the Deputy Clerk for circulation. I think that is a more appropriate and accurate reflection of my responsibilities in relation to this development. I stress that it is not a matter for decision in that sense or approval of the development for Commonwealth authorities. In response to Senator Macdonald's claim that I have released the Valentine report to Senator Kernot, that is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did they get a copy?
—That is a good question, and one that I cannot answer. I do not know.
—There were only three people who had copies, weren't there?

—I would have thought that might well be the case. I know you have not been following the debate in this chamber very closely, but I did indicate a long time ago that I would pass to Queensland authorities not only a copy of the final report of Mr Valentine, but also a copy of the draft report of Mr Valentine so there would be full transparency between both federal and state governments in relation to this matter.

PARA.TAB: I understand that that section of the report from which Senator Kernot quoted related to the executive summary of Mr Valentine's draft report but I can clearly say that the report certainly has not been released by me. I am very confident that it has not been released by anyone in my department or by any agency of my department. If that is the insinuation contained within that string of absurd interjections from Senator MacDonald, it is an insinuation without justification.

Mr Acting Deputy President, within the parameters that I have outlined to the Senate in my contribution, and if this amendment is acceptable to the chamber, the government is comfortable in supporting the notice of motion in the amended form, as I have indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I would like to pick up on the points that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has just made and a point that Senator Ian Macdonald was also dealing with. I have in my possession only the three pages of the report which I tabled yesterday. I do not know how they came into my possession—they were off the back of a truck, as they say—and, as far as I am aware, that is all that Senator Kernot has in her possession.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, Senator Macdonald's motion earlier today, calling for us to table that report, is asking for an impossibility. We do not have it. As I say, we have only those three pages, which he now also has.

I want to pick up on a very general but very important point. What we are dealing with, not only in this debate but in so many debates in relation to environmental protection, is a difference in world view, a difference in paradigm. We have Senator Macdonald and people of his view on the one hand and people like me on the other.

On the one hand, there are those who see the environment as something out there other than self, something to be exploited for profit. On the other hand, there are those with a view similar to many indigenous people, including our own Aboriginal people—people who see the environment as part of self, as part of something to which they belong and which therefore has a right to exist for its own sake and which has a need for protection. We see it as something of which we are a part rather than being apart from and therefore able to exploit. Because of that fundamental difference it is very difficult to argue with people like Senator Macdonald because we are coming from different points of view—and I think Senator Macdonald would be the first to admit that.

I would like to expand briefly on my point of view. Several years ago, Dr Stephen Boyden of the Australian National University, who has worked at CRES for a number of years, published a book called The biological history of western civilisation in which he developed the theme that for most of human history, for some 400,000 generations, we lived in small groups as gatherers and hunters and we lived in a natural environment. It is only very recently that a small proportion of us have lived in an industrialised and urbanised society. He draws from that the conclusion that most of us are fundamentally genetically adapted to living in a natural environment.

One finds examples of this type of thinking in ordinary, everyday expressions. How often does one hear when people go away on a holiday, `We are getting away from it all'? We need to get away from something. We need to go back to our more human roots which are, quite literally, rooted in a natural environment. Because of those who would exploit that natural environment and build these mega tourist resorts it would not be possible to get away from it all because the `all' would be everywhere. One could never escape from it and one would therefore be diminished as a human being; one would be less than human. That is the fundamental difference in the view being put by Senator Ian Macdonald and those on that side and the view being put by the Democrats and those who would protect these areas.

It is important for these areas to remain as places to which humans can go and experience nature on nature's terms and not be surrounded by thousands of people, which makes that experience quite impossible. Not only that, but if one picks up the theme of intergenerational equity—that is, the idea of equity between generations in addition to equity within generations—then it is very important for this generation to ensure that future generations can also experience nature on its own terms and that there are wild places to which our children, our grandchildren and our great-grandchildren can go. If we take those opportunities away, they will be less than human.

Yesterday, if I understood Senator Ian Macdonald correctly, he was saying that this is an area that has not been developed like many of the other areas in this stretch of the Queensland coast. From that I interpreted him to say, `Why should this not also be developed in this way?' The very reason why it should not be developed in this way is that those other areas have their mega hotels, their casinos and that type of experience. Let us keep wilderness areas where people can experience wilderness. That is very important. It is also very important for later generations.

Hinchinbrook is such an area. Hinchinbrook Island and the channel have been protected as a World Heritage area. It is one which has been clearly recognised as a place where one can have a wilderness experience. Populations have been limited there. It has not been well policed, but it is simply impossible to continue to protect that sort of experience if there are these very large hotels. I make the plea that it is at that level that we are going to continue to have these sorts of debates. It is for that sort of reason that Hinchinbrook needs to be protected. It is for that reason that the Democrats have gone in so hard on this issue. It is for that reason that we put up this motion. We support it most strongly.

SPEECH.PARA: DEPARTURE TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1994

This bill together with the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1994 implements the Government's decision announced in the 1994 Budget to replace the existing departure tax with a passenger movement charge to achieve full cost recovery for Customs, Immigration and Quarantine processing at Australia's borders and the cost of issue of short-term visitor visas.
The cost of these services has been calculated as being $27 per departing passenger.

In addition to achieving cost recovery for these services, it was also the Government's desire that there be a more effective way of collecting the charge. The old system under departure tax involved purchasing a tax stamp, affixing that to the ticket and then having the stamp cancelled by a Customs officer as the person passed through Customs on the way out of the country. This process added to the red tape that passengers had to go through at what is often a stressful time anyway. The Government is committed to achieving further improvements to Australia's already efficient passenger processing procedures and the report of the Review of the Australian Customs Service—the Conroy report—gave strong endorsement to the Customs' Service's direction in this respect. The removal of the process I've just mentioned is a step towards realisation of the vision for airports of the future.

That is why the Government also decided to seek the agreement of the airlines to collect the Passenger Movement Charge. While the Government is aware that it is common practice around the world for airlines to be required by Governments to collect taxes, fees and charges—70% of countries world wide have airlines collecting some sort of charge—the Government chose rather to work with the airlines, in recognition of the importance of the travel and tourism industry to this country.
The Government also gave the airlines a commitment to meet reasonable costs of establishing and running the system. Those discussions are underway at present.
The cost recovery initiative is proposed to be achieved by utilising the existing legislative mechanism for departure tax to both levy and collect the passenger movement charge.

This bill imposes the passenger movement charge whilst the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1994 outlines the mechanism for the collection of the charge pending resolution of negotiations with airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies on video and computer games and classification issues. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 15 September 1994
Senator the Hon Margaret Reynolds
Chair
Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Reynolds
I refer to your Committee's report titled: Report on Video and Computer Games and Classification Issues which was tabled in the Senate on 28 October 1993.
I support the majority of the recommendations made in the Committee's report. States and Territories have been consulted about this response.
My specific comments on each of the recommendations are as follows.

Recommendation 1. The Committee is encouraged by the consultations to date between the OFLC and the industry over regulation proposals. The Committee recommends that a code of practice for distributors of video and computer games be developed and that all distributors be signatories to the code.

Response: The OFLC has developed a regulatory system which provides for classification guidelines, official markings, consumer advice and application procedures. The regulatory system will have a statutory basis consistent with the existing framework of censorship laws. It is continuing discussions with industry. The system was approved by Ministers on 18 February 1994.

Recommendation 2. The Committee notes that the enforcement of a regulatory regime will be under State and Territory laws. The Committee recommends that the consideration by Ministers of enforcement measures ensures that breaches of regulations must attract prosecution and the imposition of penalties that are sufficiently severe so as to act as a realistic deterrent.
Response: This is a matter for State and Territory Ministers. The Committee's concerns have been drawn to the attention of Ministers.

Recommendation 3. The Committee accepts the classification proposals G-0 to 8 years of age, G8-8 to 14 years of age and M-15 to 17 years of age and recommends that the Government supports the adoption of these categories at the meeting of Federal, State and Territory Censorship Ministers in November 1993.
Response: Censorship Ministers agreed to these classifications at their meeting on 4 November 1993.

Recommendation 4. The Committee is concerned that the level of technology involved with the use of video and computer games means that many parents do not necessarily have the competency to ensure adequate parental guidance. Therefore the Committee recommends that material of an `R' equivalent category to be refused classification. The Committee recommends that if an `X' equivalent classification is considered it should not be adopted for video and computer games material. The Committee also recommends that entertainment centres operating coin-operated games should be restricted to offering the G and G8 categories only.

Response: The issue of which computer game classification categories will be permitted, and the circumstances in which they may be made available, is a matter for each State or Territory government. Each State and Territory has the capacity to decide under its censorship enforcement laws which classification categories may be sold, hired, exhibited or offered for use in its jurisdiction. At their meeting on 4 November 1993 Censorship Ministers asked the Chief Censor to consult with the public about the proposed computer games classification guidelines. The consultation process is documented in the January 1994 report issued by the Chief Censor: `Report on: Public Submissions on Draft Computer Games Classification Guidelines'. Several changes were made to the guidelines as a result of the consultation. These were agreed to by the Ministers on 18 February 1994.

At that meeting Ministers also wished that their divergence of views about whether the `R' or `X' categories for computer games ought to be permitted be recorded. After further consideration, some Ministers, who initially supported those categories, reported that their governments no longer supported the `R' or `X' classifications for computer games. Accordingly, the interim computer games classification scheme set out in the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance, 1983 has been amended to remove the `R' and `X' categories for computer games. Similarly, the Commonwealth Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994 does not permit `R' and `X' computer games to be classified.

Recommendation 5. The Committee recommends that an MA classification be introduced for video and computer games found to be unsuitable for viewing by persons under 15 years of age. Games in this classification can only be sold, hired, delivered or exhibited to persons under the age of 15 years if they are accompanied by a parent or guardian. The Committee also recommends that the availability of MA material must be conditional on a statutory requirement to provide proof of age at the point of sale or hire.

Response: Ministers agreed to an `MA' classification for computer games that restricts such games to persons 15 years and over. However, some jurisdictions have now indicated that they will permit access to such games by persons under the age of 15 years if they are accompanied by a parent or guardian, as recommended by the Committee.

Recommendation 6. Having regard to the extra sensory intensity involved in the playing of interactive games and the implications of long-term effects on users, the Committee recommends that stricter criteria for classification than those applying to equivalent film and video classifications be set by censorship authorities. The criteria, once established, should be made known to prospective applicants for classification, and the standard of application of the criteria must be maintained.

Response: Censorship Ministers agreed that classification guidelines for computer games should be stricter than for other media (see 4 November and 18 February press releases). The draft guidelines were exposed to the public and the industry for comment, amended in the light of those comments, and have been endorsed by Ministers. They have been revised, and endorsed by Ministers, in the light of the decision of all jurisdictions not to permit `R' or `X' classified games to be available.

Recommendation 7. The Committee supports the efforts of the Office of Film and Literature Classification to conduct research into the effects of video and computer games as an entertainment form as well as their impact on community standards. The Committee recognises the importance of this research and recommends that appropriate levels of funding be provided to the Office to ensure it can properly assess the influence of this evolving technology.

Response: Censorship Ministers recognise the importance of research in this area. A jointly funded research project into several aspects of computer games is being developed for Ministers to consider.

Recommendation 8. The Committee commends the proposals of governments to establish and adopt uniform classification legislation for video and computer games. The Committee recommends that a high priority be accorded to achieving that goal and that censorship authorities maintain a monitoring role on the relevance of the legislation in a rapidly growing and changing industry.

Response: Responses to earlier recommendations set out some of the steps already in progress that address this recommendation. Censorship Ministers are in agreement that a cooperative national approach is essential. Also, as you would be aware, the Ministers have a keen interest in the effective operation of the Commonwealth, State and Territory censorship system.
Recommendation 9. The Committee recommends:
that both the Film Classification (Censorship) Board and the Film and Literature Board of Review be restructured and expanded to ensure that they have more comprehensive community representation; and
that, before appointments are made to either Board, the Attorney-General consult with State and Territory Ministers.

Response: The Government will continue to ensure that membership of both Boards appropriately reflects the community's interests. The resource implications of the additional functions of the Censorship Board will have to be considered.
Recent advertisements in the national press for vacancies on the Censorship Board drew approximately 700 applications from the community.

I have already indicated to my State and Territory colleagues that I shall consult, including by representation on selection panels interviewing for vacancies, with them before making appointments to both Boards. This has already been the case with recent appointments and is provided for in the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994.
Recommendation 10. The Committee also recommends:
that a community committee be established, representing major interest groups such as parents, teachers, churches, academics, women, youth and aboriginal and ethnic representatives;
(a)that the committee would be asked to consider:
any decisions of the Film Censorship Board in relation to the release of a film or video with an MA or R rating about which the Board was not unanimous; and
any decision of the Review Board to vary a Board decision to refuse to release, or release a film or video with a recommended R or MA rating at a lower classification, than recommended by the Board.
(b) that the Review Board be required to take the community committee's recommendations into account in its deliberations, and

(c) that the Attorney-General be required to make a determination on any decision of the Review Board to release a film or video at a lower classification than approved by the unanimous decision of the Board, and be required to take account of the community committee's recommendations.

Response: Censorship Ministers collectively supervise the national classification system and in some cases have retained the right to overturn individual decisions with which they disagree. Members of both Boards are appointed to represent community views.

In addition, the Australian Law Reform Commission's recommendation for an on-going public consultation program has already commenced. This consultation process takes the form of special screenings of classified, but as yet unreleased, films to groups of people assembled by a market research recruitment agency. An independent market research consultant supervises the completion of a questionnaire and leads a discussion aimed at comparing the issues of concern, the range of intensity of concern about those issues, the recommended age, and appropriate consumer advice with those considered by the Censorship Board when making the classification decision.

The initial Australian Bureau of Statistics survey on Films, Videos and Computer Games commissioned by the OFLC has been completed and copies have been provided to the Committee. Further surveys and research flowing from the results of that survey are planned or underway. These include another joint exercise with the OFLC and the ABA and additional research being jointly funded by the Commonwealth and participating States and Territories. Accordingly, the additional processes recommended by the Committee are considered unnecessary.
Recommendation 11. The Committee recommends that
the Censorship Ministers review the length of tenure of members of the Boards;
the current Chief Censor be the only ex officio member of the restructured Film Censorship Board;
the current position of Chief Censor be re-styled as the Chief Executive Officer of the OFLC; and
there be new positions of Chief Censor and Deputy Chief Censor of the Film Censorship Board, to be appointed from the community representatives of the Board.

Response: The Law Reform Commission's recommendations regarding tenure have largely been adopted. The maximum term of any appointment is to be 5 years and the maximum period of service 7 years. The three other parts of the recommendation, and the support of the Northern Territory for the last part in particular, have been noted.
Recommendation 12. The Committee recommends:

that the terminology of the guidelines, especially in relation to the Refused category, be revised and clarified to limit as far as possible scope for varying interpretation in relation to material of a sexual or violent nature;
that the OFLC's guidelines be amended for video release to ensure that higher standards are applied to material permitted on video than equivalent categories of film for cinema release;

that the various regulatory bodies co-ordinate their activities to establish and maintain definitions which will ensure that there is uniform interpretation of terms and expressions used in their respective guidelines.

Response: The classification guidelines cannot and should not be drafted to include every possible nuance of film expression. They are not exhaustive, they are intended to be flexible enough to cope with changes in community standards over a period of time and to allow for unique films to be assessed on their merits and not solely on a predetermined list of proscribed elements. Equally, the Censorship Ministers have expressed their views to both the Censorship and Review Boards that violent and sexually violent material should be dealt with more strictly. In accordance with Ministers' wishes, they are already highly prescriptive in the restricted and refused categories. The guidelines shared by the Boards recognise the Ministers' and community concern in this regard.

The recommendation that video releases be dealt with more strictly contradicts current policy which sets the film and video criteria at identical thresholds. There are persuasive arguments that the system should continue in its present uniform form to promote community understanding of, and confidence in, the classification process, and to provide business certainty on a national basis.The present policy also includes the proposition that the provision of classification advice about films and videos to the community should be as clear and concise as possible so that parents, in particular, can choose entertainment for themselves and those in their care. The classification system also gives notice to those with more delicate sensibilities that this material is inappropriate for them. Accordingly, the second part of the recommendation is also not supported.

The third part of the recommendation deals with the prerogative of the Censorship Board and the Review Board, while working from the same guidelines endorsed by Censorship Ministers, to be able to interpret the guidelines in different ways according to their respective perception of a film. Both Boards work within statutory and administrative criteria. Within that criteria, members of both Boards are entitled to apply their interpretation of those criteria as they see them. Accordingly, the third part of the recommendation is also not supported.

Recommendation 13. The Committee recommends that the Censorship Ministers give favourable consideration not only to the Law Reform Commission's recommendation that standing be widened before the Film and Literature Board of Review but that it also should be widened before the courts in relation to the decisions of the Film and Literature Board of Review.

Response: While the full breadth of the Law Reform Commission's approach and the Committee's proposed appeal to a Court is not supported, there is support for a more generous arrangement than exists at the moment in most State and Territory legislation. That approach includes standing to be given to the Attorney-General, the applicant, a distributor and a person aggrieved. Also, the Attorney-General is to be required to appeal if a request is made by the Censorship Minister of a State or Territory. These changes together with increased public consultation initiatives are considered to give the public an appropriate level of input into the classification process.

Recommendation 14. The Committee recommends that the Government should review, together with the other organisations, authorities and governments which utilise the Advertising Standards Council, the present charter of the Council and its operations with the aim of maximising its services to the community.

Response: The Minister for Consumer Affairs, the Hon Jeannette McHugh will consult with the Media Council of Australia regarding the operation of the advertising self-regulatory system, with particular focus on the concerns raised by the Senate Select Committee.

The Minister has been successfully involved in a number of industry based dispute resolution schemes, including the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman, the Banking Industry Ombudsman and public complaint schemes operated by the insurance industry. Much thought and innovation have been invested by industry and government in the establishment of alternative dispute resolution schemes which are responsive to community standards and these will provide a useful model for complaint handling schemes in the field of advertising.
In closing, I wish to pass on to the Committee the view of Censorship Ministers that the Committee's work has been of great value in their deliberations.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL LAVARCH

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories on the proposal for pay parking in the parliamentary zone. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Deputy Prime Minister
Minister for Housing and Regional Development
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
19 September 1994
Mr R. L. Chynoweth MP
Chairman
Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Chynoweth
Thank you for your letter of 24 June 1994 providing the Committee's report on The Proposal for Pay Parking in the Parliamentary Zone.
I have noted the Committee's recommendations:

"that Parliamentary approval, as required under Section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, not be granted for the proposal to install voucher parking machines and associated signs in the Parliamentary Zone", and;

"that the National Capital Planning Authority, in consultation with other relevant departments, investigate alternative means by which additional funds could be raised to offset the cost of the Restorations and Replacement Program of National Assets".

Due to the Disallowance motion on the National Land (Parking) Ordinance 1994 and National Land (Parking) (Consequential Amendments) Ordinance 1994 by Senator Margaret Reid, a statement was made to Senate on Tuesday 23 August 1994. In my statement, I indicated that other considerations made it critical for both Ordinances to pass into law.

I also undertook not to proceed with the present proposal to introduce pay parking the Parliamentary Zone, under the powers of the Ordinances. I also indicated that the Government will consider alternative proposals for pay parking in the Zone in response to a number of Parliamentary Committee Reports over a number of years and in relation to strategies being adopted for surrounding areas.

The introduction of pay parking in the Parliamentary Zone was viewed by the Committee solely as a revenue measure whereas its introduction should be seen in the context of implementing a number of Government policies. The Government endorses a reduction in the use of private transport and encourages the use of public transport through such policies as the National Greenhouse Response Strategy and the National Strategy for Ecologically Sustainable Development. At the United Nations Earth Summit in 1992, Australia and 86 other countries became signatories to the Climate Change Convention, which has an international target of stabilising gas emissions at 1990 levels by 2000.

The Committee has recommended that the NCPA investigate alternative fund raising measures to offset the cost of its Restoration and Replacement Program for Commonwealth Assets. In the course of developing the pay parking proposal, the NCPA investigated a number of alternative or additional fund raising measures. These included land rent from Government owned office buildings including the Treasury and Administrative Buildings and East and West Blocks. This was rejected because it would necessitate additional funding from Treasury to enable the relevant Government Departments to pay the rent. Similarly, photographic and film rights, concessions for commercial activities and fees for permits to use National Land were considered administratively expensive for potentially little or at best unreliable returns. Retaining revenue from diplomatic leases would not be budget neutral since these funds currently go directly into consolidated revenue. None of these alternatives proved to be as reliable or predictable a source of income as pay parking.

Without the implementation of pay parking in the Zone the NCPA will be unable to generate the $4.3m to offset funding for the Restoration and Replacement Program. This will mean that the four year Program will fall short of necessary requirements. To maintain the Commonwealth's assets in the National Capital, the NCPA will need a longer term strategy to fund such works.
I will be taking this matter further through the Budgetary process.
Yours sincerely
BRIAN HOWE
