PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration on asylum, border control and detention. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: THE AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE JOINT COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REPORT:

SPEECH.PARA: "ASYLUM, BORDER CONTROL AND DETENTION"

Recommendation 1 The Committee recommends that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs consider certain anomalies in the text of the Migration Reform Act 1992, as identified by the Committee and outlined at paragraphs 3.139, 3.140, 3.150 and 3.151 and 3.155 of this report, and overcome these anomalies before the commencement of the Migration Reform Act 1992 on 1 September 1994.
Agree in part.

Paragraph 3.139 proposes legislative amendment to ensure the availability of "questioning detention" during immigration clearance. This issue has already been considered in the review of the Migration Reform Act 1992 (MRA) initiated by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and is covered in the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1994 (MLAA) at section 52(d).

Paragraph 3.140 proposes legislative amendment to ensure that a person in immigration clearance need not remain with the same clearance officer. This concern is also addressed in the MLAA in section 52, paragraphs (c) and (d).

Legislative amendment is also proposed in paragraph 3.150, to make it clear when a review of a decision to refuse a bridging visa is "finally determined". The Government considers that no amendment is necessary on this point, as section 4(12) of the Migration Act 1958 ("the Act") defines when an application is finally determined, namely, when a decision is no longer subject to any form of review, or when the period during which such a review could be instituted has ended.

In regard to paragraph 3.151, the Government considers that people who bypass immigration clearance should generally be eligible to apply for a bridging visa, and to seek review of a decision to refuse that application. One element taken into consideration is that persons who have bypassed immigration clearance are likely to include people who may have been in the community for many years and have developed strong ties with Australian citizens or permanent residents. It is therefore appropriate that there be a facility to allow them to make an application for the grant of a bridging visa. Such an application would not, of itself, mean that the person would be granted the visa. An exception will be made in the case of people who bypass immigration clearance but who come to the notice of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (DIEA) within 45 days. They will be eligible to apply for a bridging visa only in the circumstances discussed under Recommendations 11 and 12.

Paragraph 3.155, like Recommendations 4-6, relates to judicial review. The recommendations themselves raise complex issues requiring careful consideration. The Government has determined that these recommendations will be the subject of consideration by an Interdepartmental Committee comprising the Departments of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Attorney-General's and Prime Minister and Cabinet, in the light of experience after the MRA comes into force.
Recommendation 2 The Committee recommends that as soon as possible, the Government provide to the Committee for examination the draft regulations which will accompany the Migration Reform Act 1992.
Agree in principle.

It is not practical to provide the Committee with the draft MRA regulations prior to their creation. The process of their creation involves extensive restructuring of the regulations to ensure incorporation of totally new terminology and concepts. Any delays would affect training and other matters, putting at risk effective implementation of the MRA on 1 September.

The regulations need to be put to the Executive Council and will be gazetted, and hence publicly available, very soon thereafter. If the Joint Standing Committee identifies a problem, the Government would consider subsequent amendments.

Recommendation 3 The Committee recommends that the decision on whether to include unauthorised boat arrivals within the prescribed class of detention non-citizens, conferring on them eligibility to be released from detention with a bridging visa, be a decision of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs personally which is not to be delegated. In addition, the mechanism for including such prescribed non-citizens within the prescribed class of detention non-citizens be structured carefully so as to allow for appropriate exercise of Ministerial discretion without inviting challenges for judicial review of such discretion.
Agree in part.

In order to be granted a bridging visa under the Migration Act as it will be from 1 September 1994, a non-citizen will need either to be immigration cleared or to be in a prescribed class of persons (in either case the person is referred to as an "eligible non-citizen"). An eligible non-citizen will then generally need to apply for a bridging visa and be assessed against the relevant criteria for the grant of that bridging visa.

It is not clear whether the Committee intended, in Recommendation 3, to refer only to the first process—that is, to the making of regulations relating to prescribed classes of persons—or whether it intended to refer also to the subsequent process of application and assessment.

Legislative amendment is not necessary to give effect to this recommendation, insofar as it relates to the making of regulations relating to prescribed classes of persons. The regulation-making power is effectively non-compellable and involves the Minister acting personally.

To introduce a non-compellable, non-delegable power in relation to decisions made pursuant to any such regulation will require an amendment to the Act. This will be done in respect of changes to be enacted in partial response to Recommendation 11.

Recommendation 4 The Committee recommends that the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and the Judiciary Act 1903 be amended to specify that the Migration Reform Act 1992 and its predecessors are enactments to which the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and the Judiciary Act 1903 do not apply.
Under consideration.

As this Recommendation deals with judicial review, it will be considered further in the light of experience after the MRA comes into force on 1 September 1994. See comments relating to paragraph 3.151 of Recommendation 1.

Recommendation 5 The Committee recommends that a leave provision be introduced such that applicants challenging decisions under the Migration Act 1958 be required to obtain leave in order to apply for a review of Migration Act decisions to the Federal Court.
Under consideration.
See Recommendation 4.

Recommendation 6 The Committee recommends that if the amendments in the Migration Reform Act 1992 and the proposals in this report aimed at curtailing the recent trend to litigate migration decisions in the higher courts are not successful, consideration should be given to implementing a new refugee determination process which would provide refugee claimants with access only to the two tier administrative process, and which would close off access to review and appeal in the higher courts, save for the right of access to the High Court which is guaranteed in the Australian Constitution.
Under consideration.
See Recommendation 4.

Recommendation 7 The Committee recommends that public funding be available through the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for the provision of legal advice and assistance to border refugee claimants in relation to the preparation of primary applications for refugee status and review applications to the Refugee Review Tribunal. Thereafter, publicly funded legal assistance to refugee claimants seeking review of a refusal decision to the Federal Court be provided only on the basis of a merits test.
Agree.

This Recommendation accords with current Government policy. All boat arrivals seeking refugee status are offered, at public expense, legal assistance to prepare and prosecute their applications, including the preparation of any subsequent application for review of a refugee status refusal by the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT).

Equivalent publicly-funded support will be extended to all other people in detention seeking refugee status, including border claimants who do not arrive by boat. Work is under way to establish an open tender process for provision of this service. In the interim, a service arrangement is currently being negotiated with an independent agency experienced in the provision of refugee application assistance.
The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs does not make funds available to support those who wish to challenge refugee status refusals through the courts. Such individuals are free to make
whatever arrangements for their legal assistance they wish, including approaches to legal aid bodies.

Recommendation 8 The Committee recommends that as an absolute priority, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Refugee Review Tribunal ensure that applications for refugee status are processed in a fair and expeditious manner, and that the processing of applications for refugee status from unauthorised border arrivals and persons held in detention continues to be given precedence.
Agree.

The Recommendation accords with present practice. The Department and the RRT are conscious of the importance of processing applications for refugee status in a fair and expeditious manner. Both organisations are also conscious of the need to ensure that the decision making process provides applicants with the opportunity to present their claims and that these are fully and sensitively considered. Under the Act, the RRT is specifically charged with providing a review mechanism that is ". . . fair, just, economical, informal and quick".

Arrangements have been in place for some time to ensure that refugee applications from unauthorised border claimants and other persons in detention are given precedence. Streamlined processes are in place to facilitate the speedy resolution of such applications, with the average processing time for boat arrivals over the last two years averaging just five weeks from date of lodgement to time of decision.
Recommendation 9 The Committee recommends that all parties to litigation concerning and relating to refugee determinations make every effort to expedite the hearing of that litigation.
Agree.

The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs attempts to expedite the hearing of all immigration litigation, and particularly refugee cases where the person is in custody. The capacity for DIEA to encourage an applicant's legal representatives to expedite their presentation of the case, file supporting documents or meet deadlines imposed by the courts is limited. Ultimately, it is a matter for the court to determine whether it will allow an applicant more time.

Recommendation 10 The Committee recommends that unauthorised border arrivals who claim refugee status be held in detention during the determination of their status, including during administrative processing, administrative review and any legal appeals, but that there be a capacity to consider release where the period of detention exceeds six months.
See response to Recommendation 11.

In cases where unauthorised arrivals claiming refugee status have been detained for more than six months as a result of lack of action or administrative error by DIEA, the Minister, in accordance with his powers under the Migration Reform Act 1992, may consider including such detained asylum seekers in a prescribed class of detention non-citizens eligible for grant of a bridging visa. In considering whether to include in the prescribed class all or any such detainees, the Minister have regard to the following matters:
whether the applicant has a special need based on age, health or previous experiences of torture and trauma;
whether the applicant has satisfied appropriate health, character and security checks;
the likelihood that the applicant would abscond if granted a bridging visa;
whether there is a reasonable basis for the applicant's claim for refugee status;
the timeliness of the lodgement of the application for refugee status;
the extent to which the applicant cooperated with DIEA in the provision of information relevant to the applicant's claims;
whether there will be adequate support arrangements if the applicant is released into the community; and
Australia's international obligations.
Agree.

The Government will implement the essential element of the Committee's Recommendations 10 and 11, thus enabling release from detention of unauthorised arrivals who claim refugee status and have been detained for more than six months from the receipt of their application without a primary decision, owing to lack of Departmental action by DIEA. However, to ensure that the Minister's power to order such release is both non-compellable and discretionary, as per Recommendation 3, amendments to the Migration Act will be necessary.

Regulations have been enacted which will enable unauthorised arrivals to be released at any time (without the need to wait six months) on compassionate grounds, including age (both for children where it is in the child's best interests and for the elderly), ill health and previous experience of torture and trauma. The Regulations will come into effect on September 1, 1994.

In determining whether to prescribe any unauthorised border arrivals as a class of detention non-citizens eligible for the grant of a bridging visa, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs give particular consideration to the release of those persons who particularly are vulnerable to any effects of long-term detention, namely those persons with a special need based on age, health or previous experience of torture and trauma.
Agree.

It is proposed that the regulations referred to in response to Recommendations 10 and 11 will make provision for the grant of bridging visas to people who have such a special need who are refused immigration clearance on or after 1 September 1994, or who bypass immigration clearance but come to the notice of DIEA within 45 days of arrival, who would otherwise not be eligible for bridging visas. It is proposed that eligibility not be limited to protection visa applicants who have been in immigration detention for more than six months, nor to those where continued detention has been brought about by lack of action or administrative error on the part of DIEA, nor to cases where there is a reasonable basis to the applicant's protection claim. Grant of a bridging visa will be subject to the availability of suitable alternative care arrangements.
In order to be granted a bridging visa, an unauthorised border arrival deemed eligible for release from detention should be required to agree that he/she will:
report regularly, at least once a fortnight, to a nominated office of DIEA;
reside at a nominated address notified in advance to DIEA;
notify DIEA at least one week in advance of any change of address; and
depart Australia or present for removal if he/she is refused refugee status.
Agree.

It is proposed that the first three parts of Recommendation 13 will be reflected in conditions attached to any bridging visa granted pursuant to the regulations referred to in responses to Recommendations 10, 11 and 12. Breach of these, or other, conditions would be grounds for cancellation of the bridging visa.

In relation to the fourth part of Recommendation 13, the Government proposes that the giving of a written undertaking to depart Australia or present for removal on finalisation of the applicant's protection visa application would be a criterion for the grant of a bridging visa.

Recommendation 14 The Committee recommends that before unauthorised border arrivals who become eligible for the grant of a bridging visa in fact are released into the community, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs liaise with accredited community support or charitable organisations and relevant ethnic community support groups to ensure that appropriate support arrangements are established to maintain such persons in the community. In addition, any government funding which may be provided to assist with such support arrangements be directed through accredited community support or charitable organisations.
Agree.

Issues in the Government's implementation of this recommendation will include the identification of appropriate support organisations and the level of financial assistance, if any, to be provided. While community organisations have expressed a strong commitment to community release schemes, the JSCM report notes their unease about the financial burden of long-term care.

Recommendation 15 The Committee recommends that an Immigration Detention Centres Advisory Committee be established comprising representatives of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Australian Protective Service, detention centre residents, community based service providers and local community representatives. The terms of reference for the advisory committee should require it to consider and make recommendations pertaining to the conditions and services provided within immigration detention centres. In considering such matters, the advisory committee should be required to take account of issues relevant to the refugee determination process, including the number of persons detained, the likely length of their stay, and the likelihood of their gaining refugee status in Australia.
Agree.

The concept is supported. It is proposed that a committee be established at each Immigration Detention Centre (IDC). It is seen as important that each Centre have its own locally-based committee which would have an appreciation of local influences, be able to focus on physical conditions and remedy any problems as soon as they arise.

The committees have the potential to become a knowledgable and constructive reference point for service development. The centres have long been open to inspection by interest groups, but this form of external scrutiny does not have the advantages of depth of familiarity with the detention environment which a standing committee could offer.

Specific membership of committees has been recommended by the JSCM, which is supported by the Government. Draft terms of reference for advisory committees have already been circulated to the Australian Protective Service (APS), IDCs and relevant DIEA offices for comment.

Recommendation 16 The Committee recommends that having regard to the literacy levels of detainee children, the number of native languages spoken, the likelihood of the children being allowed to remain in Australia, and the standard of education provided within the centre in which the children are detained, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs consult with State Government education agencies to determine whether, in appropriate cases, children held at the detention centres might be able to attend local schools, and to consider whether education in a child's native language is viable and can be organised.
Agree.
Legal advice suggests that custody can be maintained while children attend local schools, provided children are escorted to and from school and remain in the school precinct.

The question of education in a child's native language is more problematic, given the small number of school-age children in detention in New South Wales and a changing mix of language groupings at the Port Hedland Centre. DIEA is currently investigating options for the implementation of this part of the Recommendation, possibly through attendance at "Saturday schools".

Recommendation 17 The Committee recommends that where a large group of detainees belonging to a particular ethnic group are held together in a particular immigration detention centre, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs makes every effort to engage the services of medical personnel who can provide regular consultations in the native language of that ethnic group.
Agree.

This is consistent with current practice, although not always achievable. In Sydney the visiting medical officer is a Chinese language speaker, although other languages are less easily catered for. In Port Hedland there are few medical personnel of a non-English speaking background available.

Recommendation 18 The Committee recommends that the Port Hedland Immigration Reception and Processing Centre be retained for the purpose of detaining unauthorised boat arrivals pending the determination of their status; and
Agree.

Recommendation 19 The Committee recommends that should the number of detainees held at the Port Hedland Immigration Reception and Processing Centre decrease to the extent that it is no longer viable to operate the Centre, the Port Hedland Centre be decommissioned, but with the capacity to recommission the Centre should it be required in the future.
Agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address a few brief remarks to the government response to what is a very important report. This is a very pleasing response from the government to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. The report contains 19 recommendations. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has given unqualified acceptance to 13 of those recommendations. He has accepted two more which have been agreed to in part and one other which has been agreed to in principle. So 16 out of 19 recommendations have been agreed to, three with qualifications.

PARA.TAB: Three important recommendations—recommendations Nos 4, 5 and 6—are still under consideration. Recommendation No. 4—the legal recommendation—states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and the Judiciary Act 1903 be amended to specify that the Migration Reform Act 1992 and its predecessors are enactments to which the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and the Judiciary Act 1903 do not apply.

In recommendation No. 5 the committee recommended that a leave to apply provision should be inserted in respect of persons seeking to take actions in the Federal Court before the court can deal with them. Recommendation 6 deals with amendments to the Migration Reform Act.

PARA.TAB: I hope that when the interdepartmental committee gives consideration to those three recommendations, it will take into account the experiences of the Federal Court since this report was brought down in March of this year. The Joint Standing Committee on Migration has expressed concerns in this report about the high usage that people are making of the Federal Court after they have been through what has been proved to be very fair processes of administrative decisions for asylum seekers in this country.

We have people entering this country illegally who are given the opportunity of applying for refugee status through the administrative process. If they are rejected at that initial stage, they then have the opportunity of applying for a review of that decision through the Refugee Review Tribunal. If they fail with those two areas to which they have access, they then take their case into the judiciary. There is no other country in the world which allows both an administrative processing system and a judicial processing system to take place. That is one of the reasons the committee made the recommendations along the lines that it has.

I hope that the interdepartmental committee of the Department of Immigration, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Attorney-General's Department looks very seriously at this situation. Otherwise, as the committee said in its report, if we are going to end up with two very expensive systems of processing asylum seekers in this country, it is the people of Australia who will ultimately suffer. There are people suffering because of what I have publicly termed to be an abuse of the system.

Generally, those people who have had their applications and their appeals for refugee status in this country refused take their case through to the Federal Court, but some people have been through to the state Supreme Courts, and there are a couple of cases that have gone to the High Court. While those cases are going on, those people remain in detention. In some cases they have children who also remain in detention.

On the matter of children, I certainly hope that when the IDC is considering the committee's recommendations Nos 4, 5 and 6 it takes into account the experiences of two very young Chinese girls, asylum seekers, who have received a deal of publicity in recent months. Lin Yan is aged 13 and Lin Jing is aged nine. They had made application for refugee status in this country. That application was rejected because they did not qualify under the criteria of assessment that we use. They made application to apply for a review of that refusal. But before the Refugee Review Tribunal concluded its deliberations on their appeal, their application was withdrawn. It left the two children without any status whatsoever in Australia and liable for immediate deportation.

The minister did not act to deport them immediately. He waited until their uncle's application to the Refugee Review Tribunal had been assessed. It was rejected and then the whole family became liable for deportation. Deportation orders were issued to the whole family. I think there were nine members in total, including the uncle and his wife, a brother of the wife, a brother of the husband and, of course, the two little girls, and there were some other children as well.

Lawyers acting on behalf of the two girls and the uncles made application to the Federal Court in Canberra—not in Perth or Port Hedland, which is part of that state—for a stay of those deportation orders. The application was refused and the children were still liable for deportation. The very next day, lawyers again made application to the Federal Court—this time in Sydney—for a stay of the deportation orders. The judge in Sydney referred the application back to Canberra where again two days later the deportation orders were upheld. The lawyers immediately went to the Full Court of the Federal Court in Sydney with three judges sitting and made further application, and the Full Court upheld the decision.

The family had been through four separate applications for asylum and review in this country and the applications had been rejected on all occasions. They were not satisfied with that and they took the case to five judges of the Federal Court on three separate occasions. The girls were in the news again this morning because the court sitting in Sydney suggested that the children should be brought to Sydney because their lawyer is based in Sydney and it is a better place for them to live.

I have publicly called the way these children have been treated child abuse. It is not only child abuse, but also an abuse of their parents. After enormous efforts by the department, the parents were located in China and they were to meet the children when they returned to their homeland, but the courts in Australia were used to intervene and the children never actually returned to meet with their parents. It now appears that they are going to be here for a considerable time. Another directions hearing is going to take place. I do not want to comment on the actual court case itself but rather the use of the courts and how the Australian system can be abused and is being abused in my opinion in this particular case.

This is not the only case dealing with boat people in Australia that is going on in the courts. I am informed that there are 151 immigration cases before the Federal Court and almost 100 of them are applications from boat people. I suggest that most of those applications are from people who have already been through the administrative system. In the government's response to the committee report the minister states that there has been a dramatic improvement in the processing of boat people in this country. That system is not accepted by some. I made a tongue-in-cheek suggestion earlier this year that if we were to send boats up to China to bring the people in ourselves, they probably would not be satisfied with that.

It is a very costly exercise which is paid for not by the government but by the Australian taxpayers. I am continually and ever increasingly getting requests from constituents to bring an end to this abuse of the system. In saying that it is an abuse, I do recognise that there are some lawyers and some refugee support groups who truly believe in what they are doing and believe they are doing it for the best reasons.

There are some individuals and organisations that have involved themselves in the boat people debate whose ethics I question. Three weeks ago I revealed, without naming it again, that one refugee organisation in our home state is being used as a front for the National Civic Council. I think the use of refugee organisations in the past has unfortunately brought the reputation of many dedicated people into question, if not disrepute.

This costly exercise has gone on too long. I hope the interdepartmental committee mentioned in the government's response comes up with some ways of amending the ADJR Act and the Judiciary Act to ensure that these abuses are not allowed to continue and that the suffering of people in detention and the suffering of the Australian taxpayers is put an end to once and for all, whilst retaining a very fair and just asylum seeking processing system.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m. I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter which I raised yesterday by way of a question to Senator Schacht. I want to take issue with some of the things that he presented to the Senate in his answer. Before doing so, I make it quite plain to you, Mr President, and to Senator Schacht that I am in no way suggesting that he misled the Senate or gave an answer that was not in accordance with all the facts. He received the information from another source and presented it, I believe, totally in good faith. In a sense, however, it does not deal with the issue that I raised. More information needs to be placed before the Senate for the situation to be understood fully.

PARA.TAB: I am talking about the science olympiads—physics, chemistry and biology—and the opportunity of Australian students to participate in them. My question yesterday—and the issue that I raised previously—relates to the government's failure to continue to support the olympiads and my concern that it is not in Australia's best interests to neglect to encourage students to participate in science and engineering. It is crucial to the future of this country that this should be the case.

I turn to the history of the olympiads as far as Australia is concerned. The ASO was founded in Australia in 1988. For the first three years, those who were encouraging students to participate managed to raise the funds locally through the goodwill of universities. The students also raised funds. This enabled Australia to take part. That was fairly unsatisfactory in that the students spent much of their time raising money rather than preparing themselves for the olympiad activities.

In 1990, Mr Dawkins, as a result of representations made to him, recognised that the olympiads were an important opportunity for students with aptitude in the areas of physics, chemistry, et cetera. He said that $100,000 per annum would be made available for five years for each of physics and chemistry, and responsibility for the money was passed to the management committee. From then on, participation in the international olympiads took place with the assistance of this government money which Mr Dawkins made available.

As I said in my question yesterday, the Australian science olympiads directors have been advised that this money will not be renewed. That was the point that I was making. There are three directors of the Australian science olympiads, one in each area of physics, chemistry and biology, who run the teams for Australia. They are doing this in their own time. They have neither the time nor the expertise to go fundraising.

Apparently it has been suggested by the government that the ASO should raise money to support student participation. That would be fine if it had any form of secretariat that had the expertise to do it. I remind honourable senators that this organisation started from people putting in this effort on a totally voluntary basis to give Australian students the opportunity to participate. This is not an organisation with the structure, mechanisms and bureaucracy to give members the expertise and time to go out raising money for these activities. I suggest that it is in the interest of Australia that young people participate in these olympiads.

Australia, though, secured the 1995 International Physics Olympiad to take place in Australia, and the federal government promised $300,000 to assist in the funding. Yesterday, in answer to my question Senator Schacht referred to this money and said that the government was surprised that I had suggested funds were being withdrawn when in fact this money was being given for the purpose of the Physics Olympiad in 1995. It is true, indeed, that the money has been given to stage the International Physics Olympiad in 1995, but there has been no funding towards Australia's participation in it. That is the point I am attempting to get across.

In fact, the $300,000 is presenting the organisers with somewhat of a problem in that the fairly tight budget was drawn up to an amount of $480,000. Intensive fundraising efforts have added another $10,000 but, thanks to the assistance of the University of Canberra, it has been decided that the $310,000 will be made do to enable us to stage the International Physics Olympiad of 1995.

It will be a pretty bare bones activity. It will mean that the participants coming here will see nothing of Australia—only the inside of the university. It is a shame that the bright students coming here from all around the world will not have much of an opportunity to see anything of Australia other than to participate in the event at the University of Canberra. Thankfully, that university is enabling it to go ahead even with the small budget that is available for the purpose.

I asked Senator Schacht if it were true that the government was no longer providing money for the Australian Physics Olympiad. The answer in fact is that the government is not providing money for that purpose, but we do acknowledge that it is providing funds to enable the event to be staged. It is quite different. As one of the people involved in it said to me, it is like saying that in the year 2000 there will be no funds for the AIS; all the money available will go to the city of Sydney towards staging the Olympic Games. That, effectively, is what is being said: you will get money to assist the staging of the event but you will not get any money to assist the Australian students who ought to be participating in it.

For that reason it is very disappointing, indeed. If that is the end of the matter, there will be no Australian participation thereafter in physics, chemistry or the areas students ought to be encouraged to participate in. It looks as though Australia will not be able to take part in other events in the future. How will we get our students to the Chemistry Olympiad in China if there is no support for this event? There are others in the future. I think there is a Chemistry Olympiad proposed to be staged in Australia later this decade but there is no commitment to assist Australian students prepare for events in the future. There will be no Australian physics team going to Norway, shall we say, in 1996 if this situation persists.

We give money for sporting events. We give money for the development of sportsmen, and I totally support that because I think there are very good reasons for our doing that. But I think it is a matter of great regret that we appear to be penny-pinching when it comes to supporting students who have the sort of intellectual capacity in the areas Australia needs if we are going to be competitive with the world and develop exports and markets in areas that take some activity.

There is no doubt that science and engineering are the keys to success and growth. If we look at the number of people employed in these disciplines in the countries around us, in the countries we are trying to compete with, it absolutely stands out that the number of people who have graduated with science or engineering is closely linked to the success of the country.

I urge the government to have another look at this, to look at what is being done to provide assistance for Australian students to participate. I urge the government not to confuse the money that is being given next year to hold the physics event in this country with the ongoing opportunity for young people to take part in it. Senator Schacht's answer to the question I raised yesterday is not adequate, and I ask him to go back to the minister he represents, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) with a view to looking at it in the way I have now spelled out.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed float of the NRMA has the potential to create the largest number of shareholders of any Australian company—some 1.8 million people. Many—probably most—of these people have never held shares before. The NRMA has budgeted to spend more than $30 million promoting the case for the conversion of the association from a mutual society into a company.

PARA.TAB: In the process, the NRMA has failed to fully apprise its members of the reasons not to convert from a mutual society to a company. These may include pressure on the NRMA to dispose of loss making services such as its road service, its legal services, its free maps and its consumer advocacy. The shareholders will demand bigger and better returns and services that do not make money would then be threatened.

More worrying for NRMA members—including me—is that the biggest winner from the NRMA float is not the members but the federal Treasury. Those directors of the NRMA who promote the float claim that the float is the best way to distribute the $2.2 billion worth of reserves that the NRMA has built up over two generations of service. While the NRMA prospectus makes a few mentions of tax treatment, it fails to mention that the likely total tax bill, when all the dust settles, will be about $600 million to $700 million, with the vast bulk of that being paid by the new shareholders. The NRMA has not given its members the overall picture of what happens to the NRMA pre and post a float from a taxation point of view.

I would like later to table advice I received from David Parker, a chartered accountant of many years standing and also a former director of the NRMA. His advice is compelling reading and highlights the massive tax disadvantage that the NRMA will face if it moves from a mutual society structure to a company. In the process of losing its mutual society status, the NRMA will lose $375 million worth of tax credits from its franking account; it will lose $375 million off the tax assessable assets base for capital gains purposes; it will have to bring $480 million of pre-1985 assets into the capital gains tax net; and its income becomes tax assessable.

Little wonder that all the NRMA competitors in the insurance industry have warmly welcomed the NRMA float. They know it will make the NRMA less competitive in insurance and less able to use its reserves to provide rebates on insurance premiums.

Mr Parker concludes that the NRMA board has not sufficiently explored more tax neutral alternatives to floating the society. We have to ask ourselves: why is that? I am not necessarily saying that the answers to the following questions are in the affirmative, but it is certainly possible. Was it because the current ruling faction of the NRMA saw moving to a company structure as the only means of maintaining control of the association and delaying board elections, which would probably have delivered a board majority to the Motorists Action Group? As a floated company, the majority of the board could move to remove minority directors, even if they were democratically elected.

Why did the board not agree to a `no' case being put to members? That is a very important question. Surely, with $30 million being spent on the `yes' case, the cost of putting a `no' case would pale into insignificance. Was it because the board thought or knew that the `no' case was compelling and that the advantages of maintaining a tax exempt mutual society structure more than outweighed the marginal advantages of moving to a company structure?

What about the federal government? The silence of the ASC is deafening. Is it because the deputy chair of the ASC also happens to be vice-president of the NRMA? Hundreds of thousands of Australians could be about to become shareholders with little or no concept of what that means in terms of responsibilities, the changed responsibilities of directors to maximise returns rather than maximise services, their own personal tax, and even the impact on their social security benefits because of treatment of investment incomes under the DSS income tests. I seek leave to table the document I spoke of earlier. I did deliver a copy of it to the minister and to the shadow minister 1 1/2 hours ago.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to raise an issue that is of very great concern to the part of Queensland in which I live—and, I might say, fish—and that is the move by the Queensland government to ban all angling in national parks. That, in itself, does not seem to be such a major move, but it does have the effect of really closing off from amateur angling all the saltwater mangrove creeks from Cape Upstart, just south of Ayr and Home Hill, right up to the Hinchinbrook Island.

PARA.TAB: That move by the Queensland government has brought a pall of doom across those people in North Queensland who are interested in recreational fishing. Last Saturday morning, in my own town of Ayr, there was a demonstration of about 300 boats and trailers driving through the main street. In Townsville during the week a meeting attracted over 2,000 fishermen, an extremely large meeting in this day and age when people are all too reluctant to get out of their armchairs and from in front of their television sets to make some mark on government policies. That meeting of over 2,000 fishermen was unanimous in opposing the proposal by the Queensland government to shut these creeks and this area off to amateur angling. The Labor member for Thuringowa, Mr Ken McElligott, showed a lot of courage in attending the meeting and, as I understand media reports, agreeing with the anglers that these closures of creeks should not take place.

Most anglers are responsible people. They do not take more fish than they need; in fact, if they are anything like me, they very seldom have the opportunity of taking fish. We just like going out into the creeks and fishing. It is only ever a bonus if we catch a fish or two. Having that right taken away from us is a major assault on the way of life of many North Queenslanders, not to mention the impact it would have on tourism, because many people come from all over Australia to partake in recreational fishing in the creeks of Upstart Bay, Cleveland Bay, Bowling Green Bay and up to Hinchinbrook Island.

All anglers would agree, if fish stocks are being attacked and depleted, to some reasonable management such as closing off a couple of creeks for longer periods or closing off all creeks for shorter periods. I do not think anyone objects to proper management of the fish stock in these creeks, but to absolutely ban fishing in all of them is an outrageous action. As well as affecting the tourist industry and the families that like recreational fishing, the proposal would also put many tackle shops in the towns of Home Hill, Ayr, Townsville, Thuringowa and Ingham out of business.

People's livelihoods that are invested in those businesses would disappear overnight. Many employees of those shops, which are in many instances quite big establishments, would simply find themselves without a job and so the unemployment queue would again be added to in the Townsville region—and it is already quite large. These sorts of actions by the Queensland government would add to the unemployment problem in the Townsville region.

I have been disappointed that, apart from Mr McElligott, the Labor member for Thuringowa, the other elected representatives in the Townsville region have not raised their voices. These include Mr Geoff Smith, the member for Townsville; Mr Ken Davies, the member for Mundingburra; and Senator Reynolds and Mr Lindsay, in the federal parliament, who all represent people in that area. I have been disappointed that they have not joined the opposition to this move by the Queensland government.

I am speaking tonight because I cannot attend a meeting protesting this move which is being held at the Burdekin theatre in my home town. I would very much have liked to have been at that protest meeting, but unfortunately I am required to be in parliament. I am paid to do that; so it is appropriate that I should be here.

Not being able to be part of the protest meeting in my home town, I want to make my own protest in this chamber. I ask the Queensland government to seriously consider the implications of its move. No-one objects to sensible management of the environment or of the fish stock, but simply closing these creeks in a blanket way is not the way to do it. I would hope that the enormous protests that have developed in the region will make the Queensland government realise it has made the wrong decision. It is my hope that it will see the sense of the arguments put by those opposing the action and amend the proposals that it currently has.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to place on the record tonight a follow-up to something that I placed on the record a couple of weeks ago—a letter by Pamela Bornhorst, formerly of the ABC 7.30 Report, protesting against an article written in the Courier-Mail by Peter Charlton. This letter gives her an opportunity to record her side of an argument; so I will read it. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: On June 2, 1994 . . . Senator Christabel Chamarette, tabled a document in the Australian Senate relating to my axing as presenter of the Queensland edition of the ABC's 7.30 Report.
It has been assumed and reported that I was either the author of this document or in some way collaborated in its preparation.
For the record, I wish to state that I was not the author nor was I involved with it in any way. I had never sighted it.
Furthermore, at no stage prior to the tabling of this document in the Federal Parliament was I contacted to determine whether I supported its contents or the tabling of it in the Senate.

As you would be aware, there was considerable public disquiet over my removal from the 7.30 Report. In the weeks following, a group of supporters (including some members of the Friends of the ABC) gathered some 7000 signatures calling for my re-instatement.

For my part, in January this year I told a meeting of my supporters that I was personally devastated by the episode, given my 16 year association with the ABC, but I wanted to put it behind me and get on with my life and my new job in talk back radio.

However, I believed then as I do now that there was political interference and I remain deeply concerned about the treatment handed out to those within the ABC who supported me, particularly the five journalists from the Queensland edition of the 7.30 Report who supported me in writing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about the Workskill Australia-New England competition. Honourable senators might wonder why I would want to speak about this tonight in this chamber. I happen to be the patron of the Workskill Australia-New England competition.

PARA.TAB: Workskill has done a great deal of good to help the apprentices in that area achieve better skills and higher standards. The 180 competitors who last weekend came from all over New England and the north-west—Moree, Glen Innes, Armidale, Coonabarabran, Inverell—really strived to win. But all the people who attended the competition were winners because those who enter Workskill all improve their skills and achieve a lot more.

There were competitions in bricklaying, cabinet-making, cooking, autobody repair, automechanics, carpentry, electrics, hairdressing, metal fabrication, office secretarial support, plant and transport, mechanics, plumbing, turning, vehicle painting and welding. There were also two demonstration categories—art design and autoelectrical. All of them, as I say, were winners because they all competed and did a great job. I congratulate the winners. I also congratulate all those who put themselves on the line to strive to improve their skills.

Bob Turnbull, who is really an ambassador at large for the Workskill foundation, spoke at the presentation dinner and gave a very good recitation of what it is all about. There is a volunteer network of something like 1,500 people to promote higher standards of performance in vocational training and to give recognition to young workers and their teachers and trainers. That has all happened over the last 12 years.

This has been achieved with the support of governments, industry, trade unions and the TAFE system. Over 25,000 young people around Australia have taken up the challenge to test their skills against the very high standards that are set in the Workskill competitions. Some of the people in the turning competition start off with just one piece of steel and a blueprint and, within eight hours, they have just about gone through every discipline that is required to be performed in the turning field.

Whilst everyone aims for high performance in vocational training, the end result which I believe we all want to achieve is world standard performance in our work force. That is what this is about. It is great to see the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) at the table tonight because he knows the worth of competing. The foundation has been working to match industry developments by including modern technology categories in the competition.

If we look at our international performance we see that the team of 35 young people that Australia sent to the 1993 Workskill Olympics in Taipei was one of the most competent teams to represent Australia. It finished 10th out of 24 countries, winning four bronze medals and 13 diplomas, which are rewarded for high standard performances. It was a great performance from Australia.

It is interesting to note that 167 Australians have competed and have won 37 medals in international competitions since 1985. Whilst Australia's results over five Workskill Olympic competitions have shown that we are the best performing English-speaking nation in terms of both medals won and the percentages of the diplomas awarded, we see a need—and I am sure the minister would agree with this—to improve this performance at the international level. Just listen to the countries which have been at the top of the competition in the last few years: Japan, Korea and Taiwan. They are the ones that have led the way. If we are to compete in Asia, we have to have a work force in Australia that is competent, competitive and always striving for excellence and that little bit extra.

A new pilot program has been started by the foundation this year. The program is known as CLIP, which is the continuous learning and improvement program. It is hoped that it will help—and it will help, I am quite sure—those regional winners to prepare for the national finals and to develop skills to assist them to succeed in their careers.

All the young people I met who competed last weekend were absolutely ecstatic that they had competed. The winners were a little more ecstatic, I suppose, than the ones who did not win, but they all felt very excited that they had competed and tested their own skills standards against everyone else. The wealth of this nation will be based on our ability to compete on the world stage. I am quite sure Workskill will be right at the forefront of that to make sure we have young apprentices going on through the field to become our leaders for tomorrow.

As I said, Workskill is about striving for excellence, recognition of excellence and producing future leaders of industry. We all stand up in this place, laud our Commonwealth Games gold medallists—I do, as does everyone else in this place—and give them due recognition. But I think it is time that we started to give due recognition to young people who strive for excellence in whatever field. That is why I am here tonight speaking on behalf of those people who competed and those others associated with them. Our quality of labour must be internationally competitive. The only way we can do that is by making sure that we have people competing at the highest level.

In October 1995, which is only a year away, the winners of the Australian competition will form the Australian team, with the Australian colours, and compete in Lyon in France. Hopefully, we will have some gold medal winners. If our competitors do come back with some gold, silver or bronze medals, I think they should be acclaimed in this place, just as we acclaim any of our sports people who do well when they compete. We should think of giving the Order of Australia, which we often give to our sporting stars, to some of these people who attain the highest world standards at the international Olympics. It the same competition and it is just as intense.

It is a great spectator sport. Anyone who has been to a Workskill final or the Workskill Olympics, which were held in Australia a few years ago, will know how interesting the sport is. That is how I became so interested in it and became its patron in the north of New South Wales. When I was the patron of the Workskill Olympics in Sydney, I saw the amount of help and support that other countries give their competitors. I think we have to start doing the same thing here.

I congratulate all those who competed. I congratulate the employers who gave their apprentices and other young people time off to train and practise for the competition. I wish the winners well at the national finals. I congratulate the sponsors who put so much time, effort and money into helping the competition. I particularly single out Helen Tickle from the Tamworth TAFE; Roslyn Dewick, the coordinator of the New England

SPEECH.PARA: Workskill; John Morris, the chairman; and Joanne Thomas, the secretary. They all played a very big part. If we can all have a little bit of a think about recognising our young people—whether they be sports people or people who strive for excellence in their profession—then I think Australia will be a better place.

PARA.TAB: The following document was tabled:

The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Please provide a breakdown of government funding to Australian Defence Industries (ADI) in the 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years.
(2) Please provide details of the Government funding going to support administration costs in these years, and what is the justification.
(3) During the 1992-93 financial year, did the Government write off $366.2 million in loans to ADI.
(4) How did this occur.
(5) Does the Government expect that ADI will be able to support itself eventually, and where is the evidence.

(6) Please explain the contradiction between selling off Australian National Line (ANL) with far less debts than ADI and retaining ADI when ANL also has a role in the Government's policy of self-reliance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government has not provided financial support for ADI's ongoing operations. Payments to ADI have been restricted to transitional costs associated with establishing the Company and those related to obligations which ADI inherited from the Commonwealth including employee related liabilities and others involving occupational health and safety and environmental requirements. The totals of transitional costs were as follows: 1990-91—$14.33m; 1991-92—$13.98m; 1992-93—$21.23m; 1993-94—$17.55m. In addition, $14m was advanced in 1993-94 as the first instalment of a bridging loan facility of up to $38m, for the clean up of former Defence properties before redevelopment.
(2) No government funding has gone towards supporting administration costs in these years.

(3) During the 1992-93 financial year the Government did not write off $366.2 million in loans to ADI. ADI's capital structure was determined during the 1993-94 financial year. The Commonwealth's total investment (reflecting the net value of the assets transferred to ADI) was set at $426.204 million, comprising share capital of $366.204 million and $60 million as a long-term loan, repayable at commercial interest rates.

(5) ADI has supported itself fully since it was established. The Company has returned a profit in each year since it began operations in May 1989. The Company's earnings, before tax and abnormal items were: 1990—$23.4m; 1991—$29.4m; 1992—$33.6m; and 1993—$34.4m. This information is contained in ADI's annual reports which have been tabled in Parliament.
(6) The Government has made no decisions in relation to the future of ADI. In relation to the issue of ADI's debt, see the answer to questions (3) and (5).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the department's total expenditure on assertiveness training courses during the 1993-94 financial year.
(2) How many: (a) women; and (b) men, attended those courses.
(3) What other personal development courses have been utilised by the department during the 1993-94 financial year.
(4) For each of those courses, how many: (a) women; and (b) men, attended those courses.
(5) What was the department's total expenditure on each of these courses during the 1993-94 financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department's expenditure on assertiveness training courses during the 1993/94 financial year was approximately $400,000. This amount comprised:

expenditure of approximately $383,000 for the internally conducted assertion component of the Department's client service training program and is made up entirely of trainee and trainer salary costs, and
expenditure of approximately $17,000 for Departmental staff to attend externally-provided assertion training courses and includes trainee salary costs, course fees and travel costs.
(2) (a) & (b) 1,761 women and 1,203 men attended the internally-conducted program; and 25 women and 26 men attended the externally-provided courses.
(3)-(5) None of the training courses Departmental staff undertake are considered to be personal development courses in the sense of being for the benefit of the individual and not of direct relevance

ANSWER.PARA: to the services they provide as officers of the Department. The Department's objective in providing training is to enhance its staff's productivity and efficiency in the support of the provision of quality service to its clients.

PARA.TAB: Training in assertion is provided for public contact staff to assist them in dealing confidently and politely with the full range of the Department's clients in undertaking their responsibilities to assist clients obtain their entitlements while ensuring that all necessary information is obtained in order to properly determine a client's eligibility for payment. The training also assists them to operate more effectively as members of a work team.
